question.text:
Filter A is a discrete-time LTI system with input x[n] and output $y[n]$ 
<image>
The frequency response magnitude and group delay functions for Filter A are shown in Figure 1.10-1. The signal $x[n]$ ,also shown in Figure 1.10-1, is the sum of three narrowband pulses. Specifically, Figure 1.10-1 contains the following plots:
$x[n]$ 
$|X(e^{j\omega})|$ ,the Fourier transform magnitude of $x[n]$ 
•Frequency response magnitude plot for filter A.
• Group delay plot for filter A.
In Figure 1.10-2 you are given 4 possible output signals $y_{i}[n],\quad i=1,2,3,4$ . Determine which one of the possible output signals is the output of filter A when the input is $x[n]$ . Provide a justification for your choice.
<image>
Figure 1.10-1: The signal and the filter
<image>
Figure 1.10-2: Possible output signals.

answer.text:
$$y[n]=y_{2}[n]$$
Justification:
The input signal $x[n]$ is made up of three narrow-band pulses: pulse-1 is a low-frequency pulse (whose peak is around 0.12π radians), pulse-2 is a higher-frequency pulse (0.3π radians),and pulse-3 is the highest-frequency pulse (0.5π radians).
Let $H(e^{j\omega})$ be the frequency response of Filter A. We read off the following values from the frequency response magnitude and group delay plots:
$$ egin{aligned}{|H(e^{j(0.12\pi)})|}&{{}\approx1.8}\ {|H(e^{j(0.3\pi)})|}&{{}\approx1.7}\ {|H(e^{j(0.5\pi)})|}&{{}\approx0}\ {	au_{g}(0.12\pi)}&{{}\approx40~\mathrm{s a m p l e s}}\ {	au_{g}(0.3\pi)}&{{}\approx80~\mathrm{s a m p l e s}}\ \end{aligned}$$
From these values, we would expect pulse-3 to be totally absent from the output signal $y[n]$ . Pulse-1 will be scaled up by a factor of 1.8 and its envelope delayed by about 40 samples.Pulse-2 will be scaled up by a factor of 1.7 and its envelope delayed by about 80 samples. The correct output is thus $y_{2}[n]$

short_answer_description: The variable represents the identifier of the correct output signal selected from the four possible options ($y_1[n]$, $y_2[n]$, $y_3[n]$, or $y_4[n]$) shown in Figure 1.10-2. The expected format is the mathematical notation corresponding to the chosen signal label.

reasoning_flow.step: From the |X(e^{jω})| plot, identify the normalized frequencies (in units of π rad/sample) at which the three narrowband pulses are centered.
From the frequency-response magnitude plot of Filter A, read off the approximate magnitude |H(e^{jω})| at the three frequencies identified in Step 1.
From the group-delay plot of Filter A, read off the approximate group delay τ_g (in samples) at the first two pulse frequencies (0.12π and 0.3π).

Using the values from Steps 1–3, state the expected effect of Filter A on each of the three pulses (i.e., whether each pulse is passed or suppressed, the amplitude scaling, and the approximate envelope delay).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: pulse-1: passed, scaled ×1.8, delayed ≈40 samples; pulse-2: passed, scaled ×1.7, delayed ≈80 samples; pulse-3: suppressed (≈0 gain)

reasoning_flow.step: Compare the expected per-pulse amplitude and delay pattern from Step 4 with the four candidate outputs y1[n]…y4[n] and decide which candidate matches the pattern (one candidate should show the low-frequency pulse delayed by ≈40 samples, the mid-frequency pulse delayed by ≈80 samples, and the high-frequency pulse absent).

question.text: Consider the three-dimensional case $\Phi(\mathrm{x,}\mathrm{y,}\mathrm{z})$ and assume the boundary conditions yield $\mathbf{k}^{2}=0$ 1. If potential $\Phi=0$ everywhere along three intersecting edges of a cube (and therefore at four corners), and $\Phi=10$ volts at the opposite corner, what is the single value of Φ at the remaining three intermediate corners? Explain briefly. <image>

answer.text:
The general solution in Equation 4.34 may be applied to satisfy the given boundary conditions. Place the coordinate system along the vertex where the three zeroed edges intersect. Along any axis, at least two coordinates are zero, this means that the first four constants in the general solution can be non-zero, but all the rest must be zero. But symmetry also restricts the solution. For the expanded form, you can readily convince yourselfthat $C_{2}=C_{3}=C_{4}=C$ . For the factored form, in order to require that $C_{5},C_{6}$ ,and $C_{7}$ are zero, we need that $DF=BF=BD=0$ . But symmetry in this case requires that the problem is invariant if the axes are permuted; as such,$A=C=E$ and $B=D=F$ '. In other words, symmetry means that Equation 4.34 can be written as 

$$\Phi(x,y,z)=(A x+B)(A y+B)(A z+B)$$

Then it follows that $B=D=F=0$ . Immediately, we recognize that the only term that survives is the $x y z$ term. If the cube has length, (, then $10=C_{1}\ell^{3}\Rightarrow C_{1}=10/\ell^{3}\left(([\mathrm{V}]\right)$ in this application). Along the intermediate corners, either x or y or z is zero; therefore, the $x y z$ term vanishes, leaving 

$\Phi({\mathrm{i n t e r m e d i a t e~c o r n e r s}})=0.$

short_answer_description: The single value of the electric potential \Phi at the three intermediate corners of the cube, determined based on the given boundary conditions (0V along three intersecting edges and 10V at the opposite corner), expected as a numerical value with units (volts).

reasoning_flow.step: Place a Cartesian coordinate system at the vertex where the three zero-potential edges intersect; state the potential at the origin and at the opposite corner in coordinates (x,y,z) with cube side length ℓ.
State the implication for Φ on any corner where at least two coordinates are zero (i.e., along any of the three given zero edges).

Using symmetry under permutation of axes and the boundary conditions in Steps 1–2, write the most general separable cubic polynomial form for Φ(x,y,z) that is invariant under interchange of x,y,z and consistent with linear factors in each coordinate.
Apply the zero-potential conditions from Step 2 to the general form in Step 3 to find constraints on the constant B.
Substitute B=0 into the form from Step 3 and state the surviving term.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: Φ(x,y,z)=A^3 x y z (only the x y z term survives)

reasoning_flow.step: Use the value Φ(ℓ,ℓ,ℓ)=10 from Step 1 to solve for the constant A^3 (or equivalently the coefficient C1 in Φ=C1 x y z).
Write the explicit potential formula Φ(x,y,z) using the coefficient found in Step 6.
Evaluate Φ at any intermediate corner where exactly one coordinate equals zero (e.g., (ℓ,ℓ,0)) using the formula from Step 7.
State the value of Φ at all three intermediate corners given the result of Step 8.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: Φ=0 at each of the three intermediate corners

question.text: In the following pedigree shows the segregation of two dferent recessive traits. =female showing trait 1 only = male showing trait 2 only = male showing both traits <image> Assuming that both traits are due to linked autosomal genes that are 10 cM apart,calculate the probability that the indicated child will have both recessive traits.

answer.text:
Remember that the traits are recessive! $\mathrm{A}=\mathrm{wt}$ $\mathrm{a}=\mathrm{trait}1$ $\mathrm{b}=\mathrm{trait}2$ Dad's genotype: $\mathrm{aaBb}$ *He's affected with trait 1, so he must be aa *He's not affected with trait 2, but he must have gotten one b from his father who was bb. So he must be heterozygous for trait 2 with Bb. Dad's chromosomes look like this: aB (from mother) ab (from father) Mom's genotype: $\mathrm{AaBb}$ *Her father is aabb, so she must have gotten ab alleles from him. However, she is not affected, and so she must be heterozygous for both traits. Mom's chromosomes look like this: AB (from mother) ab (from father) The genes are 10 cM apart, so crossing over between them will occur 10% of the time. For example, Mom's gametes will exist in the following ratios:
AB (Parental) 45%
ab (Parental) 45%
aB (crossover) 5%
Ab (crossover) 5%
Otherwise, the two alleles on one chromosome will remain linked 90% of the time.
(Note that for the dad's chromosome, when crossing over between the alleles occurs, the allele combinations remain the same)

p(aabb child) = p(ab chromosome from mom) and p(ab chromosome from dad)
= (0.45) x (0.5) = 0.225

short_answer_description: The calculated numeric probability that the indicated child will express both recessive traits, based on the provided pedigree and the assumption that the traits are caused by linked autosomal genes separated by a map distance of 10 cM.

reasoning_flow.step: State allele symbols for the two recessive traits (use A/a for trait1 locus and B/b for trait2 locus) and specify which alleles are wild-type vs recessive.

From the pedigree, determine the father's genotype at both loci given that traits are recessive and using only the pedigree information (father shows trait1 only and his parents' phenotype symbols in the diagram).

From the pedigree, determine the mother's genotype at both loci given that traits are recessive and using only the pedigree information (mother is unaffected and her father is affected with both traits as shown).
Assign phased chromosome allele combinations (haplotypes) for the mother consistent with her genotype AaBb and the pedigree information about her affected father.
Assign phased chromosome allele combinations (haplotypes) for the father consistent with his genotype aaBb and the pedigree information about his parental origin of alleles.
Given the genes are 10 cM apart, compute the expected gamete frequency distribution from the heterozygous mother (AaBb) in terms of the two parental haplotypes and two recombinant haplotypes.
Determine the probability that the father contributes the ab haplotype to the child given his phased chromosomes aB and ab.
Calculate the probability that the child is aabb by multiplying the probability mother supplies ab and the probability father supplies ab.

question.text: A certain electric battery is not quite ideal. It can be thought of as a perfect cell with constant output voltage $V_{0}$ connected in series to a resistance $r,$ but there is no way to remove this internal resistance from the battery. <image> The battery is connected to N identical lightbulbs in parallel. The bulbs each have a fixed resistance $R,$ ,independent of the current through them. It is observed that the configuration dissipates more total power through the bulbs when $N=5$ than it does for any other value of $N$ . In terms of $R$ ,what range of values is possible for possible for $r?$

answer.text:
Onecan simply start with the fact that the maximum power is dissipated when the external resistance is equal to the internal resistance.$\\mathrm{O r}$ take the derivative of $P$ with respect to R and set it equal to zero. In either case, you will get 
$$r=R_{e}=\frac{R}{N}$$
Don't assume, however, that the answer is then $r=R/5$ Since we can't have half a bulb, we don't actually know that the power is a maximum for the circuit, only that it is the maximum configuration. It could be that a larger power output could occur with a resistance between $R/4$ and $R/5,$ or maybe between $R/5$ and $R/6$ 
A rough guess would be to assume 
$$\frac{R}{5.5}\leq r\leq\frac{R}{4.5}$$
A better estimate would be to assume a quadratic function of $1/N$ with respect to $P$ in the vicinity of $P_{\\mathrm{m a x}}$ (think Taylor expansion of $P)$ , and then the important point is the halfway point between $1/N$ and $1/(N\pm1)$ or 
$$\frac{1/N+1/(N\pm1)}{2}=\frac{1}{2N}+\frac{1}{2(N\pm1)}=\frac{N\pm1/2}{N(N\pm1)}$$
So the bounds are 
$$\frac{5.5R}{30}\leq r\leq\frac{4.5R}{20}$$
The correct approach is to assume the power outputs at N and $N\pm1$ are equal, and solve for the necessary value of r. Then 
$$\frac{N}{(N r+R)^{2}}=\frac{N\pm1}{(N r\pm r+R)2}$$
or 
$$N^{3}r^{2}+2N^{2}(R\pm r)r+N(R\pm r)^{2}=N^{3}r^{2}+2N^{2}R r+N R^{2}\pm N^{2}r^{2}\pm2N R r\pm R^{2}.$$
Thankfully, we loose the cubic term 
$$\pm2N^{2}r^{2}\pm2N R r+N r^{2}=\pm N^{2}r^{2}\pm2N R r\pm R^{2}.$$
To save space, flip the \pmto the one term that doesn't have it.
$$N^{2}r^{2}\pm N r^{2}=R^{2}$$
Onlypositive answers have meaning, so 
$$r=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N(N\pm1)}}R.$$
which give the correct bounds as 
$$\frac{R}{\sqrt{30}}\leq r\leq\frac{R}{\sqrt{20}}$$ 
If you knew about geometric means, you might have been able to just write this down.

short_answer_description: A mathematical inequality or interval expressed in LaTeX format representing the possible range of values for the internal resistance r in terms of the bulb resistance R. This range is derived from the condition that the total power dissipated by the N=5 parallel lightbulbs is greater than the power dissipated for any other integer number of bulbs.

reasoning_flow.step: For N identical bulbs each of resistance R connected in parallel, compute the equivalent resistance R_e of the N-bulb bank.
Write an expression for the power P dissipated in the N-bulb bank in terms of V0, r, R_e (or N and R). (You may omit the overall factor V0^2 since it is constant.)
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: P ∝ R_e / (r + R_e)^2 = N R / (N r + R)^2

reasoning_flow.step: State the condition on r such that the observed maximum power occurs at integer N rather than at N±1: write the equality between P(N) and P(N+1) that locates the boundary where P(N)=P(N+1).
Solve the equation from the previous step for r in terms of R and N for the N versus N+1 boundary.
Write the analogous equality for the boundary where P(N)=P(N-1).
Solve the equation from the previous step for r in terms of R and N for the N versus N-1 boundary.
Substitute N = 5 into the two boundary formulas to obtain the numerical range for r in terms of R.

question.text: Two perfectly conducting plates are arranged as shown in Fig. 8P.7. A magnetic field trapped between the plates is established in such a way that it does not penetrate the perfectly conducting plates. Also $H_{3}=0$ and $\begin{array}{r}{\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{3}}=0}\end{array}$ . Under the assumption that $b\ll L$ ,find the $x_{1}\mathrm{-c o m p o n e n t}$ of the force per unit t $x_{3}$ on the section of the lower plate between $x_{1}=L{~}{\operatorname{a n d}}{~}x_{1}=-L$ . You may assume that, when $x_{1}=-L,\:\mathbf{H}=H_{0}i_{1}$ 'where $H_{0}$ is a known constant. <image> Figure 3: Two perfectly conducting plates with an applied magnetic field

answer.text: $${\mathsf X}_{1}=-{\mathsf L}$$ Figure 1: Diagram of surfaces (1), (2), (3), and (4) to evaluate the force on the lower plate using the Maxwell Stress Tensor. Before finding the force, we must calculate the H field at $x_{1}=L$ . To find this field let us use $$\oint\bar{B}\cdot\bar{n}d a=0$$ over the dotted surface. At $x_{1}=+L$ $$\bar{H}(x_{1}=L)=H_{0}\bar{i}_{1}$$ over surface (4)$\bar{H}=0$ , and over surface (2), H is in the $\overline{{i}}_{1}$ direction, where $\bar{n}=\bar{i}_{2}$ . Thus over surface (2),$\bar{B}\cdot\bar{n}=0$ . Hence, the integral in (1) reduces to $$\begin{aligned}{}&{{}-\int_{(1)}\mu_{0}H_{0}d a+\int_{(3)}\mu_{0}H(x_{1}=+L)d a=0}\\ {}\&{{}-\mu_{0}H_{0}a+\mu_{0}H b=0\qquad\operatorname{p e r u i t l e n g t h}}\\ \end{aligned}$$ Thus: $$\begin{aligned}{}&{{}\bar{H}(x_{1}=+L)=(a/b)H_{0}\bar{i}_{1}}\\ {}\&{{}T_{i j}=\mu_{0}H_{i}H_{j}-\frac{\delta_{i j}}{2}\mu_{0}H_{k}H_{k}}\\ \end{aligned}$$ Hence, the stress tensor over surfaces (1), (2), and (3) is: $$T_{i j}=\left[\begin{array}{c c c}{\frac{\mu_{0}}{2}H_{1}^{2}}&{0}&{0}\\ {0}&{-\frac{\mu_{0}}{2}H_{1}^{2}}&{0}\\ {0}&{0}&{-\frac{\mu_{0}}{2}H_{1}^{2}}\\ \end{array}\right]$$ Over surface (4) $$T_{i j}=[0]$$ Thus the force in the 1 direction is $$\begin{aligned}{f_{1}}&{{}=\int T_{i j}n_{j}\cdot d a}\\ {f_{1}}&{{}=-\int_{(1)}T_{11}d a+\int_{(3)}T_{11}d a+\int_{(2)}T_{12}d a.}\\ \end{aligned}$$ Thus, since the last integral makes no contribution, $$f_{1}=-\frac{\mu_{0}}{2}H_{0}^{2}(a)+\frac{\mu_{0}}{2}H_{0}^{2}\left(\frac{a}{b}\right)^{2}\cdot b=\frac{\mu_{0}}{2}H_{0}^{2}a\left(\frac{a}{b}-1\right)$$ Since $T_{i j}=0$ over surface (4) there is no contribution to the force from this surface and, by symmetry, there is no contribution to the force from the surfaces perpendicular to the $x_{j}$ axis. Thus, the force per unit depth in 1 direction is (2).

short_answer_description: The formula for the x1-component of the force per unit length in the x3 direction acting on the section of the lower plate between x1 = -L and x1 = L. The answer should be a mathematical expression in LaTeX format expressed in terms of the magnetic permeability (\mu_0), the magnetic field constant (H_0), and the geometric parameters (a and b).

reasoning_flow.step: Extract from the problem statement the given magnetic field at x1 = -L and the plate spacings labeled a and b.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: H(x1=-L)=H0 i1; spacings: upper channel thickness = a, lower channel thickness = b

reasoning_flow.step: State the divergence-free flux integral of B to use over a closed pillbox/dotted surface that encloses the region between the plates.

Identify which faces of the dotted closed surface have nonzero normal flux contributions given H at x1=-L is H0 i1, H on outer conductor surfaces is zero, and H has only i1 component in the channel (∂/∂x3=0).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: Nonzero contributions only from faces at x1=-L (area a per unit depth) and x1=+L (area b per unit depth)

reasoning_flow.step: Write the flux integral in terms of μ0, H0 over the face at x1=-L and μ0, H(+L) over the face at x1=+L, per unit depth, and set it equal to zero.
Solve the equation from the previous step for H(+L) in terms of H0, a, and b.
Write the Maxwell stress tensor Tij for a purely magnetic field (in SI) in terms of μ0 and the components Hi.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: Tij = μ0 Hi Hj - (δij/2) μ0 Hk Hk

reasoning_flow.step: Compute the component T11 for a field purely along i1 (H1 nonzero) and evaluate its value over a face where H = H1 i1.

Express the net force in the x1 direction per unit depth on the lower plate as integrals of T11 over surfaces (1) at x1=-L, (3) at x1=+L, and (2) (which gives zero), then substitute T11 values using H0 at -L and H(+L) at +L.
Substitute H(+L) = (a/b) H0 into the expression for f1 and simplify to obtain the force per unit depth in the x1 direction.

question.text: A long thin rod is fixed at $x=0$ and driven at $x=l.$ , as shown in Fig. 9P.10. The driving transducer consists of a rigid plate with area A attached to the end of the rod, where it undergoes the displacement $\delta(l,t)$ from an equilibrium position exactly between two fixed plates. These fixed plates are biased by potentials $V_{0}$ and driven by the voltage $v=\operatorname{R e}(\hat{V}e^{j\omega t})$ as shown.$(|\hat{V}|\ll V_{0})$ <image> Figure 4:A long thin rod fixed at $x=0$ . and driven by imposed voltages at $x=l+\delta(l,t)$ Derive a boundary condition relating $\delta(l,t)$ ,$(\textstyle\frac{\partial\delta}{\partial x})(l,t)$ and $v(t)$

answer.text: At the outset, we can write the equation of motion for the massless plate: $$-a T(l,t)+f^{e}(t)=M\frac{\partial^{2}\delta}{\partial t^{2}}(l,t)\approx0,$$ Using the maxwell stress tensor we find the force of electrical origin $f^{e}(t)$ to be $$f^{e}(t)=\frac{\varepsilon_{0}A}{2}\left[\frac{(V_{0}+v(t))^{2}}{(d-\delta(l,t))^{2}}-\frac{(V_{0}-v(t))^{2}}{(d-\delta(l,t))^{2}}\right]$$ Since $v(t)\ll V_{0}$ $\delta(l,t)\ll d,$ we can linearize $f^{e}(t)$ $$f^{e}(t)=\left[\frac{2\varepsilon_{0}A V_{0}^{2}}{d^{3}}\right]\delta(l,t)+\left[\frac{2\varepsilon_{0}A V_{0}}{d^{2}}\right]v(t)$$ Recognizing that $\begin{array}{r}{T(l,t)=E\frac{\partial\delta}{\partial x}(l,t)}\end{array}$ we can write our boundary condition at $x=l$ in the desired form $$a E\frac{\partial\delta}{\partial x}(l,t)=\frac{2\varepsilon_{0}A V_{0}^{2}}{d^{3}}\delta(l,t)+\frac{2\varepsilon_{0}A V_{0}}{d^{2}}v(t)$$

short_answer_value: $a E \frac{\partial \delta}{\partial x}(l,t) = \frac{2\epsilon_0 A V_0^2}{d^3}\,\delta(l,t) + \frac{2\epsilon_0 A V_0}{d^2}\,v(t)$
short_answer_description: A mathematical expression in LaTeX format representing the boundary condition at the driven end of the rod ($x=l$). This equation must relate the displacement $\delta(l,t)$, the strain term $\frac{\partial\delta}{\partial x}(l,t)$, and the driving voltage $v(t)$, typically by equating the internal mechanical force of the rod to the net electrostatic force generated by the transducer plates.

reasoning_flow.step: Write the dynamic balance (equation of motion) for the massless rigid plate at x = l, relating the axial tension T(l,t), the net electrical force f^e(t) on the plate, and the plate mass M and acceleration.
Use the fact that the plate is massless (M ≈ 0) to simplify the equation from Step 1 into an algebraic equilibrium condition.
Express the axial tension T(l,t) at x = l in terms of the rod's Young's modulus E and the slope of transverse displacement ∂δ/∂x at x = l.

Write the electrostatic force f^{e}(t) on the movable plate as the difference of the electrostatic pressures from the two biased fixed plates using the plate area A, permittivity ε_0, plate separations (d−δ(l,t)), and voltages (V_0 ± v(t)).
Assuming small signals v(t) compared to V_0 and small displacement δ(l,t) compared to d, linearize the expression for f^{e}(t) from Step 4 to first order in v(t) and δ(l,t).
Substitute T(l,t) from Step 3 and the linearized f^{e}(t) from Step 5 into the equilibrium condition from Step 2 and rearrange to express the boundary condition relating ∂δ/∂x(l,t), δ(l,t), and v(t).

question.text:
Consider the following finite-state Markov Chain.

<image>
Let $p_{i,j}\left(night)$ denote the probability of the process ending up in state jin n transitions,
conditioned on the fact that the process started in state i. In other words,
$p_{i,j}(n)=P\left(X_{n}=j\mid X_{0}=iight)$ . Compute the value of each of the limits below, or else explain briefly why it does not exist.
 $\operatorname*{l i m}_{n	o\infty}p_{4,5}(n)$

answer.text:
Since both recurrent classes are aperiodic, once the process enters a recurrent class containing state i, the long-term probability of being in state i equals the corresponding steady-state probability $\pi_{i}$ . Considering first the class {3,4,5}, by symmetry in the transition probabilities,th long-term probability of the process being in a particular state is the same for every state in the class. Thus,$ egin{array}{r}{\operatorname*{l i m}_{n	o\infty}p_{4,5}(n)=1/3}\end{array}$ .Similarly, looking at $\{6,7\}$ ,the simple form of the chain allows us to conclude that lin $\mathrm{m}_{n	o\infty}p_{7,7}(n)=1/3$ . (If you don't see it immediately, then let $\pi_{6}$ be the steady state probability of being in state 6 and $\pi_{7}$ be that corresponding to state 7, where both are conditioned on the process starting out in the recurrent class {6, 7}. Conditioning on the previous transition:$\pi_{6}=(1/2)\pi_{6}+\pi_{7}$ . But also $\pi_{6}+\pi_{7}=1$ ,and the result follows solving the two equations.)
$$\mathsf{iv})\lim_{n	o\infty}p_{4,5}(n)=1/3.$$

short_answer_description: The calculated value for the limit $\lim_{n\to\infty}p_{4,5}(n)$, representing the long-term probability of the Markov chain being in state 5 given it started in state 4. The answer should be a mathematical expression, such as a fraction, in LaTeX format.

reasoning_flow.step: Extract the set of states that are in the communicating class containing state 4 from the chain diagram.
Determine whether the class {3,4,5} is closed (i.e., no transitions from any of 3,4,5 to states outside the set) using the transition arrows in the diagram.
Determine whether every state in {3,4,5} communicates with every other state in that set (i.e., the class is irreducible) using the transition probabilities in the diagram.
Determine whether the class {3,4,5} is aperiodic by computing the greatest common divisor of cycle lengths for any state in the class from the transition structure.
State whether, for an irreducible, closed, aperiodic finite class, the limit of p_{i,j}(n) as n→∞ exists and equals the stationary probability π_j conditioned on starting in that class.
Use symmetry of transition probabilities within the class {3,4,5} to state the relation among the stationary probabilities π_3, π_4, and π_5 (conditioned on the chain being in the class).
Use the normalization condition π_3 + π_4 + π_5 = 1 together with the relation from the previous step to compute π_5 (the long-run probability of being in state 5 given the class {3,4,5}).

State the value of lim_{n→∞} p_{4,5}(n) given that the process starts in state 4 (which lies in the closed, irreducible, aperiodic class {3,4,5}) and the computed stationary probability π_5 for that class.

question.text:
The factor effect plots below represent the results of an orthogonal array based matrix experiment.
<image>
Factor Effects on the Mean 
<image>
 After optimizing the S/N ratio, what level should be selected for the scaling factor in order to place the mean response of the system at 16 seconds? (Assume an additive model holds for the mean response of the system)

answer.text:
Again, the average of the control factor level means $(\mathrm{e.g.,m_{A1},m_{A2},m_{A3}})$ for any control factor is always equal to the grand mean () for the experiment. This applies equally well to the means as it does to the S/N ratio if an additive model is assumed to hold. Looking at the factor effect plot for mean, the grand mean appears to be about 16.2 seconds.

You've already decided to set the factor levels A2, B1, D3 in order to increase the S/N ratio. Given these changes in control factor settings, the predicted mean is the grand mean plus the sum of the factor effects. From the factor effects plot, you can estimate the S/N ration as $16.2\mathrm{sec}-1.2\mathrm{sec}-1.5\mathrm{sec}=13.5\mathrm{sec}$ 

In order to get back on target at 16 seconds, we should use the scaling factor to raise the mean time by 2.5 seconds. Setting C1 should get us most of the way back on target, but we may want to go to a slightly lower level of control factor C beyond the level we tested to get the product back on target.

short_answer_description: The specific level identifier (e.g., A1, B2, C3) for the factor designated as the scaling factor that is required to adjust the system's mean response to the target value of 16 seconds, assuming an additive model.

reasoning_flow.step: From the mean response factor effect plot, read the grand mean (overall average mean response) for the experiment.
From the mean response factor effect plot, read the effect (deviation from the grand mean) associated with setting factor A to level A2.
From the mean response factor effect plot, read the effect (deviation from the grand mean) associated with setting factor B to level B1.
Compute the sum of the factor effects for the chosen settings A2 and B1 (add the values from Steps 2 and 3).
Predict the mean response after setting A2 and B1 by adding the sum of their effects (from Step 4) to the grand mean (from Step 1).
Calculate the change in mean required to move the predicted mean (from Step 5) to the target mean of 16 seconds.

From the mean response factor effect plot, read the effect (deviation from the grand mean) associated with setting factor C to level C1 and state whether that effect moves the mean toward the required +2.5 seconds.

Given the required adjustment (+2.5 seconds from Step 6) and the C1 effect (from Step 7), determine whether selecting C1 will reach the 16 second target or whether a further increase beyond tested levels would be needed.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: C1 gets most of the way back on target; a slightly larger level of C beyond tested C1 would be needed to fully reach 16 sec

question.text:
A DC motor is connected to an op-amp circuit in cascade as shown in Figure1.The op-amp circuit subsystem is shown in Figure 2; the input to the op-amp is a voltage source (battery)$v_{i}(t)$ ,the output is the voltage $v_{s}(t)$ 1, and the transfer function of this subsystem is $G_{1}(s)$ . The DC motor subsystem is shown in Figure 3; the input to the DC motor is the op-amp's output $v_{s}(t)$ ,the output is the angular velocity $\omega(t)$ of a shaft connected to the motor, and the transfer function of this subsystem is $G_{2}(s)$ 1. The DC motor subsystem is not loading the op-amp circuit subsystem. We will analyze the behavior of each subsystem independently, and that of the overall cascaded system.
$V_{i}\left(s\right)$op-amp circuit I $G_{1}(s)$$V_{s}(s)$DC motor $G_{2}(s)$Ω()
Figure 1: Cascade of an op-amp circuit subsystem and a DC motor subsystem. $$v_{i}(t)$$ Figure 2: The op-amp circuit subsystem. Figure 3: The DC motor subsystem. Additional data for the op-amp circuit subsystem are: the resistors $R_{1}=100\Omega$ $R_{2}=100\Omega$ and $R_{3}=100\mathrm{k}\Omega$ , and the capacitor $C_{4}=1\mu F$ Additional data for the DC motor subsystem are: motor resistance $R=1\Omega$ ;the torque constant $K_{m}=1\mathrm{N}\cdot\mathrm{m}/\mathrm{A}$ , and back–emf constant $K_{v}=1\mathrm{V}\cdot\sec/\mathrm{r a d}$ ; the load shaft inertia $J=1\:\mathrm{k g}\cdot\:\mathrm{m}^{2}$ and viscous friction coefficient $b=1\:\mathrm{N}\cdot\:\mathrm{m}\cdot\:\mathrm{s e c}/$ .rad. The motor's own inertia and inductance are negligible. Time-saving hint You may use the following result to simplify your calculations:The voltage—in/voltage-out transfer function of an op-amp connected in feedback configuration with four impedances $Z_{1},Z_{2},Z_{3},Z_{4}$ is as shown below: Derive the time-domain response $\omega(t)$ when the input $v_{i}(t)$ is a step function of amplitude 1V (i.e., the unit–step response.)

answer.text:
We can see from the transfer function that this is a second order system with two real & negative poles; therefore, we recognize an overdamped system.To obtain the step response, we multiply the transfer function by $1/s,\;\mathit{i.e}$ . the Laplace transform of the unit step function, and expand in partial fractions.

$$-\frac{s-10}{s(s+2)(s+10)}=\frac{A}{s}+\frac{B}{s+2}+\frac{C}{s+10}.$$

The partial fraction expansion works out as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}A\quad&=\quad-\frac{s-10}{(s+2)(s+10)}\bigg|_{s=0}=\frac{1}{2};\\B\quad&=\quad-\frac{s-10}{s(s+10)}\bigg|_{s=-2}=-\frac{3}{4};\\C\quad&=\quad-\frac{s-10}{s(s+2)}\bigg|_{s=-10}=+\frac{1}{4}.\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the Laplace transform of the step response is:

$${\frac{1/2}{s}}-{\frac{3/4}{s+2}}+{\frac{1/4}{s+10}}.$$

From this, we obtain immediately the step response in the time domain 

$$f(t)=\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{3}{4}e^{-2t}+\frac{1}{4}e^{-10t}\right)u(t).$$

short_answer_description: The time-domain expression for the angular velocity \(\omega(t)\) of the motor shaft when the input voltage \(v_i(t)\) is a unit step function. The answer should be a mathematical formula in LaTeX format, typically involving exponential decay terms and the unit step function \(u(t)\).

reasoning_flow.step: Using the op-amp four-impedance formula and the circuit in Figure 2, write the symbolic transfer function G1(s)=V_s(s)/V_i(s) in terms of Z1,Z2,Z3,Z4.
Substitute the impedances for the op-amp circuit: Z1 = R1, Z2 = R2, Z3 = R3, and Z4 = 1/(s C4). Use the given values R1=100Ω, R2=100Ω, R3=100kΩ, C4=1μF, and simplify to obtain G1(s) in rational form.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: G1(s)= -1 * (R3 - (R2/(s C4)) / R1)/(R3 + 1/(s C4)) which with the numbers simplifies to G1(s)= -(s-10)/(s+10)

reasoning_flow.step: Write the electrical/mechanical transfer function G2(s)=Ω(s)/V_s(s) for the DC motor subsystem using the motor equations with negligible inductance: R (armature resistance), K_m (torque constant), K_v (back-emf), J (inertia), b (viscous friction).
Substitute the given motor parameter values R=1Ω, K_m=1, K_v=1, J=1, b=1 into the formula from Step 3 and simplify to obtain numeric G2(s).
Form the overall cascade transfer function G(s)=Ω(s)/V_i(s) by multiplying G1(s) from Step 2 and G2(s) from Step 4 and simplify algebraically.
Multiply the transfer function G(s) by the Laplace transform of a unit step input (1/s) to obtain Ω(s) for the step response.
Set up the partial fraction expansion Ω(s)= A/s + B/(s+2) + C/(s+10) and write expressions to solve for A, B, C.
Evaluate the expressions for A, B, C from Step 7 numerically.
Take the inverse Laplace transform of the partial-fraction form with the constants from Step 8 to write ω(t) in the time domain (include the unit step u(t)).

question.text:
A small box of mass m hangs from three massless ropes as shown in Figure 3. The ropes are attached to a ball joint which is located at the origin O of the Cartesian coordinate system Oxyz. Two of these ropes are also attached to the ball joints A and B which are fixed to a rigid wall; the third one is connected to the ball joint C which is attached to a rigid block of mass M. The latter stands on a plane surface; the coefficient of static friction between it and the surface is $\mu_{\mathrm{s}}$ . Note that the gravity g acts on the small box and the block which are both made from a homogeneous material. •Static friction is the force F that acts between two solid surfaces which are in contact but do not move relative to each other. It opposes the relative lateral motion of the two surfaces which would occur in the absence of the friction due to applied external forces. The static friction force acts tangentially to thetwo contacting surfaces. According to the Coulomb model, it fulfills the condition 
$$|F|\leq\mu_{s}N $$
where $\mu_{s}$ is the coefficient of static friction corresponding to the considered pair of surfaces, and N is the acting normal force between the two surfaces. (If the condition was violated, the surfaces would start moving relative to each other.)
<image>

Figure 3: Box hanging from three ropes.
For safety reasons, the magnitude of the tensile force in the ropes must not exceed the maximum admissible value $F_{\mathrm{m a x}}$ .What is the maximum value for the mass m of the small box so that this safety condition is met?

answer.text:
Ropes can support only axial tensile forces. Express these forces as vectors in terms of the sought force magnitudes and unit direction vectors:
$$\begin{aligned}&\mathrm{Fore in Rope OA:}\quad\boldsymbol{F}_{OA}=F_{OA}\hat{\mathbf{v}}_{OA}\quad where\quad\hat{\mathbf{v}}_{OA}=\frac{1}{3}\begin{bmatrix}-2\\ -1\\ 2\end{bmatrix}\\&\mathrm{Fore in Rope OB:}\quad\boldsymbol{F}_{OB}=F_{OB}\hat{\mathbf{v}}_{OB}\quad where\quad\hat{\mathbf{v}}_{OB}=\frac{1}{3}\begin{bmatrix}-2\\ 1\\ 2\end{bmatrix}\\&\mathrm{Fore in Rope OC:}\quad\boldsymbol{F}_{OC}=F_{OC}\hat{\mathbf{v}}_{OC}\quad where\quad\hat{\mathbf{v}}_{OC}=\frac{1}{5}\begin{bmatrix}3\\ 0\\ 4\end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}$$
Consider the force equilibrium for the ball joint at Point O:
$$\begin{array}{r}{\sum_{\boldsymbol{F}_{O A}}^{\boldsymbol{F}_{O B}}\sum_{\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\mathit{\mathbf{\mathit{\mathbf{\mathit{\mathbf{\mathit{\mathbf{\mathit{\mathbf{\mathbf{\mathit{\mathbf{\mathbf{\mathit{\mathbf{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{\mathbf{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{\mathit{}}{\mathbf{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{}\mathbf{{}\mathbf{}{}}\mathbf{{}}\mathbf{{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{}}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{}}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}{}}\mathbf{{}}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{}{}}\mathbf{{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{{}}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{{}}\mathbf{{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{{}\mathit{}{}\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{{}\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{}{\mathit{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}{}\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}{}\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}{}\mathbf{}{\mathit{}{}\mathbf{}{\mathbf{{}\mathit{}{}\mathbf{{}\mathbf{}}{\mathbf{{}\mathit{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}{}\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}{}\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}{F}}}{}}}{\mathbf{{\mathit{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}\mathbf{{}\mathit{}{}\mathbf{{}{\mathbf{}\mathit{{}}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}{\mathbf{}\mathbf{{}\mathit{{}}{\mathbf{}\mathit{{}\mathbf{{}\mathit{{}\mathbf{{}\mathbf{}{\mathit{}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}{\mathbf{}}{\mathit{{}\mathbf{{F}}}{}}}{\mathit{\mathbf{{}}\mathbf{{\mathit{{}\mathbf{}{\mathit{}{\mathbf{}\mathit{{\mathbf{}\mathit{{}\mathbf{{\mathit{}\mathbf{}{\mathit{\mathbf{}\mathit{{\mathit{}{\mathbf{}{\mathit{\mathbf{}{\mathit{\mathbf{}}\mathit{{\mathbf{\mathit{}\mathbf{}{\mathit{\mathit{}\mathbf{{\mathit{}\mathit{}{\mathbf\mathit{{\mathit{}\mathbf{}\mathit{{\mathit{}\mathbf{}{\mathit{\mathbf{\mathit{\mathit{}\mathit{}\mathbf{{\mathit{}}{\mathit{}\mathit{{\mathit{\mathbf{}{\mathit{}{\mathit{\mathit $$
Inserting Eqs. (78) to (80) into Eq. (81) and solving for $F_{O A},F_{O B},F_{O C}$ yields:

$$F_{O A}=F_{O B}={\frac{9}{28}}m g $$

$$F_{O C}=\frac{5}{7}m g $$

The largest force occurs in Rope OC which connects the small box to the block.Setting $F_{O C}=F_{\mathrm{m a x}}$ then yields the maximum value for the mass m that the small box can have while the force $F_{\mathrm{m a x}}$ is not exceeded in any rope:

$$F_{O C}=F_{\mathrm{m a x}}\quad\Rightarrow\quad m_{\mathrm{m a x}}=\frac{7}{5}\frac{F_{\mathrm{m a x}}}{g}$$

short_answer_description: The maximum value for the mass m of the small box that ensures the magnitude of the tensile force in any of the ropes does not exceed the maximum admissible value F_max. The answer should be a mathematical expression in LaTeX format involving parameters such as F_max and g.

Project the equilibrium equation from Step 4 onto the x, y, and z axes to obtain three scalar equations in the unknowns F_{OA}, F_{OB}, F_{OC}.

answer.text: The system function for the inner loop is $$ rac{ rac{K_{2}}{s-30}}{1+ rac{K_{2}}{s-30}}= rac{K_{2}}{s+K_{2}-30}.$$ Thus the overall system function is $$H(s)= rac{K_{1}\left( rac{K_{2}}{s+K_{2}-30}ight)\left( rac{1}{s+3}ight)}{1+K_{1}\left( rac{K_{2}}{s+K_{2}-30}ight)\left( rac{1}{s+3}ight)}= rac{K_{1}K_{2}}{s^{2}+(K_{2}-27)s+3K_{2}-90+K_{1}K_{2}}$$ At low frequencies, the magnitude of the system function must be 1: $$|H(j0)|= rac{K_{1}K_{2}}{3K_{2}-90+K_{1}K_{2}}=1	hinspace.$$ At $\omega=100$ (i.e., a high frequency), the magnitude of the system function must be $10^{-2}$ Quiz $\#2/6.003$ : Signals and Systems (Spring 2010) $$|H(j100)|= rac{K_{1}K_{2}}{\omega^{2}}= rac{K_{1}K_{2}}{100^{2}}=10^{-2}	hinspace.$$ The latter implies that $K_{1}K_{2}=100$ ,so that the former yields $ rac{100}{3K_{2}-90+100}=1,so that K_{2}=30$ and $K_{1}=100/30=10/3$

For a line current I in free space above an infinite magnetic permeability material ($\mu\to\infty$), use the method of images to derive the magnetic vector potential $\overline{A}_z$.

question.text:
In 1765, British clockmaker James Cox invented a clock whose only source of energy is the fluctuations in atmospheric pressure. Cox's clock used two vessels containing mercury. Changes in atmospheric pressure caused mercury to move between the vessels, and the two vessels to move relative to each other. This movement acted as an energy source for the actual clock. We propose an analysis of this device. Throughout,we assume that •the Earth's gravitational field $\overrightarrow{g}=-g\overrightarrow{u_{z}}$ is uniform with $g=9.8\mathrm{m}\cdot\mathrm{s}^{-2}$ and $\overrightarrow{u_{z}}$ a unit vector; • all liquids are incompressible and their density is denoted $\rho;$ •no surface tension effects will be considered; •the variations of atmospheric pressure with altitude are neglected; •the surrounding temperature $T_{\mathrm{a}}$ is uniform and all transformations are isothermal. The real mechanism developed by Cox is complex (Fig. 5). We study a simplified version, depicted in Fig.6, and described below • a cylindrical bottom cistern containing a mercury bath ; •a two-part barometric tube identical to that studied in part B, which is still completely emptied of any air, is dipped into the bath ; • the cistern and the two-part tube are each suspended by a cable. Both cables (assumed to be inextensible and of negligible mass) pass through a system of ideal pullies and finish attached to either side of the same mass M, which can slide on a horizontal surface; •the total volume of liquid mercury contained in the system is $V_{\ell}=5\mathrm{L}$ The height, cross-section and masses of each part are given in Table 2. The position of mass M is referenced by the coordinate x of its center of mass. We consider solid friction between the horizontal support and the mass M, without distinction between static and dynamic coefficients; the magnitude of this force when sliding occurs is denoted $F_{\mathrm{s}}$ Two stops limit the displacement of the mass M such that $-X\leq x\leq X\;(\mathsf{w i t h}\;X>0)$ 1.Assume that the value of X guarantees that •the bottom of the two-part tube never touches the bottom of the cistern nor comes out of the liquid bath; • the altitude $z_{\ell}$ of the mercury column is always in the upper bulb. Fig.5.Real Cox's timepiece 2(without mercury) Fig. 6. Sketch of the system modeling the timepiece
ReferenceNameHeightCross section areaEmpty mass
1cistern$H_{\mathrm{c}}=30\mathrm{c m}$$S_{\mathrm{c}}=210\mathrm{c m}^{2}$$m_{\mathrm{c}}$
2tubular part of the barometric tube$H_{\mathrm{t}}=80\mathrm{c m}$$S_{\mathrm{t}}=5\mathrm{c m}^{2}$total mass of the barometric tube: $m_{\mathrm{t b}}$
2′:bulb of the barometric tube$H_{\mathrm{b}}=20\mathrm{c m}$一 $S_{\mathrm{h}}=200\mathrm{c m}^{2}$
Table 2. Dimensions and notations for the model systm The system evolves in contact with the atmosphere, whose pressure fluctuates as in Fig. 4 (still with amplitude $A=5\times10^{2}$ Pa and period $\tau_{1}=1\mathrm{w e e k})$ 1. At the start $t=0,$ ,the mass M is at rest at $x=0$ and the tensions exerted by the two cables on either side of the mass M are in balance while $P_{1}\left(0\right)=0$ . We define $$\xi=\frac{S_{\mathrm{b}}+S_{\mathrm{c}}-S_{\mathrm{t}}}{S_{\mathrm{b}}S_{\mathrm{c}}}\frac{F_{\mathrm{s}}}{A}\simeq\frac{S_{\mathrm{b}}+S_{\mathrm{c}}}{S_{\mathrm{b}}S_{\mathrm{c}}}\frac{F_{\mathrm{s}}}{A}$$ where the last expression uses that $S_{\mathrm{t}}\ll S_{\mathrm{b}},S_{\mathrm{c}}$ (which we will assume is valid until the end of the problem). Determine the threshold $\xi^{\star}$ such that M remains indefinitely at rest when $\xi>\xi^{\star}$ .

answer.text:
Consider the case in which the mass M stays at rest at $x=0$ .At the start $t=0$ ,the tensions exerted by the two cables on either side of the mass M are in balance: the force $F_{0}$ required to suspend the barometric tube (with the fluid it contains) is equal to that required to suspend the cistern (with the fluid it contains). When the atmospheric pressure increases from $P_{\mathrm{a}}=P_{0}$ , the fluid rises in the barometric tube while it descends in the cistern. As a result, the added mass in the tube increases, while the added mass in the cistern decreases.We denote $m_{\mathrm{1,t b}}$ and $m_{\mathrm{1,c}}$ the (algebraic) variation of the apparent masses of each container. Thus, the tensions exerted by the two cables can be written:

$\left[F_{0}+m_{\mathrm{1,t b}}g\right]\overrightarrow{u_{x}}$ for the cable on the right, suspending the tube;

$-\left[F_{0}+m_{\mathrm{1,c}}g\right]\overrightarrow{u_{x}}$ for the cable on the left, suspending the cistern.

According to the principle of mass conservation, one can immediately state that $m_{\mathrm{1,t b}}=-m_{\mathrm{1,c}}$ . Subsequently, we choose to keep only $m_{\mathrm{1,c}}$ in the expressions (but all the calculations can be carried out while keeping $m_{\mathrm{1,t b}})$ 

$$\left(\mathrm{When}\;P_{\mathrm{a}}=P_{0}\right)$$
$$\varDelta z_{\ell,0}=\frac{P_{0}}{\rho g}$$
$$\varDelta z_{\ell}\left(t\right)=\frac{P_{\mathrm{a}}}{\rho g}$$

The friction force between the support and the mass M needed to maintain the equilibrium is therefore given by

$$\overrightarrow{R}_{\mathrm{t}}=-\left[F_{0}-m_{\mathrm{1,c}}g\right]\overrightarrow{u_{x}}+\left[F_{0}+m_{\mathrm{1,c}}g\right]\overrightarrow{u_{x}}=2m_{\mathrm{1,c}}g\overrightarrow{u_{x}}$$

In addition, according to the sketch above (where displacements $\delta_{\mathrm{b}}$ and $\delta_{\mathrm{c}}$ are algebraic), we have

$m_{\mathrm{1,c}}=\rho S_{\mathrm{c}}\delta_{\mathrm{c}}$ 

It is now necessary to determine $\delta_{\mathrm{c}}$ . One can use

the hydrostatic law :$\delta_{\mathrm{b}}-\delta_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{P_{\mathrm{l}}}{\rho g}$ 

the conservation of the total volume/mass of mercury :$S_{\mathrm{b}}\delta_{\mathrm{b}}=-\left[S_{\mathrm{c}}-S_{\mathrm{t}}\right]\delta_{\mathrm{c}}\simeq-S_{\mathrm{c}}\delta_{\mathrm{c}}$ (given that

$\bar{S}_{\mathrm{t}}\ll\bar{S}_{\mathrm{b}},\bar{S}_{\mathrm{c}})$ 

Solving the system formed by those equations, one finds

$$\delta_{\mathrm{c}}=-\frac{S_{\mathrm{b}}}{S_{\mathrm{b}}+S_{\mathrm{c}}-S_{\mathrm{r}}}\frac{P_{1}}{\rho g}\simeq-\frac{S_{\mathrm{b}}}{S_{\mathrm{b}}+S_{\mathrm{c}}}\frac{P_{1}}{\rho g}$$

which finally yields

$$\overrightarrow{R_{\mathrm{t}}}=-\frac{2S_{\mathrm{b}}S_{\mathrm{c}}}{S_{\mathrm{b}}+S_{\mathrm{c}}-S_{\mathrm{t}}}P_{1}\overrightarrow{u_{x}}\simeq-\frac{2S_{\mathrm{b}}S_{\mathrm{c}}}{S_{\mathrm{b}}+S_{\mathrm{c}}}P_{1}\overrightarrow{u_{x}}$$

With the triangular model for $P_{1}\left(t\right)$ , the maximum static friction force is obtained when $P_{1}=\pm A$ Therefore, according to the Coulomb's law of friction, the mass M stays at rest if and only if

$$\frac{2S_{\mathrm{b}}S_{\mathrm{c}}}{S_{\mathrm{b}}+S_{\mathrm{c}}-S_{\mathrm{t}}}A<F_{\mathrm{s}}$$

This inequality can be rewritten as

$$2<\frac{S_{\mathrm{b}}+S_{\mathrm{c}}-S_{\mathrm{t}}}{S_{\mathrm{b}}S_{\mathrm{c}}}\frac{F_{\mathrm{s}}}{A}=\xi $$

which allows us to identify

$$\xi^{\star}=2$$

short_answer_description: The numerical value of the threshold $\xi^{\star}$ for the parameter $\xi$. This threshold represents the critical condition where, if $\xi$ is greater than this value, the mass $M$ remains indefinitely at rest despite the fluctuations in atmospheric pressure.

reasoning_flow.step: State the equilibrium condition at t=0 for the tensions in the two cables suspending the tube and the cistern.

Write the net horizontal friction force R_t needed to maintain equilibrium of mass M as the difference of the two cable tensions (right cable minus left cable) expressed in terms of m_{1,c}.

reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: S_b δ_b + (S_c - S_t) δ_c = 0  ⇒  S_b δ_b ≃ - S_c δ_c

Using Coulomb friction with maximum static friction magnitude F_s and the pressure fluctuation amplitude A (so |P_1| ≤ A), state the inequality that ensures M remains at rest for all P_1 and rearrange it to obtain a condition on ξ = ((S_b+S_c-S_t)/(S_b S_c))*(F_s/A).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: Require (2 S_b S_c/(S_b+S_c-S_t)) * A < F_s  ⇒  2 < ((S_b+S_c-S_t)/(S_b S_c))*(F_s/A) = ξ

question.text:
A block with large mass M slides with speed $V_{0}$ on a frictionless table towards a wall. It collides elastically with a ball with small mass $m$ ,which is initially at rest at a distance L from the wall. The ball slides towards the wall, bounces elastically,and then proceeds to bounce back and forth between the block and the wall.

<image>

Assume that $M\gg m$ , and give your answers to leading order in $m/M$

How close does the block come to the wall?

answer.text:
Consider one of the collisions. Let it occur at a distance from the wall, and let v and V be the speeds of the ball and block, respectively, after the collision.We claim that the quantity $\ell(v-V)$ is invariant. That is, it is the same for each collision. This can be seen as follows.

The time to the next collision is given by $V t+v t=2\ell$ (because the sum of the distances traveled by the two objects is 2). Therefore, the next collision occurs at a distance c′ from the wall, whre 

$$\ell^{\prime}=\ell-V t=\ell- rac{2\ell V}{V+v}= rac{\ell(v-V)}{v+V}.$$ 

Therefore,

$$\ell^{\prime}(v+V)=\ell(v-V).$$ 

We now make use of the fact that in an elastic collision, the relative speed before the collision equals the relative speed after the collision. (This is most easily seen by working in the center of mass frame, where this scenario clearly satisfies conservation of $E$ and $|p.)$ Therefore, if $v^{\prime}$ and $V^{\prime}$ are the speeds after the next collision, then 

$$v+V=v^{\prime}-V^{\prime}.$$ 

Using this in eq. (2) gives 

$$\ell^{\prime}(v^{\prime}-V^{\prime})=\ell(v-V),$$ 

as we wanted to show.

What is the value of this invariant? After the first collision, the block continues to move at speed $V_{0}$ , up to corrections of order $m/M$ . And the ball acquires a speed of $2V_{0}$ , up to corrections of order $m/M$ . (This can be seen by working in the frame of the heavy block, or equivalently by using eq. (3) with $V^{\prime}\approx$ :$V=V_{0}{\mathrm{~a n d~}}v=0.)$ Therefore, the invariant $\ell(v-V)$ is essentially equal to 

$L(2V_{0}-V_{0})=L V_{0}$ 



Let $L_{\mathrm{m i n}}$ be the closest distance to the wall. When the block reaches this closest point, its speed is (essentially) zero. Hence, all of the initial kinetic energy of the block now belongs to the ball. Therefore,$v=V_{0}\sqrt{M/m}$ ,and our invariant tells us that $L V_{0}=L_{\mathrm{m i n}}(V_{0}\sqrt{M/m}-0)$ . Thus,

$$L_{\mathrm{m i n}}=L\sqrt{ rac{m}{M}}.$$

short_answer_description: The minimum distance between the block and the wall, expressed as a mathematical formula in LaTeX notation involving the initial distance L and the masses m and M, calculated to the leading order in m/M.

reasoning_flow.step: List the given initial parameters and assumptions from the problem statement (symbols and their meanings).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: M (mass of block), m (mass of ball), V_0 (initial speed of block), ball initially at rest, ball initial distance from wall = L, M >> m

reasoning_flow.step: Write an expression for the time t until the next collision in terms of the current distance from the wall ℓ and the speeds of the block and ball (V for block, v for ball) after a collision, using that the sum of distances they travel equals 2ℓ.
Using the time t from step 2, express the new distance from the wall ℓ' at the next collision in terms of ℓ, V, and v (the block moves toward the wall by V t).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: ℓ' = ℓ - V t = ℓ - 2ℓ V/(v+V)

reasoning_flow.step: Algebraically rearrange the expression from step 3 to obtain a relation between ℓ'(v+V) and ℓ(v-V).
State the elastic-collision relation between relative speeds before and after a collision for one-dimensional elastic collisions (relation between v,V and v',V').
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: relative speed flips sign: (v_before - V_before) = -(v_after - V_after) so magnitudes equal

reasoning_flow.step: Use the relation from step 5 to replace (v+V) in the equation from step 4 for successive collisions, and state the resulting invariant quantity involving ℓ, v, and V that is the same for each collision.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: ℓ(v - V) is invariant (same for each collision)

reasoning_flow.step: Evaluate the invariant ℓ(v - V) right after the first collision using leading-order-in-m/M approximations: give the post-first-collision speeds of the block and ball to leading order in m/M when the block initially has speed V_0 and the ball is at rest.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: after first collision: V ≈ V_0, v ≈ 2V_0

reasoning_flow.step: Compute the numerical value of the invariant ℓ(v - V) using the initial separation ℓ = L and the speeds from step 7.

At the moment the block reaches its closest approach L_min to the wall, state the block speed and then use conservation of energy (to leading order in m/M) to express the ball speed v at that moment in terms of V_0, M, and m.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: block speed ≈ 0, ball speed v = V_0 * sqrt(M/m)

reasoning_flow.step: Use the invariant value from step 8 and the values at closest approach from step 9 to solve for L_min (from L V_0 = L_min (v - 0)).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: L_min = L V_0 / (V_0 * sqrt(M/m)) = L * sqrt(m/M)

question.text: Aggrecan is a very unique "bottle-brush" macromolecule that is largely responsible for the mechanical properties and health of cartilage tissue in our joints (later on in the semester you will hear a podcast with Professor Alan Grodzinsky on this topic).Aggrecan is composed of highly negatively charged polysaccharides called glycosaminoglycans or GAGs (contour length ~ 40 nm) as side chains that are densely packed along a core protein (contour length ~ 400 nm). Aggrecan was chemically endattached to a planar substrate and a micron-sized probe tip at the end of a microfabricated cantilever at a packing density of 25 nm × 25 nm square per aggrecan molecule.A high resolution force spectroscopy experiment was then carried out where the surfaces were compressed and held for a period of time between the approach and retract curves (Figure 1 - real data taken in the month!). The uncompressed and compressed height H of the two aggrecan layers are 409 nm and 150 nm, respectively. <image> Figure 1. High resolution force spectroscopy experiment; aggrecan vs. aggrecan. Calculate the average adhesion energy per pair of aggrecan molecules in attoJoules).

answer.text: To calculate the energy per molecule, one needs to know the number of pairs of aggrecan molecules,$N$ ,contained within the contact area of the probe tip at maximum compression, A. The amount of compression is $c=409nm-150nm=259nm$ ,hence the area under compression can be calculated as, $$S=\pi\left(R^{2}-(R-c)^{2}\right)=3.86\times10^{6}\mathrm{~nm}^{2}$$ $$\mathbf{R}_{\mathrm{IP}}$$ $$\mathbf{R}_{\mathrm{TP}}-\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{r}}$$ $$\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{M A X}}$$ $$D>0$$ $$-\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{T I P}}$$ $$\mathrm{ID}_{1}$$ $$\mathbf{D}_{1}=$$ $$\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{TP}}$$ Hence, the number of pairs of aggrecan under compression is, $$N=\frac{A}{25nm\times25nm}\cong6.2\times10^{3}$$ The average adhesion energy per pair of aggrecan is, $$u_{adhesion(pair)}=\frac{U_{adhesion}}{N}=0.168\times10^{-18}J=0.168aJ $$ Note : The difference in the approach and retract force curves in the region of $F>0$ is small compared to the region where $F<0$ ,so it has been neglected.

short_answer_description: The calculated average adhesion energy per pair of aggrecan molecules, derived from the force spectroscopy experiment data, expressed as a numerical value in attoJoules (aJ).

reasoning_flow.step: Extract the uncompressed height H_uncompressed of the aggrecan layer from the Question text or figure.
Extract the compressed height H_compressed of the aggrecan layer from the Question text or figure.
Calculate the compression distance c as the difference between the uncompressed and compressed heights (c = H_uncompressed - H_compressed).
Extract or compute the contact area A of the probe tip under maximum compression from the data/figure (area under compression).
Calculate the number of aggrecan pairs N in the contact area using the given packing density (each molecule occupies 25 nm × 25 nm): N = A / (25 nm × 25 nm).
Extract the total measured adhesion energy U_adhesion between the two surfaces (from the integrated difference between approach and retract force curves) from the experiment/figure.
Compute the average adhesion energy per pair u_adhesion(pair) by dividing the total adhesion energy U_adhesion by the number of pairs N: u = U_adhesion / N.
Express the result from the previous step in attojoules (1 aJ = 1e-18 J).

question.text: Consider the combined cycle power plant shown in Figure 3. Air at 300 K and 100 kPa enters the compressor whose isentropic efficiency is 80%. It is then compressed to 800 kPa, and heated to 500K. The hot stream leaving the gas turbine, which operates with an isentropic efficiency of 88%, flows through the HRSG, where it is cooled to 423 K. Superheated steam at 723 K and 8 MPa enters the steam turbine and it is expanded to 6 kPa. The mass of fuel burnt in the combustor is negligible compared to that of the air. The isentropic efficiencies of the steam turbine and pump are 90% and 70%, respectively. <image> Figure 3 - Combined cycle powerplant. What is the amount of steam produced in the HRSG per unit mass of air.

answer.text:
We start by applying the first law to the HRSG:
$$\dot{m}_{4}\left(h_{4}-h_{5}\right)=\dot{m}_{7}\left(h_{8}-h_{7}\right)$$
Rearranging:
$$\alpha=\frac{h_{4}-h_{5}}{h_{8}-h_{7}}$$
We proceed to determining the enthalpies using EES and relationships from Chapter 5:
$$T_{4}=T_{3}\left(1-\eta_{GT}\left[1-\left(r_{p}\right)^{\frac{1-k}{k}}\right]\right)=1500\times\left(1-0.88\left(1-8^{-\frac{0.323}{1.323}}\right)\right)=975.1K $$
$$h_{4}=1018\mathrm{k J/k g},\quad h_{5}=424.6\mathrm{k J/k g}$$
For state $^6,$ the liquid water is a saturated liquid at $P_{6}=6\mathrm{k}\mathrm{{\tt Pa}};$ 
$$h_{6}=151.5\:\mathrm{k J/k g},\quad v_{6}=0.001\:\mathrm{m}^{3}/\mathrm{k g}$$
Noting water is incompressible, State 7 is the defined as:
$$h_{7s}=h_{6}+v_{6}(p_{7}-p_{6})=151.5+0.001(8000-6)=159.5kJ/kg $$
$$h_{7}=h_{6}+\cfrac{h_{7s}-h_{6}}{\eta_{p}}=151.5+\cfrac{159.5-151.5}{0.7}=162.9\mathrm{kJ/kg}$$
State 8 is fixed by $T_{8}=723\:\mathrm{{K}}\:\mathrm{{\sf{a n d}}}\:p_{8}=8\:\mathrm{{M P a}};$ 
$$h_{8}=3273\mathrm{k J/k g},\quad s_{8}=6.557\mathrm{k J/k g}\cdot\mathrm{K}$$
Hence:
$$\alpha=\frac{h_{4}-h_{5}}{h_{8}-h_{7}}=\frac{1018-424.6}{3273-162.9}=0.19$$

short_answer_description: The numeric value representing the ratio of the mass of steam produced in the Heat Recovery Steam Generator (HRSG) to the unit mass of air flowing through the system, expressed as a dimensionless quantity (kg steam per kg air).

reasoning_flow.step: Write the energy balance for the HRSG relating mass flow of air (m_dot_air) and mass flow of steam (m_dot_steam) using enthalpies at the inlet/outlet streams, and rearrange to give steam per unit air (α = m_dot_steam / m_dot_air).

Write the expression to compute the gas turbine outlet temperature T4 from turbine inlet temperature T3, turbine isentropic efficiency η_GT, and pressure ratio r_p using ideal-gas isentropic relation (assume k for air).
Using T3 = 1500 K, η_GT = 0.88, r_p = 8, and k = 1.323, calculate T4 from the expression in Step 2.
Determine the specific enthalpy h4 of the combustion products at T4 = 975.1 K (use appropriate gas property table or EES lookup for the combustion product gas mixture assumed in the reference).
Determine the specific enthalpy h5 of the hot gas after cooling in the HRSG to T5 = 423 K (use gas property table / EES lookup).
For the condensate at pressure p6 = 6 kPa (saturated liquid), extract the saturated liquid enthalpy h6 and specific volume v6 from steam tables.
Using incompressible liquid approximation, compute the pump ideal (isentropic) outlet enthalpy h7s = h6 + v6*(p7 - p6) for p7 = 8 MPa and p6 = 6 kPa. Use consistent units (kPa and m3/kg -> kJ/kg).
Compute the actual pump outlet enthalpy h7 using pump isentropic efficiency η_p = 0.70 and h7s from Step 7 with h6 from Step 6 via h7 = h6 + (h7s - h6)/η_p.
Extract the specific enthalpy h8 of the superheated steam at T8 = 723 K and p8 = 8 MPa from steam tables or EES.
Substitute h4, h5, h8, and h7 from previous steps into the HRSG mass relation α = (h4 - h5)/(h8 - h7) and compute α.

question.text:
Listed in the table below are chemical and schematic structures of poly(L-lactide) and a number of derivatives of this polymer.
PolymerChemical structuremicrostructure
Poly(L-lactide)O CH3 C CH O CH O C Jn $CH_{3}$ O Semicrystalline
Poly(lactide-co- glycolide)O CH3 O $H_{}$ C CH O C C 0 CH O C C x V CH₃3$ O Öamorphous
Poly(lactide-b-ethylene oxide)0 CH_₃ II $H_{2}$ C CH O C CH O CH_{2}$ O √ \y CH₃3$ O Semicrystalline
polycaprolactone$-((CH_2)_5-C_2^-O-)_n-$semicrystalline
Using physicochemical criteria, predict the hierarchy of degradation rates for these materials. Provide a concise but thorough explanation of your ranking. State any assumptions you make.

answer.text:
Experiments reveal that these materials ranked in terms of their rate of degradation have the following order: polycaprolactone (PCL) < poly(L-lactide) (PLLA) < poly(lactide-co-glycolide) (PLGA)< poly(lactide-b-ethylene oxide) (PLA-b-PEO).

This ranking can be rationalized via the chemical and physicochemical factors that control degradation rates: Because all of the materials are comprised of degradable ester linkages, they cannot be differentiated based on purely labile bond differences. The two slowest-degrading materials have a number of factors lowering their degradation rate: They are both semicrystalline.PLLA has the pendant methyl groups creating a steric barrier to the approach of water to the backbone. PCL is more hydrophobic and generally is highly crystalline, because its linear backbone readily packs into extensive crystallites (relative to PLLA). PLGA breaks down more quickly than PLLA because the mixture of lactide and glycolide repeat units in the chain prevents crystallization,and glycolide, lacking the bulky methyl groups, is more readily attacked by water. Lastly, PLA-bPEO, though crystallizable, are much more quickly degraded than the other materials due to the greatly enhanced entry of water into the hydrophilic PEO domains.

short_answer_description: The predicted ranking or hierarchy of degradation rates for the four polymers listed in the table (Poly(L-lactide), Poly(lactide-co-glycolide), Poly(lactide-b-ethylene oxide), and polycaprolactone). The response should express the relative order of degradation speeds, typically using inequality symbols (e.g., A < B < C) or a clear ordered list.

reasoning_flow.step: List the four polymers named in the Question.
From the chemical structures, do all four polymers contain ester linkages in their backbone?
Extract the listed microstructure (semicrystalline or amorphous) for each polymer from the table.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: PCL: semicrystalline; PLLA: semicrystalline; PLGA: amorphous; PLA-b-PEO: semicrystalline

reasoning_flow.step: From the chemical structures, indicate which repeat units have pendant methyl groups (i.e., methyl substituent on the backbone) and which do not.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: PLLA: pendant methyl present; glycolide unit in PLGA: no pendant methyl; PCL: no pendant methyl; PEO block: no pendant methyl

reasoning_flow.step: Classify each polymer's relative hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity based on chemical composition (PEO hydrophilicity, alkyl content for hydrophobicity).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: PLA-b-PEO: most hydrophilic (due to PEO domains); PCL: most hydrophobic; PLLA: moderately hydrophobic; PLGA: more hydrophilic than PLLA (due to glycolide) but less than PLA-b-PEO

reasoning_flow.step: State the general physicochemical rules relating crystallinity and hydrophobicity to hydrolytic degradation rate that will be used to rank materials.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: Higher crystallinity and greater hydrophobicity decrease degradation rate; greater amorphous character and higher hydrophilicity increase degradation rate

reasoning_flow.step: Using the facts from Steps 3–5 and the rule from Step 6, determine which of PCL and PLLA should degrade more slowly.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: PCL degrades more slowly than PLLA

reasoning_flow.step: Using Steps 3–6, determine whether PLGA should degrade faster or slower than PLLA.
Using Steps 3–6, determine whether PLA-b-PEO should degrade faster or slower than PLGA.
Combine the pairwise comparisons from Steps 7–9 into a single ranked list from slowest to fastest degrader.

question.text: Consider the following network, which consists of multiple connected components: <image> Suppose you are allowed to "immunize" exactly one vertex that can no longer be infected. Which vertex would you choose to make the average number of vertices killed as small as possible? What would the new value for this average be? Show your work.

answer.text: You should immunize the fourth vertex from the right in the lower-leftmost component. Now that this vertex is "immunized" and can no longer be selected, there are 23 vertices which can be chosen. The expected number infected is 103/23 or about 4.478. We repeat a similar calculation from before. Four of the components are unmodified, so we have a similar calculation for those, except now there are 23 vertices: The first component contributes 3*(3/23)=(9/23) to the expectation. The second component contributes 6*(6/23)=(36/23) to the expectation. The third component contributes 6*(6/23)=(36/23) to the expectation. The final component contributes $2*(2/23)=(4/23)$ to the expectation. Now we've created two new components, each of size 3. Therefore, they each contribute 3*(3/23) to the expectation, for a total of (18/23). Finally, we just sum up these numbers: (9/23)+(36/23)+(36/23)+(18/23)+(4/23)=(103/23).

short_answer_value: fourth vertex from the right in the lower-leftmost component
short_answer_description: The specific vertex selected for immunization that minimizes the average number of vertices killed, identified by its label or descriptive position within the network components.
The calculated minimum average number of vertices killed after the optimal vertex is immunized, expressed as a numerical value, fraction, or mathematical expression.

reasoning_flow.step: Count the total number of vertices in the entire network shown in the image.

Identify a single vertex whose immunization (removal from the set of selectable infection-start vertices) splits the long lower-left path component into two components of equal size (or as equal as possible). State that vertex's position relative to that path (e.g., kth from the right).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: fourth from the right in the lower-leftmost path

reasoning_flow.step: Calculate the number of selectable (non-immunized) vertices after immunizing the chosen vertex.
List the sizes of all connected components after the immunization (i.e., sizes of components that remain selectable).
For a component of size 3, compute its contribution to the expected number infected as size * (size / 23).
For a component of size 6, compute its contribution to the expected number infected as size * (size / 23).
For a component of size 2, compute its contribution to the expected number infected as size * (size / 23).
Use the contributions from Steps 5–7 and the component sizes from Step 4 to compute the total expected number infected by summing each component's contribution.
Convert the fraction from Step 8 (103/23) to a decimal approximation.

question.text:
The energy of a photon of light is given by the following equation:

$$E={\frac{h c}{\lambda}}$$

E is the energy of the photon (in J)

λ is the wavelength of light (in m)

h is Planck's constant $(6.626\times10^{-34}\mathrm{J}\mathrm{s})$ 

c is the speed of light $(2.998\times10^{8}\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1})$ 

The fluorescence of a molecule or atom can be measured by exciting a sample with light of a wavelength $\lambda_{\mathrm{e x c i t e}}$ and detecting the intensity of light that the sample emits by fluorescence at wavelength $\lambda_{\mathrm{d e t e c t}}$ 

There are two different ways of displaying this data: in an excitation spectrum, the excitation wavelength $\lambda_{\mathrm{e x c i t e}}$ is varied and the detection wavelength $\lambda_{\mathrm{d e t e c t}}$ is held constant; in an emission spectrum, the excitation wavelength is $\lambda_{\mathrm{e x c i t e}}$ held constant and the detection wavelength $\lambda_{\mathrm{d e t e c t}}$ is varied. In each case, the spectrum is presented as a graph of intensity (on the y-axis) vs varied wavelength $(\lambda_{\mathrm{e x c i t e}}\;\mathrm{o r}\;\lambda_{\mathrm{d e t e c t}})$ on the x-axis.

The emission and excitation spectra of a molecule are provided below (1$\mathrm{nm}=1\times10^{-9}\mathrm{~m}$ 1.

<image>

Calculate the energy difference between $n=1,\nu=1$ and $n=2,\nu=3$ energy levels.

answer.text:
The $n=1,\nu=0\;{\mathsf{t o}}\;n=2,\nu=3$ transition occurs at 303 nm 
in Spectrum B.E ↑

$E=\frac{h c}{\lambda}=\frac{6.626\times10^{-34}\times2.998\times10^{8}}{303.0\times10^{-9}}=6.556\times10^{-19}\mathrm{J}$ 

The $n=2,\nu=0\;{\mathsf{t o}}\;n=1,\nu=1$ transition occurs at 401 nm $n=2,\nu=3$ 
in Spectrum A.


$n=2,\nu=0$ 

$E=\frac{h c}{\lambda}=\frac{6.626\times10^{-34}\times2.998\times10^{8}}{401.0\times10^{-9}}=4.954\times10^{-19}\mathrm{J}$ 

The $n=1,\nu=0\;{\mathsf{t o}}\;n=2,\nu=0$ transition occurs at 380 nm 
in Spectrum A.


$E=\frac{h c}{\lambda}=\frac{6.626\times10^{-34}\times2.998\times10^{8}}{380.0\times10^{-9}}=5.228\times10^{-19}\;\mathrm{J}$ 


$$\begin{array}{c}{{n=1,\nu=1}}\\ {{n=1,\nu=0}}\end{array}$$ 
So for the $\mathrm{e}n=1,\nu=1\mathrm{t o}n=2,\nu=3\mathrm{t r a n s i t i o n};$ 


$E=6.556\times10^{-19}\mathrm{J}+4.954\times10^{-19}\mathrm{J}-5.228\times10^{-19}\mathrm{J}=6.282\times10^{-19}\mathrm{J}$

short_answer_description: The calculated energy difference between the energy levels n=1, v=1 and n=2, v=3. The answer should be a numerical value with units of Joules (J), typically expressed in scientific notation.

reasoning_flow.step: State the formula that gives the energy E of a photon in terms of Planck's constant h, the speed of light c, and the wavelength λ.
Extract the value of Planck's constant h from the Question text.
Extract the value of the speed of light c from the Question text.
From the provided spectra image, read the wavelength (in nm) labeled for the transition peak in Spectrum B that corresponds to the n=1,ν=0 to n=2,ν=3 transition.
From the provided spectra image, read the wavelength (in nm) labeled for the transition peak in Spectrum A that corresponds to the n=2,ν=0 to n=1,ν=1 transition.
From the provided spectra image, read the wavelength (in nm) labeled for the transition peak in Spectrum A that corresponds to the n=1,ν=0 to n=2,ν=0 transition.
Using E = hc/λ and the values of h and c from previous steps, calculate the photon energy for the 303 nm transition (express in J).
Using E = hc/λ and the values of h and c from previous steps, calculate the photon energy for the 401 nm transition (express in J).
Using E = hc/λ and the values of h and c from previous steps, calculate the photon energy for the 380 nm transition (express in J).
Compute the energy difference for the n=1,ν=1 to n=2,ν=3 level difference by combining the photon energies from the identified transitions: E_total = E(303 nm) + E(401 nm) - E(380 nm).

question.text: A small massive particle (ball) of mass m is fixed at distance z below the top of a long hollow cylinder of mass M . A series of holes are drilled perpendicularly to the central axis of the cylinder.These holes are for pivoting so that the cylinder will hang in a vertical plane. Students are required to perform necessary nondestructive measurements to determine the numerical values of the following with their error estimates: Equipment: a cylinder with holes plus a ball inside, a base plate with a thin pin, a pin cap, a ruler, a stopwatch, thread, a pencil and adhesive tape. <image> <image> $x_{\mathit{C M}}$ is the distance from the top of the cylinder to the centre of mass. R is the distance from the pivoting point to the centre of mass. <image> Caution: The thin pin is sharp. When it is not in use, it should be protected with a pin cap for safety. Useful information: 1. For such a physical pendulum,$M+m\quad R^{2}+I_{_{C M}}\quad\frac{d^{2}\theta}{d t^{2}}\quad\approx\quad-g\quad M+m\quad R\theta$ ,where $I_{\it C M}$ is the moment of inertia of the cylinder with a ball about the centre of mass and θ is the angular displacement. 2. For a long hollow cylinder of length L and mass M , the moment of inertia about the centre of mass with the rotational axis perpendicular to the cylinder can be approximated by ${\frac{1}{3}}M{\Bigg(}{\frac{L}{2}}{\Bigg)}^{2}$ 3. The parallel axis theorem:$I=I_{\mathrm{c e n t r e\:o f\:m a s s}}\:\+\:\mathfrak{M}x^{2}$ , where x is the distance from the rotation point to the centre of mass, and  is the total mass of the object. 4. The ball can be treated as a point mass and it is located on the central axis of the cylinder. 5. Assume that the cylinder is uniform and the mass of the end-caps is negligible. iii.ratio $\frac{M}{m}$

answer.text:
The ratio $\frac{M}{m}$ can be determined using the calculated value of z and the expression for the centre of mass.
From the definition of the centre of mass: $x_{CM}(M+m) = M(\frac{L}{2}) + mz$.
Given $L=30.0\mathrm{cm}$ and $x_{CM}=17.8\mathrm{cm}$, this simplifies to $17.8(M+m)=15.0M+mz$.
Rearranging this equation gives the ratio $\frac{M}{m}=\frac{z-17.8}{2.8}$.

Using the value of z from Method (a):
$z=25.3\mathrm{cm}$.
$\frac{M}{m} = \frac{25.3-17.8}{2.8} = \frac{7.5}{2.8} \approx 2.678$, which is rounded to $2.7$.
The error estimation for $\frac{M}{m}$ is $\Delta\left(\frac{M}{m}\right)=\frac{\Delta(z-17.8)}{2.8}=0.11$.

Using the value of z from Method (b):
$z=26.1\mathrm{cm}$.
$\frac{M}{m} = \frac{26.1-17.8}{2.8} = \frac{8.3}{2.8} \approx 2.964$, which is rounded to $3.0\pm0.3$.

The document notes that Method (a) is generally more accurate.

short_answer_description: The numeric value representing the ratio of the mass of the cylinder (M) to the mass of the ball (m), expressed as a dimensionless number.

reasoning_flow.step: Write the equation for the centre of mass x_{CM} of the combined system (cylinder of mass M with its centre at L/2 and a point mass m at distance z from the top), expressed as an equation relating x_{CM}, M, m, L, and z.

Rearrange the equation from Step 3 algebraically to obtain an expression for the ratio M/m in terms of z (isolate M/m).
State the value of z obtained from Method (a) to be used for numerical evaluation.
Using the formula from Step 4 and the z value from Step 5, calculate the numerical value of M/m for Method (a).
Round the numerical result from Step 6 to two significant figures as reported.

Using the formula from Step 4 and the z value from Step 9, calculate the numerical value of M/m for Method (b).

Using the uncertainty expression from Step 8 and the reported uncertainty magnitude for Method (a) (infer the reported numerical uncertainty in M/m), compute the corresponding numerical uncertainty in M/m for Method (a) as given in the Reference Answer.

question.text:
Make reasonable approximations and state them, i.e. quasi-neutrality, depletion approximation, etc.
 Use the symbols utilized in class for the various physical parameters, i.e.$\mu_{n}$ ,$I_{D}$ ,$E$ , etc.
• Every numerical answer must have the proper units next to it.
• Use $\phi=0\mathrm{a t}n_{o}=p_{o}=n_{i}$ :as potential reference.
• Use the following fundamental constants and physical parameters for silicon and silicon dioxide at room temperature:
$$\begin{array}{l}{n_{i}=1\times10^{10}{c m}^{-3}}\\ {k T/q=0.025{V}}\\ {q=1.60\times10^{-19}{C}}\\ {\epsilon_{s}=1.05\times10^{-12}{F/c m}}\\ {\epsilon_{o x}=3.45\times10^{-13}{F/c m}}\\ \end{array}$$
 Dynamic random-access memory (DRAM) is widely used in computer applications.This is because DRAMs are relatively fast, can be made very dense and are fairly inexpensive.Consider a one-transistor (DRAM) cell sketched below:
<image>
In this DRAM cell, the information is stored in the form of charge in the capacitor $C_{s}$ . If the voltage across the capacitor $V_{s}$ is HI, then $\mathrm{~a~}1\mathrm{~}$ is stored. If $V_{s}$ is LO,$\mathrm{~a~}0$ is stored.
The"word line" is used to select cells for reading or writing, as follows:
•if the word line is at ground $(V_{w}=0)$ 1, the cells on that line are not selected for reading or writing;
if the word line is at_$V_{w}=V_{D D}$ __, the cells on that line are selected for reading or writing.
The"bit $\mathrm{l i n e}$ is used to write or read the bits. It has three possible states:
•if the bit line is at $V_{b}=V_{D D},\mathrm{~a~}1$ is to be written
•if the bit line is at $V_{b}=0V,\mathrm{{a}0}$ is to be written
if the bit line is floating, the stored bit in the capacitor is to be read.
In this problem you will analyze the basic operation of the DRAM cell. In this DRAM cell the transistor is characterized by the following parameters:$L=1\mu m,W=4\mu m,\mu_{n}C_{o x}=50\mu A/V^{2}$ $V_{T}{=}1V$ . The storage capacitor is $C_{s}=50f F$ . The bit line has a capacitance $C_{B}=500\ fF$
$V_{D D}=3.3\;V$
□ Consider the operation of writing a " 1 " when the cell had a " 0 " stored at $t\:=\:0^{-}$ ,that is,$V_{s}(t=0^{-})=0.\mathrm{A t}t=0$ , the word line and the bit line are set to $V_{D D}$ $(V_{w}=V_{b}=V_{D D})$ ). Estimate the time that it takes for the capacitor to charge up to 80% of its final value. (Numerical answer expected).

answer.text:
The equation that controly the digenin of the capacitor charge un is:
$$ I_{D}=c_{s} \frac{d v_{J}}{d t} $$
since the transito remains at all kime (bot \(t \rightarrow \infty\) ) in the saturation refime, then
$$ I_{D}=\frac{k}{2 L} \mu_{m}(x)\left(v_{G}-v_{T}\right)^{2}=k\left(v_{D D}-v_{D}-v_{T}\right)^{2} $$
Hence we have a simnle dipperential esvation to solve:
$$ K\left(v_{D D}-v_{S}-v_{i}\right)^{2}=c_{S} \frac{d v_{S}}{d t} $$
we jeparate variables and interrate
$$ \frac{k}{c_{s}} \int_{0}^{t} d t=\int_{0}^{v_{s}} \frac{d v_{s}}{\left(v_{D D}-v_{1}-v_{T}\right)^{2}}=-\int_{0}^{v_{s}} \frac{-d v_{s}}{\left(v_{D D}-v_{d}-v_{T}\right)^{2}}=-\left.\frac{1}{v_{D D}-v_{d}-v_{T}}\right|_{0}^{v_{s}} $$
Then
$$ t=\frac{C_{s}}{k}\left(\frac{1}{v_{D D}-v_{s}-v_{T}}-\frac{1}{v_{D D}-v_{T}}\right) $$
The time that it taken \(t\), reach \(8 \%\) of \(v, 00-v\) is:
$$ \begin{aligned} t & =\frac{c_{5}}{k}\left[\frac{1}{v_{D D}-v_{T}-0.8\left(v_{D D}-v_{T}\right)}-\frac{1}{v_{D D}-\frac{v}{1}}\right]=\frac{c_{3}}{k} \frac{1}{v_{D D}-v_{T}}\left(\frac{1}{0.2}-1\right)= \\ & =\frac{c_{5} \times 4}{k\left(v_{D D}-v_{T}\right)}=\frac{50 \times 10^{-15} \times 4}{2 \times 50 \times 10-6 \times 23}=8.7 \times 10^{-10}=0.87 \mathrm{~ns} \end{aligned} $$
