The location of the first principal plane of the telephoto system, expressed as a distance and direction relative to a specific reference point (such as Lens 2), in terms of the focal length f.

question.text:
Calculating the Mass Flow Rate for a Prescribed Pressure Drop To improve the thermal-hydraulic performance of an Advanced High-Temperature Reactor (AHTR), a vendor wishes to compare two alternative coolants, i.e., a liquid metal (Na) and a liquid salt (LiF-BeF2). In the AHTR core the coolant flows inside 10-m long round channels arranged in a hexagonal lattice and surrounded by a solid fuel matrix.Consider the unit cell of this core (Figure 1). The friction pressure drop in the coolant channel,$\varDelta P_{f r i c}$ , is to be limited to 250 kPa. Assumptions: In selecting a suitable friction factor correlation, you may assume $\mathrm{R e}>30,000$ neglect surface roughness and entry region effects. In selecting a suitable heat transfer correlation, you may neglect entry region effects. Relevant properties are reported in the table below. Figure 1. Cross sectional view of the core unit cell. Coolant properties (independent of temperature and pressure)
Materialρ(kg/m³)k (W/m-K)(Pa·s)$\mathbf{c}_{\mathfrak{p}}(\mathrm{J}/\mathrm{k g}-\mathrm{K})$
Liquid Na78060$1.7{\times}10^{-4}$1,300
Liquid $\mathrm{L i F}\mathrm{-B e F}_{2}$1,9401$2.0{\times}10^{-3}$2,410
ii)Assuming the bulk coolant temperature at the channel inlet is 600C, and the heat flux is equal to 200$\mathrm{k W/m}^{2}$ (uniform axially and circumferentially),calculate the maximum temperature of the channel surface for both coolants.

answer.text: Since the heat flux is uniform, the maximum surface temperature will occur at the channel outlet and will be equal to (from Newton's law of cooling): $$T_{surf}=T_{out}+\frac{q}{h}$$ where $T_{o u t}$ is the bulk coolant temperature at the channel outlet,$q=200\ kW/m^2$ and h is the heat transfer coefficient. From the conservation of energy equation (integrated between $z=0and z=L$ ,we have: $$T_{out}=T_{in}+\frac{q\pi D L}{\dot{m}c_p}$$ where $T_{in}=600^{\circ}C$ and $c_{p}$ is the coolant specific heat. The outlet temperature is calculated from Eq. (11) to be ~720 and ${\sim}651{\circ}\mathrm{C}$ for sodium and the liquid salt, respectively. As for the heat transfer coefficient, in the case of sodium $(Pr=0.037<<1$ ,turbulent,fullydeveloped flow, constant heat flux in round channel) the correct correlation is $N u=7+0.025P e^{0.8}$ (with $P e{=}R e{\cdot}P r{\sim}1114)$ ,from which weget $h=83.1\ kW/m^2-K$ ,whereas in the case of liquid salt $(Pr=4.82>1$ , turbulent, fully-developed flow, constant heat flux in round channel) the Dittus-Boelter correlation is suitable, from which we get $h{\sim}17.5\mathrm{k W/m^{2}\mathrm{-K}}$ .Substituting these values into Eq. (10), we get $T_{s u r f}{\approx}722$ and 663℃for sodium and liquid salt, respectively. Note that, in spite of a much higher heat transfer coefficient, the surface temperature in the sodium case is higher than in the liquid salt case. This is due to the lower specific heat of sodium which results in a higher $T_{o u t}$

short_answer_description: The calculated maximum temperature of the channel surface when Liquid Sodium (Na) is used as the coolant, expected as a numerical value in degrees Celsius (°C).
The calculated maximum temperature of the channel surface when Liquid Salt (LiF-BeF2) is used as the coolant, expected as a numerical value in degrees Celsius (°C).

question.text: A disk or radius r and mass m rolls without slipping on the surface of a stationary half-cylinder of radius R, as shown below. Because of the rolling constraint, this is a one-degree-of-freedomsystem, and theangle θ is a convenient generalized coordinate. <image> Calculate the kinetic energy of the disk.

answer.text:
The kinetic energy of a rigid body can be obtained by evaluating the formula 
$$K E=\frac{1}{2}m v_{C}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}I_{C}\omega^{2}$$
where $v_{C}$ is the magnit ude of the velocity of the mass center C and $I_{C}$ is the moment of inertia of the rigid body about its mass center. For a uniform solid disk of radius r and mass m,$I_{C}=\frac{1}{2}m r^{2}$ .Thevelocity of the mass center C can be obtained by applying the general formula 
$$\vec{v}_{C}=\vec{v}_{B}+\vec{\omega}\times\stackrel{\rightarrow}{B C}$$
which applies to any two points B and C on the same rigid body which rotates with angular velocity ω. In the present case the point B on the disk is instantaneously at rest, so $\vec{v}_{B}=0$ ,and the length of the vector $\overrightarrow{B C}$ is r, so the vector $\vec{v}_{C}$ has the magnitude rw and is directed at right angles to BC. Substitution of $v_{C}\;=\;r\omega$ and $I_{C}=\frac{1}{2}m r^{2}$ into Eq.(1) yields 
$$K E=\frac{1}{2}m(r\omega)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(\frac{1}{2}m r^{2})\omega^{2}=\frac{3}{4}m(r\omega)^{2}$$

short_answer_description: A mathematical expression in LaTeX format representing the total kinetic energy of the disk as it rolls without slipping on the half-cylinder, expressed in terms of the disk's mass m, radius r, and the relevant angular velocity or time derivative of the generalized coordinate.

Substitute v_C from Step 5 and I_C from Step 2 into the kinetic energy formula from Step 1 and simplify to obtain KE in terms of m, r, and ω.

question.text:
Recall from your required reading on Tiered-Latency DRAM that there is a near and far segment, each containing some number of rows. Assume a very simplified memory model where there is just one bank and there are two rows in the near segment and four rows in the far segment. The time to activate and precharge a row is 25ns in the near segment and 50ns in the far segment. The time from start of activation to reading data is 10ns in the near segment and 15ns in the far segment. All other timings are negligible for this problem. Given the following memory request stream, determine the optimal assignment (minimize average latency of requests) of rows in the near and far segment (assume a fixed mapping where rows cannot migrate, a closed-row policy, and the far segment is inclusive).

time Ons : row 0 read time 10ns : row 1 read time 100ns: row 2 read time 105ns: row 1 read time 200ns: row 3 read time 300ns: row 1 read 

(e) Assume now that there are eight (8) rows in the near segment. Below is a plot showing the number of misses to the near segment for three applications (A, B, and C) when run alone with the specified number of rows allocated to the application in the near segment. This is similar to the plots you saw in your Utility-Based Cache Partitioning reading except for TL-DRAM instead of a cache. Determine the optimal static partitioning of the near segment when all three of these applications are run together on the system. In other words, how many rows would you allocate for each application? Hint: this should sum to eight. Optimal for this problem is defined as minimizing total misses across all applications.

<image>

 How many near segment rows would you allocate to C?

answer.text:
To minimize total misses across all applications when allocating 8 rows:

Application A:
1 row: 1000 misses
2 rows: 400 misses (gain 600)
3 rows: 200 misses (gain 200)
4 rows: 100 misses (gain 100)
5 rows: 50 misses (gain 50)
6 rows: 25 misses (gain 25)
7 rows: 10 misses (gain 15)
8 rows: 5 misses (gain 5)

Application B:
1 row: 100 misses
2 rows: 25 misses (gain 75)
3 rows: 10 misses (gain 15)
4 rows: 5 misses (gain 5)
5 rows: 2 misses (gain 3)
6 rows: 1 miss (gain 1)
7 rows: 0 misses (gain 1)
8 rows: 0 misses (gain 0)

Application C:
1 row: 200 misses
2 rows: 100 misses (gain 100)
3 rows: 50 misses (gain 50)
4 rows: 25 misses (gain 25)
5 rows: 10 misses (gain 15)
6 rows: 5 misses (gain 5)
7 rows: 2 misses (gain 3)
8 rows: 1 miss (gain 1)

Using a greedy approach to allocate rows based on the largest marginal reduction in misses:
1. A (gain 600)
2. B (gain 75)
3. A (gain 200)
4. C (gain 100)
5. A (gain 100)
6. C (gain 50)
7. A (gain 50)
8. A (gain 25)

This results in an allocation of A=5, B=1, C=2 rows.

short_answer_description: The optimal number of near segment rows allocated to application C that results in the minimum total misses across applications A, B, and C, derived from the provided miss rate plots and the constraint of 8 total near segment rows. The answer should be a numeric integer.

reasoning_flow.step: Extract the number of near-segment misses for Application A when allocated 1 through 8 rows (list values in order for rows=1..8).
Extract the number of near-segment misses for Application B when allocated 1 through 8 rows (list values in order for rows=1..8).
Extract the number of near-segment misses for Application C when allocated 1 through 8 rows (list values in order for rows=1..8).
For Application A, compute the marginal reduction in misses (gain) when increasing allocation from k-1 to k rows for k=1..8 (i.e., differences between consecutive entries from Step 1).
For Application B, compute the marginal reduction in misses (gain) when increasing allocation from k-1 to k rows for k=1..8 (differences between consecutive entries from Step 2).
For Application C, compute the marginal reduction in misses (gain) when increasing allocation from k-1 to k rows for k=1..8 (differences between consecutive entries from Step 3).

Using a greedy algorithm that in each of 8 allocation steps assigns one additional row to the application with the currently largest next marginal gain (using the gain sequences from Steps 4-6 and updating each application's next available gain as rows are allocated), produce the sequence of applications chosen for allocations 1..8.
From the allocation sequence in Step 7, count how many rows were allocated to each application (A, B, C).
Report how many near-segment rows are allocated to Application C based on the result from Step 8.

question.text:
Determine the velocity of point A on the outer rim of the spool at the instant shown when the cable is pulled to the right with a velocity of v. Assume r<R and that the spool rolls without slipping.

<image>

answer.text:
This problem is most easily done by computing the velocity of a point by means of a translating and rotating reference frame attached to the moving body. Refer to the diagram provided with the problem statement.

$0_{\mathrm{x y z}}$ :is an inertial non-moving reference frame.$\complement_{\mathtt{x}1\mathtt{y}1\mathtt{z}1}$ is attached to the spool at point C. A, B & C are points fixed to the spool and all on the same line which passes through the center of the wheel. Point C is at the instant shown in contact with the ground. It has zero velocity by virtue of its contact with the ground. It is known as an instantaneous center of rotation (ICR). The velocity at A in the inertial reference frame $0_{\mathrm{x y z}}$ may be expressed as $\vec{\mathcal{V}}_{A/O}$ . The solution for $\vec{\mathcal{V}}_{A/O}$ is given in the next several lines of equations, followed by a more detailed discussion.

$$\begin{aligned}&\vec{v}_{A/O}=\vec{v}_{C/O}+\vec{v}_{A/C}\\&\vec{v}_{C/O}=0,\mathrm{b e c a u s e}\;\mathrm{C}\;\mathrm{i s}\;\mathrm{a n}\;\mathrm{I C R}.\\ \end{aligned}$$

$$\begin{array}{r l}&{\vec{v}_{A/C}=(\frac{d\vec{r}_{A/C}}{d t})_{/O_{x y z}}=\underbrace{(\frac{\partial\vec{r}_{A/C}}{\partial t})_{/C_{x y y z1}}}_{A}+\underbrace{\vec{\omega}_{/o}\times\vec{r}_{A/C}}_{B}}\\ &{=(v_{A/C})_{r e l}+\vec{\omega}_{/o}\times\vec{r}_{A/C}}\\ &{(v_{A/C})_{r e l}=0}\\ &{\vec{\omega}_{/O}=\omega\hat{k}}\\ &{\vec{r}_{A/C}=2R\hat{j}_{1}}\\ &{\vec{v}_{A/O}=\vec{v}_{C/O}+(v_{A/C})_{r e l}+\omega\hat{k}\times2R\hat{j}_{1}=-2R\omega\hat{i}_{1}}\\ &{\vec{v}_{B/O}=\vec{v}_{C/O}+\vec{v}_{B/C}=0+0+\vec{\omega}_{/o}\times\vec{r}_{B/C}=V\hat{i}}\\ &{V\hat{i}=\omega\hat{k}\times(R-r)\hat{j}=-\omega(R-r)\hat{i}}\\ &{\omega=\frac{-V}{R-r}}\end{array}$$

Where $\vec{\mathcal{V}}_{A/C}$ is the velocity of A with respect to point C as seen from the inertial frame $0_{\mathrm{x y z}}$ .It has two terms.

$$\begin{aligned}&\vec{v}_{_{A/C}}=(\frac{d\vec{r}_{_{A/C}}}{dt})_{_{/O_{xyz}}}=(\underbrace{\frac{\partial\vec{r}_{_{A/C}}}{\partial t}}_{_{A}})_{_{/C_{xy1z1}}}+\underbrace{\vec{\omega}_{_{/o}}\times\vec{r}_{_{A/C}}}_{_{B}}\\ &=(v_{_{A/C}})_{_{rel}}+\vec{\omega}_{_{/o}}\times\vec{r}_{_{A/C}}\\ \end{aligned}$$

Term A is the 'relative' velocity between points A and C as seen from an observer attached to the spool, or fixed in the $\complement_{\mathtt{x}1\mathtt{y}1\mathtt{z}1}$ frame. The Williams books calls this term 

$(v_{_{A/C}})_{r e l}$ 

$$(v_{_{A/C}})_{r e l}{=}0$$

Now to the problem:

$\vec{\omega}_{/Q}=\omega\hat{k}$ and is for the moment unknown.

$$\vec{v}_{A/O}=\vec{v}_{C/O}+(v_{A/C})_{r e l}+\omega\hat{k}\times2R\hat{j}_{1}=-2R\omega\hat{i}_{1}$$

ω is unknown but may be found because the $\vec{\mathcal{V}}_{B/O}$ is given.

$$\begin{aligned}&\vec{v}_{_{B/O}}=\vec{v}_{_{C/O}}+\vec{v}_{_{B/C}}=0+0+\vec{\omega}_{_{/o}}\times\vec{r}_{_{B/C}}=V\hat{i}\\&V\hat{i}=\omega\hat{k}\times(R-r)\hat{j}=-\omega(R-r)\hat{i}\\ \end{aligned}$$

Therefore $\omega=\frac{-V}{R-r}$ which may be put into equation [1]

since $\vec{v}_{{{A}/{O}}}=-2R\omega\hat{i}=(\frac{2R}{R-r})V\hat{i}$ .Note that at the instant shown the unit vectors of frames O and C align and are interchangeable., i.e.$\hat{i}_{1}=\hat{i},\hat{j}_{1}=\hat{j},\hat{k}_{1}=\hat{k}$

short_answer_description: The velocity vector of point A on the outer rim of the spool at the instant shown. The answer should be a mathematical expression in LaTeX format, expressed in terms of the cable velocity v, radii R and r, and the unit vector \hat{\imath}.

reasoning_flow.step: Identify and state the given linear velocity of the cable (point B) from the problem statement and express it as a vector in the inertial frame.
Write the kinematic relation expressing the velocity of point A in the inertial frame as the sum of the velocity of point C and the velocity of A relative to C: v_{A/O} = v_{C/O} + v_{A/C}.
Determine the velocity of point C in the inertial frame given that point C is instantaneously in contact with the ground (ICR).

Express the relative velocity v_{A/C} as the sum of the time derivative of r_{A/C} in the body frame (the relative motion term) and the rotational term: v_{A/C}=(d r_{A/C}/dt)_{/O}=(\partial r_{A/C}/\partial t)_{/C}+\omega_{/O}\times r_{A/C}.
State the relative motion between points A and C as seen in the body frame (i.e., evaluate (v_{A/C})_{rel}).

Express the position vector from C to A in the body frame in terms of R (outer radius) and the local unit vector direction, and write the rotational vector as \omega\hat{k}; then compute the cross product \omega\hat{k}\times r_{A/C}.
Combine results from Steps 2, 3, 5, and 6 to write v_{A/O} in terms of \omega.

Write the expression for v_{B/O} in terms of the angular velocity \omega and the position vector r_{B/C} where B is located a distance (R-r) from C, and compute the cross product \omega\hat{k}\times (R-r)\hat{j}.
Equate the expression for v_{B/O} from Step 8 to the given cable velocity from Step 1 and solve that equation for \omega.
Substitute the value of \omega from Step 9 into the expression for v_{A/O} from Step 7 and simplify to obtain v_{A/O} in terms of V, R, and r.

question.text:
A bead of mass M is placed on a frictionless, rigid rod that is spun about at one end at a rate ω. The bead is initially held at a distance $\mathbf{r}_{0}$ from the end of the wire. For the questions below, treat the bead as a point mass. Ignore gravitational forces.

<image>

 After the bead is released, what is its position in the inertial frame (in polar coordinates) as a function of time?

answer.text:
In the inertial frame, we can write down the equations of motion in polar coordinates assuming that there is no radial force acting (no friction or constraint force):

$$\begin{aligned}&m(\ddot{r}-r\dot{\theta}^2)=0\\&m(r\ddot{\theta}+2\dot{r}\dot{\theta})=N\\ \end{aligned}$$

Here,N is some normal force acting on the bead in the angular direction (important for part c). The angular position is straightforward, since the rod is rotating at  constant angular rate, hence,

$$\left[\theta(t)=\theta_{0}+\omega t\right]$$

For the radial position, we must solve the radial equation of motion:

$$\ddot{r}=\omega^{2}r $$

This can be done by trial, or you can simply remember that the general solution for this equation is:

$$r(t)=A e^{\omega t}+B e^{-\omega t}$$

Using the initial conditions $\mathrm{r}(0)=\mathrm{r}_{0}$ and $\mathrm{d r}/\mathrm{d t}(0)=0$ , we find:

$$\begin{aligned}&\left\{\begin{aligned}\\ &A+B=r_{0}\\&\omega(A-B)=0\Rightarrow A=B\\&So\\&r(t)=\frac{r_{0}}{2}(e^{\omega t}+e^{-\omega t})\\ &\end{aligned}\right\}\\ \end{aligned}$$

short_answer_description: The mathematical expression in LaTeX format for the radial position r(t) of the bead as a function of time, representing its distance from the pivot point.
The mathematical expression in LaTeX format for the angular position theta(t) of the bead in the inertial frame as a function of time.

reasoning_flow.step: State the polar-coordinate form of Newton's second law (radial and angular components) for a point mass m with coordinates (r,θ) in an inertial frame.
From the problem statement, extract the values of external forces acting on the bead in the radial and angular directions after release (ignore gravity and friction).
Substitute the forces from Step 2 into the polar Newton's laws from Step 1 to write the equations of motion for r(t) and θ(t).
Use the information that the rod is being spun at constant angular rate ω to express θ(t) (assume the initial angle is θ_0).
From the expression for θ(t) in Step 4, compute \dot{\theta}(t) and substitute it into the radial equation from Step 3 to obtain an ODE for r(t).
Solve the linear second-order ODE \ddot{r}-\omega^{2}r=0 to write the general solution for r(t).
State the initial conditions given: r(0) and \dot{r}(0), as provided in the problem.
Apply the initial conditions from Step 7 to the general solution from Step 6 to determine constants A and B.
Substitute the constants A and B from Step 8 into the general solution from Step 6 to write the explicit r(t).
Combine θ(t) from Step 4 and r(t) from Step 9 to state the bead's position in polar coordinates as a function of time in the inertial frame.

question.text:
A zero effective length spring (ZLS) is a spring for which the force is proportional to the spring's length,$F=k L$ for $L>L_{0}$ where $L_{0}$ is the minimal length of the spring as well as its unstretched length. Figure 1 shows the relation between the force F and the spring length L for a ZLS, where the slope of the line is the spring constant k.

<image>

Figure 1: the relation between the force F and the spring length L

A ZLS is useful in seismography and allows very accurate measurement of changes in the gravitational acceleration g. Here, we shall consider a homogenous ZLS, whose weight $M g$ exceeds $k L_{0}$ .We define a corresponding dimensionless ratio,$\alpha=k L_{0}/M g<1$ to characterize the relative softness of the spring.The toy known as "slinky" may be (but not necessarily) such a ZLS.

Throughout this question, we will denote a point on the spring by its distance $0\leq\ell\leq L_{0}$ from the bottom of the spring when it is unstretched. In particular, for every point on the spring,  remains unchanged as the spring stretches.

 Dynamics
Experiments show that when the spring is hung at rest and then released, it gradually contracts from the top, while the lower part remains stationary (see Figure 2). As time advances, the contracting part moves as a solid chunk and accumulates additional turns of the spring, while the stationary part becomes shorter. Every point on the spring begins to move only when the moving part reaches it. The bottom end of the spring starts moving only when the spring is fully collapsed and reaches its unstretched length $L_{0}$ . After that, the contracted spring continues falling straight downwards, without tumbling, as a rigid body under the influence of gravity.

<image>

Figure 2: Left: a sequence of pictures taken during the free fall of slinky. Right: the moving part I and the stationary part II during the free fall of the spring.

In the remaining parts of the question, you are asked to base your solution on this described model. You may neglect air resistance, but you are not allowed to neglect $L_{0}$
Calculate the time $t_{c}$ it takes from the moment the spring is released, until it fully collapses back to its minimal length $L_{0}$ . Express your answer in terms of $L_{0},g$ and $\alpha$ 
Compute the numerical value of $t_{c}$ for a spring with $k=1.02\mathrm{~N/m},L_{0}=0.055\mathrm{m}$ 
and $M=0.201$ kg, while taking $g$ to be $9.8\dot{0}\mathrm{m}/\mathrm{\bar{s}^{2}}$

answer.text: From Task A.3 we have $ egin{array}{r}{H(l)= rac{l^{2}}{2l_{0}}+ rac{l_{0}}{2}}\end{array}$ . We now calculate the position of the center of mass of the suspended spring. The contribution of the unstretched section of height $l_{0}$ at the bottom, having a mass of $ egin{array}{r}{i rac{l_{0}}{L_{0}}M=\alpha M,\mathrm{i s}\alpha M rac{l_{0}}{2}}\end{array}$ . The position of the center of mass is obtained by summing the contributions of its elements: $$ egin{aligned}H_{cm}= rac{1}{M}\left[ rac{l_0}{2}\alpha M+\int\limits_{l_0}^{L_0}H(l)dmight]= rac{1}{M}\left[ rac{\alpha L_0}{2}\alpha M+\int\limits_{l_0}^{L_0}\left( rac{l^2}{2l_0}+ rac{l_0}{2}ight) rac{Mdl}{L_0}ight]\= rac{\alpha^2L_0}{2}+ rac{1}{L_0}\left[ rac{l^3}{6l_0}+ rac{l_0}{2}light]_{l_0}^{L_0}= rac{\alpha^2L_0}{2}+ rac{1}{L_0}\left[ rac{L_0^3-l_0^3}{6l_0}+ rac{l_0}{2}(L_0-l_0)ight]\end{aligned}$$ Where we have used $ egin{array}{r}{d m= rac{d l}{L_{0}}M}\end{array}$ .Substituting $l_{0}=\alpha L_{0}$ yields $$H_{c m}=L_{0}\left[ rac{1}{6\alpha}- rac{\alpha^{2}}{6}+ rac{\alpha}{2}ight]$$ When the spring is contracted to its free length $L_{0},$ ,its center of mass is located $\operatorname{\mathsf{a t}}{ rac{L_{0}}{2}}$ .From the falling of the center of mass at acceleration g we get: $$ rac{g}{2}t_{c}^{2}=H_{c m}- rac{L_{0}}{2}=L_{0}\left[ rac{1}{6\alpha}- rac{\alpha^{2}}{6}+ rac{\alpha}{2}- rac{1}{2}ight]= rac{L_{0}}{6\alpha}(1-\alpha)^{3}$$ Hence,$t_{c}=\sqrt{ rac{L_{0}}{3g\alpha}(1-\alpha)^{3}}$ For $k=1.02\:\mathsf{N}/\mathsf{m},L_{0}=0.055\:\mathsf{m},M=0.201$ kg, and_$g=9.80\;\mathrm{m}/\mathrm{s}^{2}$ ',we have $\alpha=0.0285$ ,and $t_{c}=0.245\mathsf{s}$

short_answer_description: A mathematical expression in LaTeX format representing the formula for the collapse time $t_c$ (the time required for the spring to fully collapse to its minimal length $L_0$ after being released), expressed in terms of the variables $L_0$, $g$, and $ eta$ or $\alpha$.
The calculated numerical value of the dimensionless ratio $\alpha$, determined using the definition $\alpha = k L_0 / (M g)$ and the specific values provided for $k$, $L_0$, $M$, and $g$.
The final calculated numerical value for the collapse time $t_c$, obtained by substituting the specific parameter values into the derived formula, including the unit of time (seconds).

reasoning_flow.step: State the vertical position function H(l) of a point labeled by its unstretched distance l (0 ≤ l ≤ L0) as given by Task A.3.
Express the mass of the unstretched bottom section of height l0 in terms of M, L0 and l0.
Using the definition α = k L0 / (M g), express l0 in terms of α and L0.

Evaluate the integral in Step 6 to get the first moment of the stretched part as an explicit expression (in terms of M, L0 and l0).

Combine the first-moment contribution from the bottom section (Step 4) and the stretched part (Step 7), then divide by total mass M to obtain the center-of-mass height H_cm as a function of L0 and l0.
Write the vertical drop distance Δ of the center of mass from its initial H_cm to its position when the spring is fully collapsed (L0/2).
Using constant acceleration g for the center of mass, write the equation relating Δ to the collapse time t_c and solve it for t_c.
Compute the numerical value of α using α = k L0 / (M g) with k=1.02 N/m, L0=0.055 m, M=0.201 kg and g=9.80 m/s^2.
Substitute L0, g, and α into the formula for t_c from Step 10 and compute the numerical value.

question.text: An orthotropic composite material is loaded in the plane with tensile stresses $\sigma_{a}$ and $\sigma_{b}$ . The fibers in this composite are at $\mathrm{~a~}60^{\circ}$ angle to the $\mathbf{e}_{1}$ axis. Additionally, two strain gauges aligned with the $\mathbf{e}_{1}$ (labeled a) and $\mathbf{e}_{2}$ (labeled b) directions are placed in the material. <image> Suppose you previously measured the Young's Modulus along the fiber direction to be $E_{1}=200~\mathrm{G P a}$ . Determine the remaining in-plane elastic constants describing the behavior of this material if the applied stresses are $$\sigma_{a}=100~\mathrm{M P a}\qquad\sigma_{b}=50~\mathrm{M P a}$$ and the measured strains (from the strain gauges) and the shear strain in the $\mathbf{e}_{\mathrm{{1}}}\mathbf{\scriptstyle-}\mathbf{e}_{\mathrm{{2}}}$ plane are $$\epsilon_{a}=14	imes10^{-4}\quad\epsilon_{b}=4	imes10^{-4}\quad\epsilon_{12}=-5.6	imes10^{-4}$$ Hint: Remember the fact that the constitutive laws for orthotropic materials discussed in lecture apply only in material principal axes, i.e. they can only be used $\it{i f}$ the state of stress is described in directions aligned and perpendicular to the fibers.

short_answer_description: The Young's Modulus along the fiber direction (longitudinal modulus), which is explicitly provided in the problem statement, expected as a numerical value with units (e.g., GPa).
The calculated Young's Modulus in the direction transverse to the fibers (transverse modulus), expected as a numerical value with units (e.g., GPa).
The calculated major Poisson's ratio relating contraction in the transverse direction to extension in the longitudinal direction, expected as a dimensionless numerical value.
The calculated minor Poisson's ratio relating contraction in the longitudinal direction to extension in the transverse direction, expected as a dimensionless numerical value.
The calculated in-plane shear modulus describing the material's response to shear stress in the 1-2 plane, expected as a numerical value with units (e.g., GPa).

State the stress components in the e1-e2 coordinate system associated with the strain-gauge directions (i.e., σ11, σ22, σ12) before rotation to the material (fiber) axes.

Using θ=60°, evaluate cos(120°) and sin(120°).
Compute the transformed stresses σ'_11, σ'_22, σ'_12 using the formulas from Step 3, the values from Step 2, and trig values from Step 4. Give numerical results in MPa.

question.text: Given the joint PDF $f_{X,Y}(x,y) = { rac{3}{7}}x$ within the region shown below and 0 otherwise, let $Z = Y-X$. Find the PDF $f_Z(z)$. <image>

answer.text: We use the technique of first finding the CDF and differentiating it to get the PDF. $$ egin{array}{r l}{F_{Z}(z)}&{=\quad\mathbf{P}(Z\leq z)}\ &{=\quad\mathbf{P}(Y-X\leq z)}\ &{=\quad\left\{ egin{array}{l l}{0,}&{\mathrm{i f~}z<-2,}\ {\displaystyle\int_{x=-z}^{x=2}\int_{y=0}^{y=x+z} rac{3}{7}x d y d x}&{= rac{8}{7}+ rac{6}{7}z- rac{1}{14}z^{3},}&{\mathrm{i f~}-2\leq z\leq-1,}\ {\displaystyle\int_{x=1}^{x=2}\int_{y=0}^{y=x+z} rac{3}{7}x d y d x}&{=1+ rac{9}{14}z,}&{\mathrm{i f~}-1<z\leq0,}\ {1,}&{\mathrm{i f~}0<z.}\end{array}ight.}\ &{\quad f_{Z}(z)= rac{d}{d z}F_{Z}(z)=\left\{ egin{array}{l l}{ rac{6}{7}- rac{3}{14}z^{2},}&{\mathrm{i f~}-2\leq z\leq-1,}\ { rac{9}{14},}&{\mathrm{i f~}-1<z\leq0,}\ {0,}&{\mathrm{o t h e r w i s e.}}\end{array}ight.}\end{array}$$

short_answer_description: The probability density function f_Z(z) for the random variable Z = Y - X, expressed as a mathematical function of z, likely defined piecewise over specific intervals.

reasoning_flow.step: From the problem statement and figure, state the joint PDF f_{X,Y}(x,y) (as a formula) and the geometric region (in inequalities) where it is nonzero.

For a given z in [-2,0], describe the condition on x for which the integration upper bound y\le x+z intersects the region 0\le y\le x (i.e., find x where x+z>0).
For -2\le z\le-1, determine the x-range within [1,2] where x+z>0, and hence set up the double integral for F_Z(z) over x and y.

question.text: Consider the telephoto lens system shown below. Lens Ll has known focal length f, and lens L2 has unknown focal length $f_{0}$ . The distance d between the two lenses is also unknown. Specify the telephoto system according to the following requirements: i) An object at infinity, placed off-axis at angular deviation $\alpha=10^{-2}$ radians,produces a real image of size $h=5\times10^{-2}f$ 。(cm). ii) The real image specified in part (i) is located at a distance 3f from L1. <image>If a object is 24f away from lens Ll, where is the image plane and what is the magnification? Is the image real or virtual, erect or inverted?

answer.text:
Object is 24f away from lens L1.

For L1:
$S_{o1} = -24f$.
$\frac{1}{S_{i1}} = \frac{1}{f} - \frac{1}{S_{o1}} = \frac{1}{f} - \frac{1}{(-24f)} = \frac{1}{f} + \frac{1}{24f} = \frac{25}{24f}$.
So $S_{i1} = \frac{24f}{25}$.

This image serves as an object for L2.
$S_{o2} = d - S_{i1} = \frac{f}{2} - \frac{24f}{25} = \frac{25f - 48f}{50} = -\frac{23f}{50}$.

For L2:
$\frac{1}{S_{i2}} = \frac{1}{f_{0}} - \frac{1}{S_{o2}} = \frac{1}{(-\frac{5}{8} f)} - \frac{1}{(-\frac{23f}{50})} = -\frac{8}{5f} + \frac{50}{23f} = \frac{(-8 \times 23) + (50 \times 5)}{115f} = \frac{-184 + 250}{115f} = \frac{66}{115f}$.
So $S_{i2} = \frac{115f}{66}$.

The image plane is at a distance $\frac{115f}{66}$ from L2 (to the right).

Magnification $M1 = \frac{S_{i1}}{S_{o1}} = \frac{\frac{24f}{25}}{-24f} = -\frac{1}{25}$.

Magnification $M2 = \frac{S_{i2}}{S_{o2}} = \frac{\frac{115f}{66}}{-\frac{23f}{50}} = \frac{115}{66} \times -\frac{50}{23} = \frac{5}{66} \times -50 = -\frac{250}{66} = -\frac{125}{33}$.

Total Magnification $M = M1 \times M2 = \left(-\frac{1}{25}\right) \times \left(-\frac{125}{33}\right) = \frac{5}{33}$.

Since $M > 0$, the image is erect. Since $S_{i2} > 0$, the image is real.

question.text: We abstractly represent the connections between various states of a system with the picture below. In the picture, each filed circle represents a "node", and each line represents an "edge." When two nodes are linked by an edge, we say that they are "connected." <image> Figure 5 If at time t, we are at a node that is connected to M edges, then, in the next time step $t+\Delta t,$ there is a probability of $1/M$ of traveling down any one of the connecting edges. There is a probability of zero of remaining at the same node. We take $t\to\infty$ . What is the probability to be at the various nodes?

answer.text: To find the equilibrium probabilities for this system, we will make use of the detailed balance equation $$\frac{p_{i}^{\mathrm{e q}}}{p_{j}^{\mathrm{e q}}}=\frac{\pi_{j\rightarrow i}}{\pi_{i\rightarrow j}}.$$ Computing te nn-tial librium probablty ais frm.$\operatorname{E q.}(67)$ ,we have $$\begin{aligned}\frac{p_{1}^{\mathrm{eq}}}{p_{2}^{\mathrm{eq}}}&=\frac{1/4}{1}\\&=\frac{1}{4}\quad\longrightarrow\quad p_{2}^{\mathrm{eq}}=4p_{1}^{\mathrm{eq}}\\\frac{p_{2}^{\mathrm{eq}}}{p_{3}^{\mathrm{eq}}}&=\frac{2/3}{1/2}\\&=\frac{4}{3}\quad\longrightarrow\quad p_{3}^{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{3}{4}p_{2}^{\mathrm{eq}}=3p_{1}^{\mathrm{eq}}\\\frac{p_{3}^{\mathrm{eq}}}{p_{4}^{\mathrm{eq}}}&=\frac{1/2}{1/3}\\&=\frac{3}{2}\quad\longrightarrow\quad p_{4}^{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{2}{3}p_{3}^{\mathrm{eq}}=2p_{1}^{\mathrm{eq}}.\end{aligned}$$ In the above calculation, for each new result, we used the previous result to write the equilibrium probability in terms of $p_{1}^{\mathrm{e q}}$ . Assembling these results and noting that the probabilities must be normalized, we have the condition $$1=p_{1}^{\mathrm{eq}}+p_{2}^{\mathrm{eq}}+p_{3}^{\mathrm{eq}}+p_{4}^{\mathrm{eq}}=\left(1+4+3+2\right)p_{1}^{\mathrm{eq}}=10p_{1}^{\mathrm{eq}}$$ which implies that $$ oxed{p_{1}^{\mathrm{e q}}=\frac{1}{10}.}$$ Given $\operatorname{E q.}(70)$ , Eq.(71), and Eq.(72), we find that the other equilibrium probabilities are $$ oxed{p_{2}^{\mathrm{e q}}=\frac{2}{5},\quad p_{3}^{\mathrm{e q}}=\frac{3}{10},\quad p_{4}^{\mathrm{e q}}=\frac{1}{5}.}$$

question.text: Problem: At a section of a beam, the internal forces are $V_{u}=45\ kips,M_{u}=300\ kips-ft$ ,and $T_{u}=$ 120 kips-ft. The material strengths are $f_{c}^{\prime}=4$ ksi and $f_{y}=60$ ksi. Assume that the distance from beam faces to the center of stirrups is 2 in and d is 21 in. <image> Figure 1. Plan view of overpass <image> Figure 2. Cross section a-a Assume that the depth is to be held at 24 in. Select the required torsion, shear, and bending reinforcement for the minimum required width (to nearest inch).

answer.text:
For the minimum required width of 17 in and depth of 24 in:
Stirrups for shear and torsion: The required $\frac{A_t}{s} = 0.0743\ in^2/in$ and $\frac{A_v}{s} = 0.0336\ in^2/in$. The combined minimum requirement is $\left(\frac{A}{s}\right)_{\min} = \frac{A_t}{s} + \frac{1}{2}\frac{A_v}{s} = 0.0911\ in^2/in$. The maximum spacing $s_{max} = \frac{x_1+y_1}{4} = 8.25\ in$. Trying #5 stirrups ($A=0.31\ in^2$) @ 3.5 in, $s_{\min}=\frac{A}{0.0911}=3.4in$ (O.K.) and $s_{\max}=8.25in$ (O.K.). Thus, #5 stirrups @ 3.5 in are O.K.
Longitudinal reinforcement for torsion: $A_l = 2\frac{A_t}{s}(x_1+y_1) = 2(0.0743)(13+20) = 4.9\ in^2$.
Longitudinal reinforcement for bending: From moment capacity equation, $300\times12=0.9(0.85)(4)a(17)(21-\frac{a}{2})$, which yields $a=3.605\ in$. Then $A_s = \frac{0.85f_c'ab}{f_y} = \frac{0.85(4)(3.605)(17)}{60} = 3.47\ in^2$.
Summary of reinforcement: Use 4 #10 bars at the bottom ($3.47\ in^2$ for M, $1.61\ in^2$ for T), 2 #6 bars at intermediate level ($1.50\ in^2$ for T), and 3 #6 bars at the top ($1.79\ in^2$ for T, with $0.46\ in^2$ excess).

question.text:
The next figure shows an all NMOS inverter.

Calculate $\mathrm{V_{O H},V_{O L}}$ ,and $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{M}}$ for the new inverter.

<image>

Figure 3: An Alternate Inverter Implementation

answer.text:
Solution:

$\mathbf{V_{O H^{\prime}}}$ : We calculate $\mathrm{V_{O H}}$ ,when M1 is off. The threshold for M2 is:

$$V_{T}=V_{T0}+\gamma\cdot\left(\sqrt{-2\phi_{F}+V_{S B}}-\sqrt{-2\phi_{F}}\right),V_{S B}=V_{O U T},\left|-2\phi_{F}\right|=0.6V $$

and M2 will be off when:$V_{G S}-V_{T}=V_{D D}-V_{O U T}-V_{T}=0,$ 

Substitute $\mathrm{V_{T}}$ in the last equation and solve for $\mathrm{V_{O U T}}$ 

$$V_{DD}-V_{OUT}-V_T=2.5-V_{OUT}-(0.43+0.4\cdot(\sqrt{|0.6+V_{OUT}|}-\sqrt{|0.6|}))=0$$

We get $\mathbf{V_{O U T}{=}V_{O H}{=}1.765V}$ 

$\mathbf{V_{O I}}$ : To calculate ,$\mathrm{V_{O I}}$ , we set $\mathrm{V_{IN}=V_{DD}=2.5V}$ 

We expect $\mathrm{V_{O U T}}$ ·to be low, so we can make the assumption that M2 will be velocity saturated and Ml will be in the linear region.

$$\mathrm{F o r}\mathrm{M}2:I_{D2}=k_{n}^{\prime}\cdot\frac{W_{2}}{L_{2}}\cdot\left((V_{G S}-V_{T})\cdot V_{D S A T}-\frac{V_{D S A T}^{2}}{2}\right)\cdot(1+\lambda V_{D S})\mathrm{a n d}$$

$$I_{D1}=k_{n}^{\prime}\cdot\frac{W_{1}}{L_{1}}\cdot\left((V_{G S}-V_{T0})\cdot V_{D S}-\frac{V_{D S}^{2}}{2}\right)$$

Setting $I_{D1}=I_{D2}$ _, we get an equation and we solve for $\mathrm{V_{O U T}}$ 

We get:$\mathbf{V_{O U T}{=}}\mathbf{V_{O L}{=}}\mathbf{0.263V},$ ,So our assumption holds. We have input 2.5 V instead of $\mathrm{V_{O H}}$ , an assumption that is often used. If we instead put $\mathrm{V_{O H}}$ at the input,$\mathrm{V_{OL}=0.38\ V}$ and full credit was given for either solution.

$\mathbf{V_{M}}^{\mathrm{{:}}}$ :To calculate $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{M}}$ we set $\mathrm{V_{M}=V_{I N}=V_{O U T}}$ 

Assuming that both transistors are velocity saturated, then we have the next pair of equations:

$$I_{D1}=k_{n}\cdot\frac{W_{1}}{L_{1}}\cdot\left((V_{M}-V_{T0})\cdot V_{D S A T}-\frac{V_{D S A T}^{2}}{2}\right)\cdot(1+\lambda V_{M})\mathrm{a n d}$$

$$I_{D2}=k_{n}\cdot\frac{W_{2}}{L_{2}}\cdot\left((V_{D D}-V_{M}-V_{T})\cdot V_{D S A T}-\frac{V_{D S A T}^{2}}{2}\right)\cdot\left(1+\lambda(V_{D D}-V_{M})\right)$$

Setting $I_{D1}=I_{D2}$ , we get for $\mathbf{V_{M}}=\mathbf{1.01}\mathbf{V}$

question.text:
Consider the infinite cylindrical conductor or radius $\mathbb{R}_{1}$ sketched below. This conductor has a cylindrical hole of radius $\mathbb{R}_{2}\mathrm{<}\mathbb{R}_{1}/2$ along its length. The hole is adjacent to the surface as shown.The conductor carries a current I with a uniform current density. Determine the magnetic field at a point along the line joining the center of the conductor and the center of the hole, on the for $\mathrm{r}\mathrm{<}\mathbb{R}_{1}$ on the side opposite the hole.

<image>

answer.text:
This problem can be solved using the principle of superposition. Consider the conductor as a solid cylinder of radius $R_1$ carrying the total current $I$, with current density $J = I / (\pi R_1^2 - \pi R_2^2)$, minus a cylinder of radius $R_2$ (the hole) carrying a 'negative' current with the same current density $J$. Let the origin be at the center of the large conductor.

The magnetic field inside a solid cylinder of radius $R$ carrying uniform current density $J$ is given by Ampere's Law as $B = \frac{\mu_0 J r}{2}$ (for $r < R$).

Let the center of the large conductor be at the origin (0,0) and the center of the hole be at $(d,0)$ where $d = R_1 - R_2$. We want to find the magnetic field at a point $P$ on the x-axis, on the side opposite the hole. Let $P$ be at $(-x, 0)$ where $x < R_1$.

The magnetic field due to the solid cylinder (without the hole) at point P is $B_{solid} = \frac{\mu_0 J (-x)}{2}$ (directed along y-axis if current is along z-axis, $x$ is positive magnitude here, so $r=x$ from origin).
$B_{solid} = \frac{\mu_0 J x}{2}$ (magnitude) pointing in the direction of $\vec{r} \times \hat{k}$ if current is out of page.

The magnetic field due to the 'negative' current in the hole, at point P, is $B_{hole} = \frac{\mu_0 (-J) r'}{2}$, where $r'$ is the distance from the center of the hole to point P. The center of the hole is at $d = R_1 - R_2$. So $r' = x - (R_1 - R_2)$.
$B_{hole} = -\frac{\mu_0 J (x - (R_1 - R_2))}{2}$.

The total magnetic field is the vector sum: $B_{total} = B_{solid} + B_{hole} = \frac{\mu_0 J x}{2} - \frac{\mu_0 J (x - (R_1 - R_2))}{2}$.
$B_{total} = \frac{\mu_0 J}{2} [x - (x - (R_1 - R_2))] = \frac{\mu_0 J}{2} (R_1 - R_2)$.

Substitute the current density $J = \frac{I}{\pi (R_1^2 - R_2^2)}$:
$B_{total} = \frac{\mu_0}{2} \frac{I}{\pi (R_1^2 - R_2^2)} (R_1 - R_2) = \frac{\mu_0 I (R_1 - R_2)}{2\pi (R_1 - R_2)(R_1 + R_2)} = \frac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi (R_1 + R_2)}$.

The image in the answer document shows the setup and detailed steps using this superposition method, leading to the final result of $B = \frac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi (R_1 + R_2)}$.

question.text:
A cylindrical wheel of uniform density, having the mass $\mathrm{M}=0,40$ kg, the radius $\mathrm{R}=0.060$ m and the thickness $\mathrm{d}=0.010$ m is suspended by means of two light strings of the same length from the ceiling. Each string is wound around the axle of the wheel. Like the strings, the mass of the axle is negligible. When the wheel is turned manually, the strings are wound up until the centre of mass is raised 1,0 m above the floor. If the wheel is allowed to move downward vertically under the pulling force of the gravity, the strings are unwound to the full length of the strings and the wheel reaches the lowest point. The strings then begin to wound in the opposite sense resulting in the wheel being raised upwards.

Analyze and answer the following questions, assuming that the strings are in vertical position and the points where the strings touch the axle are directly below their respective suspending points (see fig. 19.5).

<image>
Fig. 19.5
Determine the angular speed of the wheel when the centre of mass of the wheel covers the vertical distance s.

answer.text:
conservation of energy:

$$\mathbf{M}\cdot\mathbf{g}\cdot\mathbf{s}=\frac{1}{2}\cdot\mathbf{I}_{\mathbf{A}}\cdot\mathbf{\omega}^2$$

where ω is the angular speed of the wheel and $\mathsf{I}_{\mathsf{A}}$ is the moment of inertia about the axis through $\mathbf{A}$ .

Note: If we would take the moment of inertia about S instead of A we would have 

$$\mathbf{M}\cdot\mathbf{g}\cdot\mathbf{s}=\frac{1}{2}\cdot\mathbf{I}_{\mathbf{s}}\cdot\mathbf{w}^2+\frac{1}{2}\cdot\mathbf{m}\cdot\mathbf{v}^2$$

where v is the speed of the centre of mass along the vertical.This equation is the same as the above one in meanings since 

$$\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{A}}=\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{S}}+\mathrm{M}\cdot\mathrm{r}^{2}\quad\text{and}\quad\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{S}}=\mathrm{M}\cdot\mathrm{R}^{2}$$

From (1) we get 

substitute 

$$\begin{aligned}&\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2\cdot\mathsf{M}\cdot\mathsf{g}\cdot\mathsf{s}}{\mathsf{I}_{\mathsf{A}}}}\\ &\mathbf{I}_{\mathsf{A}}=\frac{1}{2}\cdot\mathsf{M}\cdot\mathsf{r}^2+\mathsf{M}\cdot\mathsf{R}^2\\ \end{aligned}$$

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2\cdot g\cdot s}{r^{2}+\frac{R^{2}}{2}}}$$

Putting in numbers we get 

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2\cdot9,81\cdot0,50}{9\cdot10^{-6}+\frac{1}{2}\cdot36\cdot10^{-4}}}\approx72,4\frac{\mathrm{rad}}{\mathrm{s}}$$

short_answer_description: The mathematical expression for the angular speed of the wheel after its center of mass has covered a vertical distance s. The answer should be a formula in LaTeX format, expressed in terms of variables such as the acceleration due to gravity g, the vertical distance s, the radius of the wheel R, and the radius of the axle r.

question.text:
The following diagram shows a schematic for the pullup circuitry for a particular CMos gate:

<image>

B. Assuming the pulldown circuitry is designed correctly, give an expression for the logic function implemented by this gate.

answer.text:
Using the pullup circuitry we can develop the following sum-of-products expression for F:

$$\mathrm{F}=(\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{D})^{\star}(\mathrm{B}+\mathrm{C})=\mathrm{A}^{\star}\mathrm{B}+\mathrm{A}^{\star}\mathrm{C}+\mathrm{B}^{\star}\mathrm{D}+\mathrm{C}^{\star}\mathrm{D}$$

Or we can look at the pulldown circuitry and express F as the complement of the function that describes when the pulldown is on:

$$\mathrm{\boldmath~F~}=\mathrm{\boldmath~\mathbb{A}^{\star}D~}+\mathrm{\boldmath~\mathbb{B}^{\star}C~}$$

Using several applications of DeMorgan's theorem this can be expanded to 

$$\mathrm{\boldmath~\cal~F~}=\mathrm{\boldmath~\left(\mathbb{A}^{\star}\mathbb{D}\right)~}^{\star}\left(\mathrm{\boldmath~\overline{{B^{\star}C}}}\right)=\mathrm{\boldmath~\left(\mathbb{A}~}+\mathrm{\boldmath~\overline{{D}}}\right)~}^{\star}\left(\mathrm{\boldmath~\overline{{B}}~}+\mathrm{\boldmath~\overline{{C}}}\right)$$

short_answer_description: The boolean logic expression representing the function implemented by the CMOS gate shown in the schematic. The answer should be a mathematical formula in LaTeX format expressing the output logic function in terms of the input variables (e.g., A, B, C, D).

reasoning_flow.step: From the schematic (and the statement that the pulldown is designed correctly), write a Boolean expression for the condition when the pulldown network is conducting (pulldown ON) in terms of A, B, C, D.
Express the gate output F as the logical function relating to the pulldown conduction condition found in Step 1 (i.e., write F as the complement of the pulldown-ON expression).
Apply DeMorgan's theorem to the expression from Step 2 to rewrite \overline{A D + B C} as a product of complements.
Apply DeMorgan's theorem separately to each factor in the product from Step 3 to rewrite \overline{A D} and \overline{B C} as sums of complements of single variables.
Multiply out (expand) the product-of-sums obtained in Step 4 to produce a sum-of-products expression for F.
Rewrite the result of Step 5 using the notation A^{\star} for \overline{A} to match the reference answer's style.

question.text: A cutaway view of an ideal toroidal coil, whose axis-of-symmetry coincides with the $z\mathrm{a x i s}$ , is shown below. It has rectangular cross-section, inner radius a, outer radius $b,$ height $c,$ and a total of N turns. In addition to the toroidal coil, there is a long straight wire that coincides with the z axis. The directions of positive currents $I_{1}$ and $I_{2}$ in these conductors are indicated with arrows <image> What is the mutual inductance M of the toroidal coil and the long straight wire?

answer.text:
Solution.
a) Assume a current $I_{2}$ flows in the straight wire. Its magnetic field is 
$$\mathbf{B}=\frac{\mu_{0}I_{2}}{2\pi r}\hat{\phi},$$
and its flux through the toroidal coil is 
$$\Phi_{2\rightarrow1}=N\int_{S}\mathbf{B}\cdot d\mathbf{a}=-\frac{\mu_{0}N I_{2}}{2\pi}c\int_{a}^{b}\frac{d r}{r}=-\frac{\mu_{0}N c\ln(b/a)}{2\pi}I_{2}=M_{12}I_{2}$$
By reciprocity,$M=M_{12}=M_{21}$ _⊥. Therefore, we identify 
$$\boxed{M=-\frac{\mu_{0}N c\ln(b/a)}{2\pi}}$$
Note that the negative sign originates with the given loop orientations. In this case, the azimuthal magnetic field due to current $I_{2}$ is pointed in the opposite direction of the toroid's integration surface S, obtained from the Stokes'theorem's right-hand rule for the toroid's loop orientation. If we flip one of the loop's orientations, then M would become positive. This is in contrast to any loop's self-induction $L$ , which is always positive.
As usual, we could have also calculated the mutual inductance M by instead assuming a current $I_{1}$ flowing in the toroidal coil and then calculating the resulting fux through circuit $C_{2}$ , which is formed by the long straight wire and a big semicircular half-loop at infinity. In this case, the work is the same, but, perhaps, it is a bit more conceptually sketchy.

short_answer_description: A mathematical expression in LaTeX format representing the mutual inductance M between the toroidal coil and the long straight wire, expressed in terms of the given parameters (inner radius a, outer radius b, height c, number of turns N) and physical constants.

reasoning_flow.step: Write the expression for the magnetic field B(r) at radial distance r from a long straight wire carrying current I_2 along the z-axis (use μ_0 and cylindrical unit vectors).

State the number of turns N and the geometric dimensions of the toroidal coil that determine the differential area element for flux calculation (inner radius a, outer radius b, height c), and write an expression for the area element d\mathbf{a} for an elemental rectangular strip at radius r spanning height c.
Form the integrand for the magnetic flux through one turn of the toroid due to the straight wire by computing \mathbf{B}\cdot d\mathbf{a} using the expressions from Steps 1 and 2.

Explain whether the dot product in Step 3 is zero or nonzero given the orientation of the toroid surface used to compute flux (use the toroid's integration surface S whose normal is along -\hat{\phi} or \hat{\phi} as determined by loop orientation) and, if nonzero, give the corrected expression for \mathbf{B}\cdot d\mathbf{a} appropriate for the flux calculation.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: Nonzero when the toroid's elemental area is taken with normal along \pm\hat{\phi}; the correct integrand for flux using the toroid's chosen surface S is \mathbf{B}\cdot d\mathbf{a}=\pm\dfrac{\mu_{0}I_{2}}{2\pi r}c\,dr

reasoning_flow.step: Write the integral expression for the total flux Φ_{2→1} through the N-turn toroidal coil by integrating the integrand from Step 4 over r from a to b and including the factor N and the appropriate sign.
Evaluate the integral in Step 5 to express Φ_{2→1} as a product of I_2 and a coefficient (show the logarithm), keeping the sign explicit.
Define the mutual inductance M_{12} by the relation Φ_{2→1}=M_{12}I_{2} and state M_{12} from the result of Step 6 (include the sign determined above).

Invoke reciprocity (M_{12}=M_{21}) to state the mutual inductance M between the toroidal coil and the straight wire, and choose the sign consistent with the given current arrow orientations in the problem statement.
State briefly why the sign in Step 8 is negative in terms of relative orientation of the azimuthal magnetic field and the toroid's integration-surface normal (answer as a short phrase).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: Because the azimuthal B from I_2 is opposite to the toroid surface normal given the stated loop orientations

question.text: <image> Chassis Engineering by Herb Adams In this problem, we will investigate basic vehicle traction principles. The most important vehicle components when it comes to traction are the tires, since they are the only actual interface between the road and the car. The figure above is a tire performance curve, which illustrates the nonlinear relationship between vertical load on a tire and available traction. As the vertical load on this tire increases, it's cornering efficiency decreases. Assume all vehicles in this problem are using tires that can be represented by the above curve. b)We are now racing a heavier, 300 Ib vehicle around a circular race track. As the car turns (going counterclockwise), there will be a lateral weight transfer from the left to the right side of the vehicle.Use the following simplified formula to determine the weight transfer we would expect with a 1g cornering force, where 'Wcar is the weight of the car, 'a' is the cornering acceleration in $\mathsf{g}^{\prime}\mathsf{s}$ , 'hcg'is the height of the center of gravity in inches (assume 20 inches),$\mathrm{{'g'}}$ is gravity, and 'Itrack' is the vehicle track width (assume 60 inches). $$W_{T}=\frac{W_{c a r}*a*h_{c g}}{g*l_{t r a c k}}$$ Determine the traction that each wheel is able to maintain after the weight shift. What cornering force (in g's) does this equate to? How does that compare to the traction available to this vehicle on a straight track?

answer.text: First, determine the lateral weight transfer: W_t=(3000 lb*1 g*20 inches)/(1 g*60 inches)=1000 lb Now, find the tractive force available on each wheel: Wheel | Initial Weight | Initial Traction | Weight Shift | Shifted Weight | Available Traction Front Left | 750 | 850 | -500 | 250 | 450 Back Left | 750 | 850 | -500 | 250 | 450 Front Right | 750 | 850 | +500 | 1250 | 1150 Back Right | 750 | 850 | +500 | 1250 | 1150 Initial Vehicle Traction Capability=4*850Ibs=3,400 lbs Max Initial Acceleration=3,400 lbs/3,000 lbs=1.13 g's 1g Cornering Vehicle Traction Capability=2*1150 lb+2*450 lb=3,200 lb Max Acceleration,1g Cornering Vehicle=3,200 lbs/3,000 lbs=1.07 g's So, the tractive capability of the vehicle that is cornering at 1 g is reduced from 1.13 g's to 1.07 g's. It won't lose traction while cornering at this speed unless it also accelerates forward or backward such that the resultant acceleration vectors is greater than 1.07 g's.

The available traction force for the back-left tire after the calculated weight transfer reduces its vertical load, determined based on the tire performance relationship. Expected to be a numerical value in pounds (lb).

The available traction force for the back-right tire after the calculated weight transfer increases its vertical load, determined based on the tire performance relationship. Expected to be a numerical value in pounds (lb).
The sum of the traction forces from all four wheels (front-left, back-left, front-right, back-right) during the cornering maneuver. Expected to be a numerical value in pounds (lb).

The equivalent cornering acceleration the vehicle can sustain based on the total cornering traction, calculated as the ratio of total traction to vehicle weight. Expected to be a numerical value in units of gravity (g).
The total traction available to the vehicle when traveling in a straight line with static weight distribution (no lateral weight transfer). Expected to be a numerical value in pounds (lb).
The theoretical maximum acceleration in g's corresponding to the total traction available in the straight-line configuration. Expected to be a numerical value in units of gravity (g).

A statement analyzing how the cornering force (in g's) after weight transfer compares to the traction available on a straight track, specifically noting whether performance increased or decreased. Expected to be a text description.

question.text:
<image>

The optical instrument shown above (not to scale) consists of three lenses L1, L2, L3.Lenses L1, L3 are positive with focal lengths $f_{1}=+20$ cm and $f_{3}=+5$ cm, as shown.Lens L2 is negative, with focal length $f_{2}=-x$ cm, where $x>0$ is to be specified. The distance between L1 and L2 is $(20-x)$ cm, as shown; that is, once we specify x this distance is also specified. The distance between L2 and L3 is fixed to 8 cm, as shown.

The system's aperture stop (AS) is located 20 cm to the left of L1, and its half—size is 2 cm. The system's field stop (FS) is located 5 cm to the right of L3, overlapping with the image plane. The FS half—size is 1 cm.

The instrument is intended for imaging objects at infinity. If a parallel ray bundle from such an object arrives at angle α with respect to the optical axis, the instrument is required to form a real image of height $h=\pm50\alpha$ at the image plane. Use the paraxial approximation to answer the following questions.
Specify x to meet the imaging requirement. Is the image erect or inverted in your design? What is the Field of View (FoV)?

answer.text:
The overall system matrix from L1 to the field stop (FS) is calculated:
$[-\left(\begin{array}{cc}1 & 0 \\ -1 / 5 & 1\end{array}\right) \times\left(\begin{array}{cc}1 & 8 \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right) \times\left(\begin{array}{cc}1 & 0 \\ -1 / x & 1\end{array}\right) \times\left(\begin{array}{cc}1 & 20-x \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right) \times\left(\begin{array}{cc}1 & 0 \\ -1 / 20 & 1\end{array}\right)]$
Then, with the translation of 5 cm to L3 to reach the FS:
$\left(\begin{array}{ll}A & B \\ C & D\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right)[0]=\left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & 100 / x \\ -0.01 x & -4-12 / x+0.2 x\end{array}\right)$
Given $x_{out} = \pm 50\alpha$, we have $(100/x)\alpha = \pm 50\alpha$. This yields $x=2$ cm.
Since $100/x$ is positive for $x=2$ cm, and the required height $h=+50\alpha$, the image is erect.
The Field of View (FoV) is calculated as $2\operatorname{tg}^{-1}(\frac{1}{5}) \simeq 22^{\circ}$.

short_answer_description: The calculated numerical value for the parameter x (in cm), which defines the focal length of lens L2 (f2 = -x) and the distance between L1 and L2, required to satisfy the condition that the image height is h = 50 * alpha.
A text description indicating the orientation of the final image relative to the object, specifically specifying whether it is 'erect' or 'inverted'.
The calculated Field of View (FoV) for the optical instrument, expressed as a numerical value with appropriate angular units (such as degrees).

reasoning_flow.step: Extract the focal lengths f1, f2 (in terms of x), and f3 and the distances between lenses L1-L2 and L2-L3 from the problem statement.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: f1=+20 cm, f2=-x cm, f3=+5 cm; distance L1-L2 = 20-x cm, distance L2-L3 = 8 cm

reasoning_flow.step: Extract the positions and half-sizes of the aperture stop (AS) and the field stop (FS) relative to the lens system and image plane from the problem statement.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: AS: 20 cm left of L1, half-size 2 cm; FS: 5 cm right of L3 at image plane, half-size 1 cm

reasoning_flow.step: Write the paraxial ray transfer (ABCD) matrices for: (a) a thin lens of focal length f, (b) free-space propagation of distance d. Provide the specific matrices for L1, the translation between L1 and L2, L2, translation between L2 and L3, L3, and the translation of 5 cm from L3 to the FS using the focal values and distances from previous steps.
Multiply the interior matrices from L1 through L3 (i.e., L3 * T(8) * L2 * T(20-x) * L1) symbolically to obtain the 2x2 matrix elements before the final T(5).

Confirm the final system matrix from just before T(5) to the FS by applying the T(5) translation to the matrix obtained in the previous step (i.e., compute M = T(5)*[matrix from Step 4]) and state the resulting A and B elements relating input angle to output height.
Write the relation between input ray angle α (object at infinity) and output image height h at the FS using the system matrix elements A and B from Step 5.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: h = A*y_in + B*α = (100/x)*α (since A=0 and input ray height y_in=0 for object at infinity)

reasoning_flow.step: Use the imaging requirement that the instrument must form h = ±50 α to solve for x from the equation derived in Step 6.
Determine whether the image is erect or inverted by checking the sign of the transverse magnification (B) for the chosen x and comparing it to the required sign in h = ±50 α.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: Erect (B = 100/2 = +50, positive, so h has same sign as α)

reasoning_flow.step: Compute the angular half-field α_max from the field stop half-size (1 cm) and the image height relation h = 50 α, then calculate the full Field of View (FoV) in degrees as 2*arctan(α_max) using small-angle exact relation.

question.text:
A spiral galaxies has stars in various places measured compared to us via Doppler shift. The resulting velocities are as plotted at right.

<image>

 Assume the mass of the galaxy is EM 
distributed in a spherical 

symmetric manner. What is the total mass of the galaxy contained within spheres of radius 5 kpc and 10 kpc of the center of the galaxy?

answer.text:
For a spherically symmetric mas distribution, the gravitational atraction of the galaxy on a mass at a distance R will be the same as the gravitational pull from a point mass located at the center whose mass M is just the amount of mass contained within the radius R. Treating the mass of the pulled on object as m, we would have the gravitational force matching the centrifugal force $GMm/R^{2}=mV^{2}/R,so M=V^{2}R/G$ . We now just substitute this formula at each radius, to find 

$$\frac{\left(2.40\times10^{5}\ m/s\right)^{2}\left(5\times10^{3}\ pc\right)}{6.674\times10^{-11}\ m^{3}\ kg^{-1}s^{-2}}\cdot\frac{3.086\times10^{16}\ m}{pc}=\frac{1.33\times10^{41}\ kg}{1.989\times10^{30}\ kg/M_{\odot}}=6.70\times10^{10}\ M_{\odot},\quad\frac{3.086\times10^{16}\ m}{pc}=\frac{3.63\times10^{41}\ kg}{1.989\times10^{30}\ kg/M_{\odot}}=1.82\times10^{11}\ M_{\odot}.$$

short_answer_description: The calculated total mass of the galaxy contained within a sphere of radius 5 kpc from the center, expected to be a numerical value (likely in scientific notation) with units of solar masses.
The calculated total mass of the galaxy contained within a sphere of radius 10 kpc from the center, expected to be a numerical value (likely in scientific notation) with units of solar masses.

reasoning_flow.step: State the formula that gives the enclosed mass M(R) for a test particle orbiting at circular speed V at radius R for a spherically symmetric mass distribution (use G for Newton's constant).
From the velocity vs distance plot, read off the circular orbital speed V at radius d = 5 kpc (report in km/s).
Convert the speed from Step 2 (240 km/s) into meters per second.
Convert the radius 5 kpc into meters using 1 pc = 3.086e16 m.
Using M = V^{2} R / G with V = 2.40e5 m/s, R = 1.543e20 m, and G = 6.674e-11 m^{3} kg^{-1} s^{-2}, compute the enclosed mass M within 5 kpc in kilograms.
Convert the mass from Step 5 (1.33e41 kg) into solar masses using 1 M_{\odot} = 1.989e30 kg.
From the reference answer extract the enclosed mass within 10 kpc expressed in kilograms (as given in the reference solution).
Convert the mass from Step 7 (3.63e41 kg) into solar masses using 1 M_{\odot} = 1.989e30 kg.

question.text:
A non-planar dislocation loop is shown in the diagram below. Each of the dislocation segments lies parallel to one of the coordinate axes. The segment AB is a left-handed screw dislocation.

<image>

 Identify the character (positive edge, negative edge, right-handed screw (RHS), left-handed screw (LHS)) of each segment of the dislocation loop.

answer.text:
Since we are told AB is LHS, we know the burgers vector b is parallel to the line vector s but in an opposite direction. This sets s for the other segements in the loop; it goes counterclockwise around the loop. The burgers vector for the loop does not change. This gives The convention for a positive and negative edge dislocation is
SegmentCharacter
ABLHS
BC-Edge
CD-Edge
DE+Edge
EFRHS
FG+Edge
GH+Edge
HA-Edge
arbitrary in any real sense; we can choose to define a positive edge with a Burgers vector to the right for a dislocation line direction into the page, but we cannot choose to make these vectors non-orthogonal (that is the defining property of the edge dislocation). Which ones you choose to call positive and negative are immaterial, as long as you recognize that DE and GH are opposite; and BC and HA are the same and opposite from DE and FG.

The character classification (e.g., positive edge, negative edge, right-handed screw, or left-handed screw) for the dislocation segment FG.
The character classification (e.g., positive edge, negative edge, right-handed screw, or left-handed screw) for the dislocation segment GH.
The character classification (e.g., positive edge, negative edge, right-handed screw, or left-handed screw) for the dislocation segment HA.

question.text:
Consider the linkage shown Figure 2. This problem considers the stationary configurations of this mechanism. In this mechanism, let $|{\overline{{A B}}}|=1$ . The dimension $|{\overline{{A C}}}|=l_{1}$ is a parameter, and you will consider its value below. <image> Figure 2: Planar Closed Loop Mechanism 
 It was shown in class that the special (or stationary) configurations for the $j^{\mathit{t h}}$ joint occur when the determinant of the cofactor of the $(j,j)$ element of the Grammian matrix:
$$\left[\begin{matrix}{\xi_{1}\cdot\xi_{1}}&{\xi_{1}\cdot\xi_{2}}&{\xi_{1}\cdot\xi_{3}}&{\xi_{1}\cdot\xi_{4}}\\ {\xi_{2}\cdot\xi_{1}}&{\xi_{2}\cdot\xi_{2}}&{\xi_{2}\cdot\xi_{3}}&{\xi_{2}\cdot\xi_{4}}\\ {\xi_{3}\cdot\xi_{1}}&{\xi_{3}\cdot\xi_{2}}&{\xi_{3}\cdot\xi_{3}}&{\xi_{3}\cdot\xi_{4}}\\ {\xi_{4}\cdot\xi_{1}}&{\xi_{4}\cdot\xi_{2}}&{\xi_{4}\cdot\xi_{3}}&{\xi_{4}\cdot\xi_{4}}\\ \end{matrix}\right]$$
becomes zero (where $\xi_{j}$ denotes the twist for joint axis j).
Develop an expression for the stationary configurations of the joint B. What are the necessary conditions (in terms of link lengths, etc.) for joint B to have a stationary configuration?

answer.text:
A stationary configuration of joint 4 (the joint at point B) will occur when:
$$d e t\left[\begin{matrix}{\xi_{1}\cdot\xi_{1}}&{\xi_{1}\cdot\xi_{2}}&{\xi_{1}\cdot\xi_{3}}\\ {\xi_{2}\cdot\xi_{1}}&{\xi_{2}\cdot\xi_{2}}&{\xi_{2}\cdot\xi_{3}}\\ {\xi_{3}\cdot\xi_{1}}&{\xi_{3}\cdot\xi_{2}}&{\xi_{3}\cdot\xi_{3}}\\ \end{matrix}\right]=0.$$
For this linkage:
$$\begin{array}{r l}{\xi_{1}\cdot\xi_{1}}&{=\xi_{1}\cdot\xi_{2}=\xi_{2}\cdot\xi_{1}=1}\\ {\xi_{1}\cdot\xi_{3}}&{=\xi_{3}\cdot\xi_{1}=0}\\ {\xi_{2}\cdot\xi_{2}}&{=l_{1}^{2}}\\ {\xi_{2}\cdot\xi_{3}}&{=\xi_{3}\cdot\xi_{2}=l_{1}\sin(\theta_{1}+\theta_{4})}\\ {\xi_{3}\cdot\xi_{3}}&{=1}\end{array}$$
Substituting Equation (8) into Equation (7) and taking the determinant:
$$\begin{aligned}{d e t\left[\begin{matrix}{1}&{1}&{0}\\ {1}&{1+l_{1}^{2}}&{l_{1}\operatorname{s i n}(\theta_{1}+\theta_{4})}\\ {0}&{l_{1}\operatorname{s i n}(\theta_{1}+\theta_{4})}&{1}\\ \end{matrix}\right]=l_{1}^{2}(1-\operatorname{s i n}^{2}(\theta_{1}+\theta_{4}))=l_{1}^{2}\operatorname{c o s}^{2}(\theta_{1}+\theta_{4})}\\ \end{aligned}$$
Discarding the trivial case where $l_{1}=0$ ,joint B will have a special configuration when (cos $\theta_{1}+\cos\theta_{4})=0$ . For this to occur, lne $\vec{A C}$ must intersect line $\vec{B C}$ orthogonally. This can only occur if $l_{1}\leq|A B|=1$

question.text: Tall buildings with a steel structure often vibrate under wind loadings and means must be used to control the displacements in the structure. It is proposed to use an electromagnetic device to control these vibrations. A simple version of such a device is shown in the figure below. A highly permeable cylindrical magnetic structure with permeability $\mu	o\infty$ has a coil of $N_{0}$ turns with a DC current $I_{0}$ that produces a magnetic field in the gap of width g. A concentrated coil ofN turns carrying a current i is mounted on a sliding mechanism that allows it to move with displacement δ as shown. For purposes of this analysis assume that the free-space gap is small,$g\ll R$ ,and that the field in the gap is purely in the radial direction but does not significantly vary with the radial coordinate r. <image> Side cross-Section View End view Find the force on the concentrated coil due to currents $I_{0}$ and i and other relevant parameters.

answer.text: $$\overline{{\mathbf{f}}}=\int\overline{{\mathbf{I}}}	imes\overline{{\mathbf{B}}}\mathrm{d}\mathbf{I}=\mathbf{i}\left( rac{\mu_{0}\mathbf{H}_{0}+\mu_{0}\mathbf{H}_{0}^{\prime}}{2}2\pi\mathbf{R}ight)\overline{{\mathbf{i}_{x}}}$$ $$\mathsf{f}_{\mathrm{x}}=-2\pi\mathsf{R}\mu_{0}\operatorname{Ni}\left( rac{2\mathrm{N}_{0}\mathrm{I}_{0}+\mathrm{Ni}}{2\mathrm{g}}ight)$$ Co-energy method $$\mathrm{d}\mathrm{W}=\lambda_{1}\mathrm{d}i_{1}+\lambda_{2}\mathrm{d}i_{2}+\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{e}}\mathrm{d}x $$ $$\mathsf{W}=\int_{\mathsf{i}_2=0}^{\mathsf{I}_0}\lambda_1\mathsf{d}\mathsf{i}_1+\int_{\mathsf{i}_1=\mathsf{I}_0}^{\mathsf{i}}\lambda_2\mathsf{d}\mathsf{i}_2$$ $$=N_{0}\mu_{0}\left[ rac{N_{0}I_{0}^{2}}{2g}2\pi R\delta+ rac{N_{0}I_{0}^{2}}{2g}2\pi R(l-\delta)ight]$$ $$+\mathrm{~N}\mu_{0}\left[ rac{2\mathrm{~N}_{0}\mathrm{~I}_{0}\mathrm{~i}+\mathrm{N i}^{2}}{2\mathrm{g}}\mathrm{~2}\pi\mathrm{R}\left(\mathrm{I}-\deltaight)ight]$$ $$\mathbf{f}_{\mathbf{x}}= rac{\mathbf{d}\mathbf{W}}{\mathbf{d}\delta} igg|_{\mathbf{I}_{0},\mathbf{j}}=-2\pi\mathbf{R}\mathbf{N}\mu_{0}\mathbf{i}\left( rac{2\mathbf{N}_{0}\mathbf{I}_{0}+\mathbf{N}\mathbf{i}}{2\mathbf{g}}ight)$$

short_answer_value: $-2\pi R \mu_{0} N i \left(\dfrac{2 N_{0} I_{0} + N i}{2 g}\right)$
short_answer_description: A mathematical expression in LaTeX format representing the electromagnetic force exerted on the concentrated coil. The formula should be expressed in terms of the system parameters such as the coil turns ($N$ and $N_0$), currents ($i$ and $I_0$), radius $R$, gap width $g$, and the permeability of free space $\mu_0$.

reasoning_flow.step: List and assign symbols for the geometry and coil parameters from the Question: radius of the circular path R, gap width g, number of turns of the fixed coil N0 with DC current I0, number of turns of the concentrated (moving) coil N with current i, and the small displacement variable δ (note g << R).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: R, g, N0, I0, N, i, δ (with g << R)

reasoning_flow.step: Using the assumption that the high-permeability return path makes the magnetic field in the free-space gap purely radial and approximately uniform in r, write an expression for the magnetic field intensity H0 in the gap produced by the fixed N0-turn coil carrying current I0 (use Ampere's law around the gap of width g).

Write an expression for the magnetic field intensity H' in the gap produced by the concentrated N-turn coil carrying current i (treat its contribution in the same gap-crossing manner as a turn count N producing H' across g).

Using superposition, express the local magnetic flux density B in the gap as mu0 times the sum of the contributing H fields; then, because the concentrated coil experiences the average of the fields on its two sides, write the average B experienced by the concentrated coil.

State the total length of conductor (per turn) of the concentrated coil that encircles the magnetic gap and therefore experiences the radial B field (i.e., the effective circumferential length at radius R).

Write the Lorentz-force integral for the concentrated coil as the product of current i, number of turns N, the conductor length per turn 2πR, and the average magnetic flux density B_avg (direction giving the x-component).
Substitute B_avg = μ0(H0 + H')/2 and H0 = N0 I0 / g, H' = N i / g into the expression from Step 6 and simplify algebraically to obtain the force component F_x.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: F_x = 2π R N i μ0 (N0 I0 + (N i)/2) / g

reasoning_flow.step: Rearrange the expression from Step 7 into the form shown in the Reference Answer (collect factors and show the negative sign convention for force direction if chosen toward decreasing δ).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: F_x = -2π R μ0 N i (2 N0 I0 + N i) / (2 g)

reasoning_flow.step: State an alternative derivation method: write the differential co-energy expression dW = λ1 di1 + λ2 di2 + f_e dx relating coil flux linkages and mechanical work, and indicate that differentiating the co-energy with respect to displacement x at constant currents yields the same force.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: dW = λ1 di1 + λ2 di2 + f_e dx ; f_x = (dW/dx)_{I0,i}

reasoning_flow.step: Conclude the final expression for the force on the concentrated coil due to currents I0 and i and the listed parameters (present the final scalar formula for F_x).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: F_x = -2π R μ0 N i (2 N0 I0 + N i) / (2 g)

question.text:
A point on a thin plate is subjected to the two successive states of stress shown in Figure 2. Determine the resultant state of stress represented on the element oriented as shown on the right.
<image>
Figure 2: Addition of stress states

answer.text:
To begin, transform the first to stress states to the final orientation. This could be done using the following equations.

$$\begin{aligned}\tilde{\sigma_{11}}&=\frac{\sigma_{11}+\sigma_{22}}{2}+\frac{\sigma_{11}-\sigma_{22}}{2}cos(2\alpha)+\sigma_{12}sin(2\alpha)\\\\tilde{\sigma_{22}}&=\frac{\sigma_{11}+\sigma_{22}}{2}-\frac{\sigma_{11}-\sigma_{22}}{2}cos(2\alpha)+\sigma_{12}sin(2\alpha)\\\&\quad\tilde{\sigma_{12}}=-\frac{\sigma_{11}-\sigma_{22}}{2}sin(2\alpha)+\sigma_{12}cos(2\alpha)\end{aligned}$$

State 1
The given state is 
$$\begin{aligned}&\sigma_{11}=-350\ MPa\\&\sigma_{22}=-200\ MPa\\&\quad\sigma_{12}=0\ MPa\\&\quad\alpha_{1}=60^{\circ}\\ \end{aligned}$$
yields the transformed state 
$$\begin{aligned}{\tilde{\sigma_{11}}}&{{}=-237.5~M P a}\\ {\tilde{\sigma_{22}}}&{{}=-312.5~M P a}\\ {\tilde{\sigma_{12}}}&{{}=65.0~M P a}\end{aligned}$$

State 2
The given state is 
$$\begin{aligned}{\sigma_{11}}&{{}=0M P a}\\ {\sigma_{22}}&{{}=0M P a}\\ {\sigma_{12}}&{{}=58M P a}\\ {\alpha_{1}}&{{}=25^{\circ}}\end{aligned}$$
yields the transformed state 
$$\begin{array}{c}{{\tilde{\sigma_{11}}=44.4~M P a}}\\ {{\tilde{\sigma_{22}}=-44.4~M P a}}\\ {{\tilde{\sigma_{12}}=37.28~M P a}}\end{array}$$
The final step is to add the two transformed states 
$$\begin{aligned}{\tilde{\sigma_{11}}=-193.1~M P a}\\ {\tilde{\sigma_{22}}=-356.9~M P a}\\ {\tilde{\sigma_{12}}=102.0~M P a}\end{aligned}$$

The resultant normal stress component in the 2-direction (vertical axis) for the element oriented as shown, expected as a numerical value with units of MPa.

question.text:
Sketch the mechanism in a position that places it in static equilibrium. Base your drawing on an estimate of the displacements to within ± 20%. Assume the joints have negligable friction and that the pulleys and links have negiligable weight. The 10cm radius pulley is fixed with respect to the table and cannot rotate. You can assume the toothed belt will not slip. The extension springs are at their natural length. You may assume that the extension springs apply tension with the spring constant indicated but cannot apply any appreciable force in compression (they buckle). Briefly justify your solution with a couple equations, schematic diagrams, and/or a few sentences of explanation. Be sure to indicate clearly:
Whether you think the 3cm pulley rotates clockwise or counterclockwise 
Whether you think the arm connecting the pulleys rotates clockwise or counterclockwise 
Whether you think the arm 1 kg mass is higher or lower at equilibrium than at the starting position 
<image>

answer.text:
Consider a modest clockwise rotation of the arm, say 0.1 radian (6 deg). To maintain the proper position of the belt, tangent to both pulleys, the belt will have to wrap arong the top of the 10 cm rad pulley by 10cm*0.1 rad or 1cm. The kinematics of a belt drive demand that the same 1cm of belt feeds off of the 3cm pulley which requires a $\mathbf{1cm}/\mathbf{3cm}=0.33$ rad (18 deg) rotation of the 3cm dia pulley relative to the arm or 0.23 with respect to the fixed frame of reference.

This 0.1 deg rotation of the arm would also extend the left spring by 1.1cm leading to a 11N downward foce. The extension spring on the right side is placed in compression and we assume it buckles out of the way or othjerwise goes slack and applies negligable force.

Due to the small angles and generous ± 20%allowance for our estimate, we can linearize. We have a motion of the weight due to two factors:Rotation of the $\mathrm{arm}=\mathrm{0.1rad}*\mathrm{24cm}=\mathrm{2.4}$ cm downward 
Rotation of the 3cm_$\mathrm{pulley}=>0.33\ \mathrm{rad}*3\mathrm{cm}=1\mathrm{cm}$ 1upward 
So a net motion of 1.4 cm downward.
Kinematically, the pulley arrangement is similar to attaching the weight directly to the arm at 14 cm. I infer the guess of 0.1 rad of rotation was a bit low. I update my guess by 30% throughout to:
#### 0.13 rad (7.5deg) CW rotation of the arm 
0.23 rad (17deg) CCW rotation of the 3cm pulley net motion of 1.8 cm downward of the 1 kg mass as a check I see if the energy stored in the spring equals the energy lost by the mass mgh=0.18J 
$0.5*\mathbf{K}*\mathbf{x}\wedge2=0.5*10*(\mathbf{N}/\mathbf{cm})*(0.13*11\mathbf{cm})\wedge2=0.19$ close enough.

The calculated angular displacement of the 3cm pulley to reach static equilibrium, specifying both the magnitude (in radians or degrees) and the direction of rotation (clockwise or counterclockwise).
The vertical displacement of the 1 kg mass at equilibrium relative to its starting position, specifying both the distance (e.g., in cm) and the direction (higher/lower or upward/downward).

Estimate the gravitational potential energy lost by the 1 kg mass for the net vertical descent Δy_net (converted to meters): ΔE_grav = m * g * (Δy_net in m) with g = 9.8 m/s^2.
Compute the energy stored in the left spring for extension x_spring (in meters) using 0.5 * k_SI * x^2 where k_SI is k converted to N/m (10 N/cm = 1000 N/m).
Based on the mismatch between ΔE_grav and spring energy for θ_arm = 0.10 rad, scale θ_arm upward by 30% and compute the updated θ_arm (in radians).

Compute the net vertical motion of the 1 kg mass for θ_arm = 0.13 rad as downward positive: Δy_net = Δy_arm - Δy_pulley (in cm).
Convert Δy_net = 2.21 cm to meters and compute the gravitational energy released: ΔE_grav = m * g * (Δy_net in m) with m = 1 kg and g = 9.8 m/s^2.

Compute the spring energy for x_spring (in meters) using 0.5 * k_SI * x^2 with k_SI = 1000 N/m.
Compare ΔE_grav (from Step 22) and the spring energy (from Step 24) and state whether they are close enough to conclude approximate equilibrium within the ±20% tolerance.
Based on the sign of the computed rotations, state whether the 3 cm pulley rotates clockwise or counterclockwise with respect to the fixed frame for the positive θ_arm (clockwise) assumed.

Based on the positive net Δy_net (downward) computed for θ_arm = 0.13 rad, state whether the 1 kg mass is higher or lower at equilibrium than at the starting position.

question.text:
Possibly Useful Information. 
$$\begin{array}{ll}g=9.8N/kg&G=6.67\times10^{-11}N\cdot m^2/kg^2\\k=1/4\pi\epsilon_0=8.99\times10^9N\cdot m^2/C^2&k_{m}=\mu_0/4\pi=10^{-7}T\cdot m/A\\c=3.00\times10^8m/s&k_{B}=1.38\times10^{-23}J/K\\N_{A}=6.02\times10^{23}(mol)^{-1}&R=N_{A}k_{B}=8.31J/(mol\cdot K)\\\sigma=5.67\times10^{-8}J/(s\cdot m^2\cdot K^4)&e=1.602\times10^{-19}C\\1eV=1.602\times10^{-19}J&h=6.63\times10^{-34}J\cdot s=4.14\times10^{-15}eV\cdot s\\m_e=9.109\times10^{-31}kg=0.511MeV/c^2&(1+x)^n\approx1+nx for|x|\ll1\\\sin\theta\approx\theta-\frac{1}{6}\theta^3for|\theta|\ll1&\cos\theta\approx1-\frac{1}{2}\theta^2for|\theta|\ll1\end{array}$$
Two stars, each of mass M and separated by a distance $d,$ orbit about their center of mass. A planetoid of mass m $(m\ll M)$ moves along the axis of this system perpendicular to the orbital plane.

<image>

Let $T_{p}$ be the period of simple harmonic motion for the planetoid for small displacements from the center of mass along the z-axis, and let $T_{s}$ be the period of motion for the two stars. Determine the ratio $T_{p}/T_{s}$.

answer.text:
This problem starts out similar to the quarterfinal exam.The center of mass of the two stars is given by 
$$R=d/2.$$
The force of attraction between the two stars is given by 
$$F=G M^{2}/d^{2}$$
The orbital period T will be given by the centripetal force law 
$$F=M{\frac{4\pi^{2}R}{T^{2}}}=G{\frac{M^{2}}{d^{2}}}$$
or 
$$T_{s}=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{d^{3}}{2G M}}=4\pi\sqrt{\frac{R^{3}}{G M}}$$
The planetoid is a distance z above the plane. The distance to either star is then $\sqrt{R^{2}+z^{2}}$ Only the part of the force that is perpendicular to the plane survives the vector addition, sothe net force is given by 

$$F=2\frac{G m M}{R^{2}+z^{2}}\frac{z}{\sqrt{R^{2}+z^{2}}}.$$
This expression is exact. But if $z\ll d,$ then we can approximate this as 
$$F\approx2\frac{G m M}{R^{3}}z $$
This is a restoring force; the planetoid will execute simple harmonic oscillations with period 
$$T_{p}=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{m}{k}}$$
where k is the effective force constant, or 
$$T_{p}=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{R^{3}}{G M}}=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{d^{3}}{8G M}}$$
SO 
$$T_{p}/T_{s}=1/2$$

short_answer_description: The calculated ratio of the period of simple harmonic motion for the planetoid (T_p) to the orbital period of the two stars (T_s), expressed as a mathematical formula or constant in LaTeX format.

reasoning_flow.step: Express the distance R from the center of mass to each star in terms of the separation d for two equal masses.
