question.text: <image> Figure 1: A sheet of surface current at $x=0$ . What are the magnetic scalar potential and magnetic field distributions for $x<0$ |and ${\overline{{0<x}}}<s?$ Hint: The algebra will be greatly reduced if you use one of the following forms of the potential for the region $0<x<s$ I. sin(ky) cosh $k(x-s)$ 1 II.$\cos(k y)$ cosh $k(x-s)$ 1 III. sin $(k y)$ sinh $k(x-s)$ 1 IV.$\cos(k y)$ ,sinh $k(x-s)$ )

answer.text: $$\nabla^{2}\chi=0\Rightarrow\frac{\partial^{2}\chi}{\partial x^{2}}+\frac{\partial^{2}\chi}{\partial y^{2}}=0.$$ General solution is of the form $$\chi(x,y)=e^{k x}\left(C_{1}\operatorname{s i n}k y+C_{2}\operatorname{c o s}k y\right)+e^{-k x}\left(C_{3}\operatorname{s i n}k y+C_{4}\operatorname{c o s}k y\right)$$ For $x<0{\mathrm{~o n l y~}}e^{k x}$ term is relevant from B.C.II lim $\chi\to0;$ also from surface current boundary condition x→-∞ I only sin ky term is needed. Therefore,$\chi(x,y)=C_{1}e^{k x}$ sin ky for $x<0$ . For $x>0$ , we can work with the general solution in sinh, cosh, due to surface current condition in y, only sin ky term is needed; also due to boundary condition at $x=0,x=s$ we can use the form $$\begin{aligned}{}&{{}\chi(x,y)=A_{1}\operatorname{s i n}k y\operatorname{c o s h}(x-s)\quad0<x<s}\ {}&{{}\Rightarrow\chi(x,y)=\begin{cases}{C_{1}\operatorname{s i n}k y e^{k x}}&{x<0}\\ {A_{1}\operatorname{s i n}k y\operatorname{c o s h}k}&{0<x<s}\\ \end{cases}}\ {}&{{}\Rightarrow\overline{{H}}=-\nabla\chi=\begin{cases}{-C_{1}k e^{k x}(\operatorname{s i n}k y\bar{i}_{x}+\operatorname{c o s}k y\bar{i}_{y})}&{x<0}\\ {-A_{1}k(\operatorname{s i n}k y\operatorname{s i n}k(x-s)\bar{i}_{x}+\operatorname{c o s}k y\operatorname{c o s h}k(x-s)\bar{i}_{y})}&{0<x<s}\\ \end{cases}}\ {}&{{}\text{B.C.I I I}\Rightarrow H_{x}\Big|_{x=s}=0\Rightarrow\text{satisfied}}\ {}&{{}\text{B.C.I V}\Rightarrow\mu_{0}H_{x}\Big|_{x=0^{-}}=\mu H_{x}\Big|_{x=0^{+}}\Rightarrow-\mu_{0}C_{1}\Big/k=-\mu A_{1}\Big/k\operatorname{s i n}(-k s)\Rightarrow C_{1}=-\frac{\mu}{\mu_{0}}A_{1}\operatorname{s i n h}k s}\ {}&{{}\text{B.C.I}\Rightarrow H_{y}\Big|_{x=0^{+}}-H_{y}\Big|_{x=0^{-}}=K_{0}\operatorname{c o s}k y\Rightarrow-A_{1}k\operatorname{c o s h}(-k s)+C_{1}k=K_{0}}\ {}&{{}\Rightarrow-A_{1}\operatorname{c o s h}k s+C_{1}=\frac{K_{0}}{k}\Rightarrow-A_{1}\operatorname{c o s h}k s-\frac{\mu}{\mu_{0}}A_{1}\operatorname{s i n h}k s=\frac{K_{0}}{k}}\ {}&{{}\Rightarrow A_{1}(\mu_{0}\operatorname{c o s h}k s+\mu\operatorname{s i n h}k s)=-\frac{\mu_{0}K_{0}}{k}}\ {}&{{}\Rightarrow A_{1}=-\frac{\mu_{0}K_{0}}{k(\mu_{0}\operatorname{c o s h}k s+\mu\operatorname{s i n h}k s}}\ {}&{{}\Rightarrow C_{1}=\frac{\mu K_{0}\operatorname{s i n h}k s}{k(\mu_{0}\operatorname{c o s h}k s+\mu\operatorname{s i n h}k s)}}\ \end{aligned}$$ $$\begin{aligned}{}&{{}\Rightarrow\chi=\frac{K_{0}}{k(\mu_{0}\operatorname{c o s h}k s+\mu\operatorname{s i n h}k s)}\begin{cases}{\mu\operatorname{s i n h}k s e^{k x}\operatorname{s i n}k y}&{x<0}\\ {-\mu_{0}\operatorname{c o s h}k(x-s)\operatorname{s i n}k y}&{0<x<s}\\ \end{cases}}\ {}&{{}\overline{{H}}=\frac{K_{0}}{(\mu_{0}\operatorname{c o s h}k s+\mu\operatorname{s i n h}k s)}\begin{cases}{-\mu\operatorname{s i n h}k s e^{k x}(\operatorname{s i n}k y\overline{{i}}_{x}+\operatorname{c o s}k y\overline{{i}}_{y})}&{x<0}\\ {+\mu_{0}(\operatorname{s i n}k y\operatorname{s i n h}k(x-s)\overline{{i}}_{x}+\operatorname{c o s}k y\operatorname{c o s h}k(x-s)\overline{{i}}_{y})}&{0<x<s}\\ \end{cases}}\ \end{aligned}$$

short_answer_value: $H = \dfrac{K_0}{\mu_0\cosh(k s) + \mu\sinh(k s)}\begin{cases} -\mu\sinh(k s)e^{k x}\big(\sin(k y)\,\mathbf{i}_x + \cos(k y)\,\mathbf{i}_y\big), & x<0,\\[6pt] \mu_0\big(\sin(k y)\sinh(k(x-s))\,\mathbf{i}_x + \cos(k y)\cosh(k(x-s))\,\mathbf{i}_y\big), & 0<x<s. \end{cases}$
short_answer_description: The magnetic scalar potential distribution for the regions x < 0 and 0 < x < s. The answer should be a mathematical expression in LaTeX format, likely defined piecewise to describe the potential in both spatial regions involving parameters like current density, permeability, and geometric constants.

The magnetic field vector distribution for the regions x < 0 and 0 < x < s. The answer should be a mathematical expression in LaTeX format, representing the vector field (including direction components like i_x and i_y) and likely defined piecewise for the specified regions.

reasoning_flow.step: Write the differential equation satisfied by the magnetic scalar potential \(\chi(x,y)\) in source-free regions.
Write the general separable solution for \(\chi(x,y)\) using exponentials in x and sine/cosine in y (include both \(e^{kx}\) and \(e^{-kx}\) branches and both sin and cos in y).
Using the requirement that the potential remain finite as \(x\to-\infty\), determine which exponential term(s) in x survive for the region \(x<0\).

Using the fact that the surface current produces a magnetic field with a \(\cos ky\) dependence in y (given \(K_z(x=0,y)=K_0\cos ky\)), determine which y-dependence (sin or cos) the scalar potential must have so that \(H_y=-\partial\chi/\partial y\) contains \(\cos ky\).
Combine the results of Steps 3 and 4 to write the form of \(\chi(x,y)\) for the region \(x<0\).

Choose a convenient single-term form for \(\chi(x,y)\) in the region \(0<x<s\) that satisfies Laplace's equation and can satisfy boundary conditions at \(x=s\). (Pick one of the suggested cosh/sinh forms multiplied by \(\sin ky\).)
Compute the magnetic field \(\mathbf{H}=-\nabla\chi\) components \(H_x\) and \(H_y\) for the region \(x<0\) using the expression from Step 5.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: H_x=-C_1 k e^{k x}\sin ky, \; H_y=-C_1 k e^{k x}\cos ky \quad (x<0)

reasoning_flow.step: Compute the magnetic field \(\mathbf{H}=-\nabla\chi\) components \(H_x\) and \(H_y\) for the region \(0<x<s\) using the expression from Step 6.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: H_x=-A_1 k\sin ky\sinh k(x-s), \; H_y=-A_1 k\cos ky\cosh k(x-s) \quad (0<x<s)

reasoning_flow.step: Apply the boundary condition that \(H_x=0\) at the perfectly conducting plane at \(x=s\) and state the resulting condition (verify whether it imposes a constraint on the chosen form).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: H_x(x=s)=-A_1 k\sin ky\sinh 0=0, so the condition is satisfied (no extra constraint on A_1)

reasoning_flow.step: Apply the boundary condition of continuity of the tangential magnetic field component across \(x=0\) accounting for permeabilities: \(\mu_0 H_x|_{x=0^-}=\mu H_x|_{x=0^+}\). Write the algebraic relation between \(C_1\) and \(A_1\).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: -\mu_0 C_1 k = -\mu A_1 k\sinh(-k s) \Rightarrow C_1 = -\frac{\mu}{\mu_0} A_1 \sinh(-k s)

reasoning_flow.step: Simplify the relation from Step 10 using \(\sinh(-k s)=-\sinh k s\) to express \(C_1\) in terms of \(A_1\).

Apply the boundary condition for the discontinuity of the tangential \(H_y\) across the sheet at \(x=0\): \(H_y|_{0^+}-H_y|_{0^-}=K_0\cos ky\). Write the equation relating \(A_1\), \(C_1\), and \(K_0\).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: -A_1 k\cosh(-k s)+C_1 k = K_0 \Rightarrow -A_1 k\cosh k s + C_1 k = K_0

reasoning_flow.step: Substitute the expression for \(C_1\) from Step 11 into the equation from Step 12 and solve for \(A_1\).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: A_1=-\dfrac{\mu_0 K_0}{k(\mu_0\cosh k s+\mu\sinh k s)}

reasoning_flow.step: Use the value of \(A_1\) from Step 13 and the relation for \(C_1\) from Step 11 to write explicit expressions for \(C_1\) and for the scalar potential \(\chi(x,y)\) in both regions.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: C_1=\dfrac{\mu K_0\sinh k s}{k(\mu_0\cosh k s+\mu\sinh k s)},\\\chi(x,y)=\begin{cases} \dfrac{K_0}{k(\mu_0\cosh k s+\mu\sinh k s)}\,\mu\sinh k s\,e^{k x}\sin ky & x<0\\ -\dfrac{K_0}{k(\mu_0\cosh k s+\mu\sinh k s)}\,\mu_0\cosh k(x-s)\sin ky & 0<x<s\end{cases}

reasoning_flow.step: From the potentials in Step 14, write the final magnetic field \(\mathbf{H}=-\nabla\chi\) expressions for both regions in closed form prefactored by the common denominator.
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: \mathbf{H}=\dfrac{K_0}{(\mu_0\cosh k s+\mu\sinh k s)}\begin{cases} -\mu\sinh k s\,e^{k x}(\sin ky\,\hat{i}_x+\cos ky\,\hat{i}_y) & x<0 \\ \mu_0(\sin ky\sinh k(x-s)\,\hat{i}_x+\cos ky\cosh k(x-s)\,\hat{i}_y) & 0<x<s\end{cases}

question.text: The imaging system shown below is illuminated by an on-axis plane wave at wavelength $\lambda=1\mu\mathrm{m}$ . Lenses L1, L2 are identical with sufficiently large aperture and focal length $f=10\mathrm{c m}$ . <image> The pupil mask M has aperture $a=1\mathrm{c m}$ . Inside the aperture there is a piece of glass of refractive index $n=1.5$ . The glass has been partially etched to form a step of height $s=1\mu\mathrm{m}$ , and the step is precisely aligned with the optical axis, as shown. With the transparency $g_{\mathrm{t}}(x)$ in place at the object plane, the system is illuminated with a plane wave on-axis. What is the optical field at the image plane?

answer.text: The optical field at the image plane can be obtained from two ways: 1) direct forward computation or 2) frequency analysis. [1] direct forward computation: The incident field to the Fourier plane is $$\mathfrak{F}\left[\cos\left(2\pi rac{x}{\Lambda}ight)ight]_{ rac{x^{\prime\prime}}{\lambda f}}= rac{1}{2}\delta\left( rac{x^{\prime\prime}}{\lambda f}- rac{1}{\Lambda}ight)+ rac{1}{2}\delta\left( rac{x^{\prime\prime}}{\lambda f}+ rac{1}{\Lambda}ight)= rac{1}{2}\delta(x^{\prime\prime}-5\;\mathrm{m m})+ rac{1}{2}\delta(x^{\prime\prime}+5\;\mathrm{m m}).$$ Since the width of the pupil is 10 mm, both delta functions pass through the pupil with a phase delay. The field immediately after the phase mask is $$ rac{1}{2}\delta(x^{\prime\prime}-5)+e^{i\pi} rac{1}{2}\delta(x^{\prime\prime}+5).= rac{1}{2}\delta(x^{\prime\prime}-5)- rac{1}{2}\delta(x^{\prime\prime}+5).$$ The field at the image plane is $$ egin{align*}\mathfrak{F}\left[ rac{1}{2}\delta(x''-5)- rac{1}{2}\delta(x''+5)ight]_{ rac{x'}{\lambda f}}=i\mathfrak{F}\left[ rac{1}{2i}\delta(x''-5)- rac{1}{2i}\delta(x''+5)ight]_{ rac{x'}{\lambda f}}\quad\=i\sin\left(2\pi rac{1}{5} rac{x'}{\lambda f}ight)=i\sin\left(2\pi rac{x'}{20\ \mu\mathrm{m}}ight).\end{align*}$$ [2] frequency analysis: The Fourier transform of the output field is a multiplication of the Fourier transform of the input field and the ATF. Since the Fourier transform of the input signal is $ egin{array}{r}{ rac{1}{2}\delta\left(u- rac{1}{20~\mu\mathrm{m}}ight)+ rac{1}{2}\delta\left(u+ rac{1}{20~\mu\mathrm{m}}ight)}\end{array}$ , the FT of the output field is $$ rac{1}{2}\delta\left(u- rac{1}{20\mu\mathrm{m}}ight)- rac{1}{2}\delta\left(u+ rac{1}{20\mu\mathrm{m}}ight),$$ and the output field is i sin $ egin{array}{r}{\left(2\pi rac{x^{\prime}}{20~\mu\mathrm{m}}ight)}\end{array}$

short_answer_description: The mathematical expression representing the optical field distribution at the image plane, expressed as a function of the spatial coordinate (e.g., x').

reasoning_flow.step: State the form of the object-plane transparency g_t(x) used in the reference solution (expressed symbolically with period Λ).
Compute the Fourier transform (spatial-frequency representation) of g_t(x)=cos(2π x/Λ) and express it as impulses in frequency u (cycles per unit length).
Write the coordinate mapping between spatial frequency u and transverse coordinate in the Fourier (pupil) plane x^{\prime\prime} for a lens of focal length f and illumination wavelength λ.
Using x^{\prime\prime}=λ f u and the delta impulses in frequency from Step 2, express the incident field in the Fourier plane as impulses located at x^{\prime\prime}=±λ f /Λ.
Substitute λ=1\;\mu\mathrm{m} and f=10\;\mathrm{cm} into the expression λ f / Λ and evaluate numerically for Λ=20\;\mu\mathrm{m} to find the impulse locations x^{\prime\prime} in mm.
Using the pupil width a=1\;\mathrm{cm}, determine whether both impulses at x^{\prime\prime}=\pm5\;\mathrm{mm} pass through the pupil (i.e., lie within ±a/2).

Compute the phase delay introduced by the glass step of height s and refractive index n (relative to surrounding), at wavelength λ; express the phase as φ=2π(n-1)s/λ and evaluate for n=1.5, s=1\;\mu\mathrm{m}, λ=1\;\mu\mathrm{m}.
Convert the phase φ from Step 7 into the multiplicative complex transmission factor e^{iφ} of the stepped region.

Apply the phase factor from Step 8 to the impulse at x^{\prime\prime}=+5\;\mathrm{mm} or x^{\prime\prime}=-5\;\mathrm{mm} as appropriate based on the step alignment shown (step aligned on-axis produces opposite phase on one side); write the field after the phase mask in the Fourier plane.

Compute the inverse Fourier transform (from Fourier-plane coordinate x^{\prime\prime} to image-plane coordinate x^{\prime}) of the field composed of the two weighted impulses at ±5 mm and express the image-plane field in terms of x^{\prime}, λ, and f.
Simplify the argument 2π(5 mm)/(λ f) using λ=1\;\mu\mathrm{m} and f=10\;\mathrm{cm} to get the sinusoid period in terms of x^{\prime}; express the result as sinusoid with period 20\;\mu\mathrm{m}.

question.text: In the early twenties, passenger cars did not have electric starters. The driver had to use a crank to start the engine. The crank is a solid rod of radius r and the geometry of the crank is shown below. Define the equivalent stress by $\overline{{\sigma}}=\sqrt{\sigma^{3}+3\tau^{2}}$ where \sigma sigma is the stress produced by bending and \tau is the shear stress due to torsion. <image> Find the relationship between the maximum equivalent stress in the crank and the magnitude of the crank load P. (Use the principle of superposition)

answer.text:
a)Determine the magnitude of the load P causing first yield in the mostly stressed point on the crank 
We will use the Mises yield condition which simplified to 
$$\sigma_{o}^{2}=\sigma^{2}+3\tau^{2}$$ 
We calculate \sigma from the moment, and from the torsion 
$$\begin{aligned}&\sigma=\frac{M_{r}}{I}where\quad I=\frac{\pi r^{4}}{4}\\&\tau=\frac{T_{r}}{J}where\quad J=\frac{\pi r^{4}}{2}\\ \end{aligned}$$ 
Because we are asked to find P causing first yield at the maximum stressed point, we need to find $\sigma_{\mathrm{m a x}}$ and $\tau_{\mathrm{m a x}}$ 
From physics we can see that the $M_{\mathrm{m a x}}$ and $T_{\mathrm{m a x}}$ will occur at the support 
$$\begin{aligned}M_{\max}=Pl\Rightarrow\sigma_{\max}=\frac{M_{\max}r}{I}=\frac{PR r}{\pi r^{4}/4}\\ T_{\max}=PR\Rightarrow\tau=\frac{T_{\max}r}{J}=\frac{PR r}{\pi r^{4}/2}\\ \left|\sigma_{\max}=\frac{4}{\pi}\frac{P l}{r^{3}}\right|\\ \tau_{\max}=\frac{2}{\pi}\frac{PR}{r^{3}}\\ \left|\sigma_{o}\right.^{2}=\sigma_{\max}^{2}+3\tau_{\max}^{2}\\ =\left(\frac{4}{\pi}\frac{P l}{r^{3}}\right)^{2}+3\left(\frac{2}{\pi}\frac{PR}{r^{3}}\right)^{2}\\ \left|\sigma_{o}\right.^{2}=\frac{4}{\pi^{2}r^{6}}P^{2}\left(4l^{2}+3R^{2}\right)\end{aligned}$$

short_answer_description: The mathematical expression representing the square of the maximum equivalent stress ($\overline{\sigma}^2$) in the crank rod. The formula should be in LaTeX format and expressed in terms of the crank load $P$, the rod radius $r$, and the geometric dimensions $l$ and $R$.

reasoning_flow.step: State the given equivalent (Mises-type) stress relation in squared form relating the equivalent stress to bending stress \sigma and shear stress \tau.
Express the bending moment M_max at the fixed support in terms of the applied load P and the lever arm length l.
Express the torsional moment T_max at the fixed support in terms of the applied load P and the crank offset R.
Write the area moment of inertia I for a solid circular shaft of cross-section radius r.
Write the polar moment of inertia J for a solid circular shaft of cross-section radius r.
Using M_{\max}, I and the outer fiber distance r, compute the maximum bending stress \sigma_{\max} at the support.
Using T_{\max}, J and the outer fiber distance r, compute the maximum shear stress (from torsion) \tau_{\max} at the support.
Substitute \sigma_{\max} and \tau_{\max} from Steps 6 and 7 into the squared equivalent stress relation from Step 1 and simplify to express \sigma_{o}^{2} as a function of P, r, l, and R.
Rearrange the expression from Step 8 to solve for the load magnitude P that produces a given equivalent stress \sigma_{o}.

question.text: <image> Figure 9: Two lossy dielectrics Two lossy dielectrics with respective dielectric permittivities $\epsilon_{1}$ and $\epsilon_{2}$ and respective ohmic conductivities $\sigma_{1}$ and $\sigma_{2}$ are superposed within a short-circuited capacitor. At $t=0$ there is a free surface charge density of $\sigma_{s0}\frac{C}{m^{2}}$ ·on the interface between the dielectrics. Neglect fringing field effects. The free volume charge density at time $t=0$ is zero in both dielectrics. Find the short circuit current $i(t)$ that flows in the wire short-circuiting the two electrodes as a function of time.

answer.text: Solution: $$\begin{aligned}{\frac{d i(t)}{l d}}&{{}=\sigma_{2}E_{2}+\epsilon_{2}\frac{d E_{2}}{d t}=\sigma_{1}E_{1}+\epsilon_{1}\frac{d E_{1}}{d t}}\\ {}&{{}=\left(\sigma_{1}-\frac{\epsilon_{1}}{\tau}\right)E_{1}}\\ {}&{{}=\left(\sigma_{1}-\frac{\epsilon_{1}}{\left(\epsilon_{1}b+\sigma_{2}a\right)}\left(\sigma_{1}b+\sigma_{2}a\right)\right)E_{1}}\\ {}&{{}=\left(\frac{\sigma_{\ddagger}\epsilon_{\ddagger}b+\sigma_{1}\epsilon_{2}a-\epsilon_{\ddagger}\sigma_{\ddagger}b-\epsilon_{1}\sigma_{2}a}{\epsilon_{1}b+\epsilon_{2}a}\right)E_{1}}\\ {}&{{}=\frac{a(\sigma_{1}\epsilon_{2}-\epsilon_{1}\sigma_{2})}{(\epsilon_{1}b+\epsilon_{2}a)^{2}}\sigma_{s0}b e^{-\frac{t}{\tau}}}\\ {i(t)}&{{}=\frac{a b\sigma_{s0}(\sigma_{1}\epsilon_{2}-\epsilon_{1}\sigma_{2})l d}{(\epsilon_{1}b+\epsilon_{2}a)^{2}}e^{-\frac{t}{\tau}}}\\ \end{aligned}$$

short_answer_description: The mathematical expression for the short-circuit current i(t) flowing in the wire connecting the two electrodes as a function of time. The answer should be a formula in LaTeX format, expressed in terms of the given dielectric properties (permittivities \epsilon_{1}, \epsilon_{2} and conductivities \sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}), the initial surface charge density \sigma_{s0}, time t, and relevant geometric dimensions of the capacitor.

reasoning_flow.step: Write the constitutive relation for the current density j in a lossy dielectric in terms of its conductivity and permittivity and the local electric field E(t).

Using Step 1, write the expressions for the current densities j1 and j2 in the upper dielectric (with \epsilon_1, \sigma_1 and field E_1) and the lower dielectric (with \epsilon_2, \sigma_2 and field E_2).
State the condition on current densities at the interface (continuity of conduction plus displacement current) for the short-circuited system (neglecting lateral leakage): relate j_1 and j_2.
Write the D-field (electric displacement) discontinuity boundary condition at the interface relating the surface free charge density \sigma_s(t) to the normal fields E_1 and E_2.

Write the constraint on E_1 and E_2 coming from the fact that the two electrodes are short-circuited (net potential difference across both layers is zero): express this voltage relation using thicknesses a (upper) and b (lower).
Use the relation from Step 5 to express E_2 in terms of E_1 and the layer thicknesses a and b.
Substitute the expression for E_2 from Step 6 into the D discontinuity equation from Step 4 and solve for E_1 in terms of \sigma_s(t), a, b, \epsilon_1, and \epsilon_2.
Differentiate the E_1 expression from Step 7 with respect to time to express dE_1/dt in terms of d\sigma_s/dt and the geometric/permittivity combination (do not substitute any other relations yet).

Write the interface charge conservation relation that links the time derivative of the surface charge density to the normal current density j at the interface (take current leaving the surface as positive sign convention).

Using Step 2 for j_1 and the equality j_1 = j_2 from Step 3, pick the expression j = j_1 = \sigma_1 E_1 + \epsilon_1 dE_1/dt and substitute dE_1/dt from Step 8 to obtain j in terms of E_1 and d\sigma_s/dt (do not eliminate d\sigma_s/dt yet).

Replace \dfrac{d\sigma_s}{dt} in the expression from Step 10 using the conservation relation from Step 9 (\dfrac{d\sigma_s}{dt} = -j) and solve algebraically for j in terms of E_1 and the parameters a,b,\epsilon_i,\sigma_i (isolate j).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: j\left(1+\dfrac{\epsilon_1 b}{\epsilon_1 b+\epsilon_2 a}\right)=\sigma_1 E_1\quad\Rightarrow\quad j=\dfrac{\sigma_1(\epsilon_1 b+\epsilon_2 a)}{\epsilon_1 b+\epsilon_2 a+\epsilon_1 b}\,E_1

reasoning_flow.step: Simplify the algebraic factor in the expression from Step 11 to obtain j in the compact form j = (\sigma_1 - \dfrac{\epsilon_1}{\tau})E_1 and identify the expression for the time constant \tau in terms of a,b,\epsilon_i,\sigma_i by comparing coefficients (derive \tau).

Using the E_1 expression from Step 7 and the factor identity from Step 12, substitute E_1 into j = (\sigma_1 - \dfrac{\epsilon_1}{\tau})E_1 and simplify to express j solely in terms of \sigma_s(t), a,b,\epsilon_i,\sigma_i (perform algebraic simplification).
Solve the first-order ODE for \sigma_s(t) using the time constant \tau from Step 12 and initial condition \sigma_s(0)=\sigma_{s0}.
Substitute the solution for \sigma_s(t) from Step 14 into the expression for j from Step 13 to obtain j(t) as an explicit function of time.
Given the plate area is l\times d, convert the current density j(t) found in Step 15 into the total short-circuit current i(t) by multiplying by the area.

question.text: Steady State Operation This problem concerns a large turbine generator with rating parameters: Rating P 907 MVA Terminal Voltage VB 24 kV, 1-1, RMS Inertial Constant H 4.0S The electrical equivalent circuits for the direct- and quadrature axes are shown in Figure 1.All values called out in this figure are in per-unit. <image> Figure 1: Direct and Quadrature Axis Equivalent Circuits The machine is operated at rated kVA and at a power factor of 85% lagging (over-excited).In preparation for a simulation it is necessary to find all of the internal fluxes and currents.Do this: Find numerical values for direct- and quadrature- axis voltage and for each of the five internal fl uxes.

answer.text: The machine is operated at rated kVA and at a power factor of 85% lagging (over-excited).This means that the real component of current is $i_{r}=.85$ per-unit and the imaginary component of current is $i_{i}=-\sqrt{1-.85^{2}}$ . If we note the actual current to be $i_{a}=i_{r}+j i_{i}$ , we can find a point on the quadrature axis: $$e_{1}=v_{t}+(r_{a}+j x_{q})i_{a}$$ This allows us to find the torque angle (just the angle of $e_{1})$ , and then to construct the two components of current: $$ egin{array}{r c l}{{i_{d}}}&{{=}}&{{i_{a}\sin\delta-\psi}}\ {{i_{q}}}&{{=}}&{{i_{a}\cos\delta-\psi}}\end{array}$$ The voltage seen by the reactive parts of the machine is inside of the stator resistance: $$v_{a}=v_{t}+r_{a}i_{a}$$ and we may express this as: $$v_{a}=|v_{a}|\angle v_{a}=|v_{a}|e^{j	heta_{a}}$$ Voltage components are: $$ egin{array}{r l r}{v_{q}}&{=}&{|v_{a}|\cos{(\delta+	heta_{a})}}\ {v_{d}}&{=}&{|v_{a}|\sin{(\delta+	heta_{a})}.}\end{array}$$ Now, the d- and q- axis fluxes are simply: $$ egin{array}{r c l}{{\psi_{d}}}&{{=}}&{{v_{q}}}\ {{\psi_{q}}}&{{=}}&{{-v_{d}}}\end{array}$$ Air-gap fluxes are simply terminal fluxes plus flux produced by the stator leakeage: $$ egin{array}{r l r}{\psi_{a d}}&{=\psi_{k d}=}&{\psi_{d}+x_{a l}i_{d}}\ {\psi_{a q}}&{=\psi_{k q}=}&{\psi_{q}+x_{a l}i_{q}}\end{array}$$ Field flux is air-gap flux on the d- axis plus flux across the field leakage inductance: $$\psi_{f}=\psi_{d}+x_{f l}i_{f}$$ where, for the steady state condition: $$i_{f}= rac{e_{a}}{x_{a d}}$$ This has all been built into a MATLAB script which is appended and which yields the following rendition of numbers: Problem Set 4,Part 1 Terminal Voltage =1 Terminal Current =0.85+ j -0.526783Terminal Current Magnitude = 1Terminal Current Angle =-0.554811radians =-31.7883deg Torque Angle =0.68942radians =39.5009deg Torque Angle =0.68942PF angle =-0.554811Voltage behind sync reactance eq =2.85721Voltage Behind Resistance =1.00493+j -0.00305534D-axis voltage =0.641583Q-Axis voltage =0.773476Terminal Flux psid =0.773476psiq =-0.641583Air-Gap Flux psiad =0.868191psiaq =-0.609504Field Current if =1.36057Field Flux psif =1.43963Torque by generation plus loss =0.8558Torque by flux times current 0.8558Audit Difference = 1.11022e-16

short_answer_description: The numerical value for the direct-axis component of the terminal voltage (v_d) in per-unit.
The numerical value for the quadrature-axis component of the terminal voltage (v_q) in per-unit.
The numerical value for the total direct-axis stator flux linkage (psi_d) in per-unit.

question.text:
A current 
$$I(t)=\left\{\begin{aligned}&I_{0}&&t>0\\ &0&&t<0\end{aligned}\right.$$
flows through a circuit as shown below. At the origin, find the retarded vector potential $\mathbf{A}(t)$ and electric field $\mathbf{E}(t)$ for all time t.
<image>

answer.text:
## 7 ) Case $t<a/c{:}$
The observer at the origin hasn't received news of the flowing current. Therefore, all the fields are zero.

## Case $a/c<t<b/c;$
For a filamentary current, the retarded vector potential is 
$$\mathbf{A}(\mathbf{r},t)={\frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi}}\int{\frac{\mathbf{J}(\mathbf{r}^{\prime},t_{r})}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}|}}d V^{\prime}={\frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi}}\int{\frac{I[t_{r}(\mathbf{r}^{\prime})]}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}|}}d\mathbf{s}^{\prime}$$
In terms of the source location, the current is 
$$I[t_{r}(\mathbf{r}^{\prime})]=\left\{\begin{aligned}{}&{{}I_{0}}&{}&{{}t>0}\\ &{{}0}&{}&{{}\mathrm{e l s e w h e r e}}\end{aligned}\right.=\left\{\begin{aligned}{}&{{}I_{0}}&{}&{{}|\mathbf{r}^{\prime}|<c t}\\ &{{}0}&{}&{{}\mathrm{e l s e w h e r e}}\end{aligned}\right.$$
Within this time range, the small semicircle always gives its full contribution,
$$\mathbf{A}_{a}(t)=\frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi}\frac{I_{0}}{a}\int_{a}d\mathbf{s}^{\prime}=\frac{\mu_{0}I_{0}}{4\pi a}(2a\mathbf{\hat{x}})=\frac{\mu_{0}I_{0}}{2\pi}\mathbf{\hat{x}}.$$
The two straight segments, each giving equal contributions, yield a total 
$$\mathbf{A}_{a b}(t)=2\frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi}I_{0}\mathbf{\hat{x}}\int_{a}^{c t}\frac{d x^{\prime}}{x^{\prime}}=\frac{\mu_{0}I_{0}}{2\pi}\ln\left(\frac{c t}{a}\right)\mathbf{\hat{x}}$$
The large semicircle doesn't contribute in this time range. Therefore, the vector potential at the origin is 
$$\left[\mathbf{A}(t)=\frac{\mu_{0}I_{0}}{2\pi}\left[1+\ln\left(\frac{c t}{a}\right)\right]\mathbf{\hat{x}}\right]$$
Because the wire remains neutral, the scalar potential is always zero, and the electric field at the origin is 
$$\boxed{\mathbf{E}(t)=-\frac{\partial\mathbf{A}}{\partial t}=-\frac{\mu_{0}I_{0}}{2\pi t}\mathbf{\hat{x}}}$$

## Case $b/c<t;$
In this time range, the entire loop gives its full contribution.

The large semicircle's contribution,
$$\mathbf{A}_{b}(t)=\frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi}\frac{I_{0}}{b}\int_{b}d\mathbf{s}^{\prime}=\frac{\mu_{0}I_{0}}{4\pi b}(-2b\mathbf{\hat{x}})=-\frac{\mu_{0}I_{0}}{2\pi}\mathbf{\hat{x}},$$
cancels the small semicircle's contribution.

Then, the vector potential at the origin is 
$$\boxed{\mathbf{A}(t)=\frac{\mu_{0}I_{0}}{2\pi}\ln\left(\frac{b}{a}\right)\mathbf{\hat{x}}}$$
The vector potential is now time-independent, so 
$$\boxed{\mathbf{E}(t)=-{\frac{\partial\mathbf{A}}{\partial t}}=0}$$

Case $\mathbf{\nabla}t=\mathbf{\boldsymbol{a}}/c\mathbf{:}$
At this time, the vector potential abruptly jumps from zero to 
$$\mathbf{A}_{0}=\frac{\mu_{0}I_{0}}{2\pi}\mathbf{\hat{x}}.$$
We can express this mathematically using the unit step function,
$$\mathbf{A}(t)=\mathbf{A}_{0}\;\theta(t-a/c)$$
Then, in the neighborhood of $t=a/c$ ,using $d\theta/d x=\delta(x)$ 
$$\mathbf{E}(t)=-\frac{\partial\mathbf{A}}{\partial t}=-\mathbf{A}_{0}\delta(t-a/c)=\boxed{-\hat{\mathbf{x}}\frac{\mu_{0}I_{0}}{2\pi}\delta(t-a/c)}$$
Realistically, the loop has a self-inductance so that the current can not be discontinuous. Furthermore, the wire will have a finite cross-section. Therefore, in reality, at the origin, we would briefly see a large, but finite, electric field. However, we can reasonably say what impulse a charge q at the origin at time $t=a/c$ would receive,
$$\Delta\mathbf{p}=\int\mathbf{F}d t=\int q\mathbf{E}d t=-\mathbf{\hat{x}}\frac{\mu_{0}I_{0}q}{2\pi}$$

Case $\mathbf{\nabla}\mathbf{t}=\mathbf{b}/c\mathbf{:}$
At this time, the vector potential abruptly jumps back down, undoing the previous jump. Therefore, in the neighborhood of $t=b/c$ 
$$\mathbf{E}(t)=-\frac{\partial\mathbf{A}}{\partial t}=+\mathbf{A}_{0}\delta(t-b/c)=\boxed{+\mathbf{\hat{x}}\frac{\mu_{0}I_{0}}{2\pi}\delta(t-b/c)}$$

question.text: Consider the steam-injected gas turbine cycle shown in the Figure 2. Air at 298 K and 100 kPa nters the compressor. The pressure ratio is 9. The turbine inlet temperature is 1423 K. The flue gases leaving the turbine flow through a heat recovery steam generator (HRSG) which produces superheated steam at 700 K. The exhaust gases leave the HRSG at 400 K. Water at 298K and 100 kPa is pumped to the HRSG. No water recycling from the flue gas is considered. The compressor, turbine and pump operate with isentropic efficiency of 90%, 85% and 70%, respectively. The fuel burnt in the combustor is methane with LHV of 50.05 MJ/kg. The properties of the fl ow at states 3,4 and 5 may be modeled as an idea gas of air + steam mixture. <image> Figure 2 - Steam injected gas turbine cycle The amount of steam injection and fuel consumption per unit mass of the air.

answer.text:
We start by fixing some of the states specified before proceeding. While state 1 is given,state 2 can be fixed by determining the temperature at the outlet of the compressor given the inlet conditions and the compression ratio. Hence, using the result from Chapter 5:
$$T_{2}=T_{1}\left(1+\frac{1}{\eta_{c}}\left[\left(r_{p}\right)^{\frac{k-1}{k}}-1\right]\right)=298\left(1+\frac{1}{0.9}\left[\left(9\right)^{\frac{1.39-1}{1.39}}-1\right]\right)=580.2\;\mathrm{K}$$
Similarly,for the turbine:
$$T_{4}=T_{3}\left(1-\eta_{T}\left[1-\left(r_{p}\right)^{\frac{1-k}{k}}\right]\right)=1423\left(1-0.85\left[1-\left(9\right)^{\frac{-0.29}{1.29}}\right]\right)=951.53K $$
Furthermore, the conditions at the inlet and exit of the pump are defined using EES such that:
$$h_{6}=104.3\:\mathrm{k J/k g}\quad\mathrm{a n d}\quad v_{6}=0.001\:\mathrm{m}^{3}/\mathrm{k g}$$
As an incompressible fluid, the enthalpy at the pump exit is calculated as follows:
$$h_{7s}=h_{6}+v(p_{7}-p_{6})=104.3+0.001\times(900-100)=105.1kJ/kg $$
$$h_{7}=h_{6}+\frac{h_{7s}-h_{6}}{0.7}=104.3+\frac{0.8}{0.7}=105.4\mathrm{~kJ/kg}$$
Next, we apply the first law across the combustor to arrive at the expression below. Note that the flow at the exit in state 3 is modeled as an ideal gas mixture of $\mathsf{a i r}+\mathsf{s t e a m}$ 
$$\sum_{r e a c t a n t s}H_{i}=\sum_{p r o d u c t s}H_{i}$$
$$\dot{m}_{f,i n}L H V_{f,i n}+\dot{m}_{a i r,i n}h_{a i r,i n}+\dot{m}_{s,i n}h_{s,i n}=\dot{m}_{a i r,o u t}h_{a i r,o u t}+\dot{m}_{s,o u t}h_{s,o u t}$$
$$\dot{m}_{f,i n}L H V_{f,i n}+\dot{m}_{a i r,2}h_{a i r,2}+\dot{m}_{s,8}h_{s,8}=\dot{m}_{a i r,3}h_{a i r,3}+\dot{m}_{s,3}h_{s,3}$$
Dividing by the inlet air mass flow rate, using the hint provided, and applying mass balance:
$$\alpha\cdot LHV_{f,in}+h_{air,2}+\beta\cdot h_{s,8}=(1+\alpha)h_{air,3}+\beta h_{s,3}$$
where α is the fuel-to-air mass ratio,$\beta$ is the steam-to-air mass ratio.
Calculating the enthalpies using EES:
$$h_{a i r,2}=586.6\:\mathrm{k J/k g},\quad h_{a i r,3}=1543\:\mathrm{k J/k g},\quad h_{s,3}=5021\:\mathrm{k J/k g},\quad h_{s,8}=3323\:\mathrm{k J/k g}$$
Applying the first law to the HRSG, we arrive at the following:
$$\sum_{i n}H_{i}=\sum_{o u t}H_{i}.$$
$$\dot{m}_{a i r.4}h_{a i r.4}+\dot{m}_{s.4}h_{s.4}+\dot{m}_{7}h_{7}=\dot{m}_{a i r.5}h_{a i r.5}+\dot{m}_{s.5}h_{s.5}+\dot{m}_{8}h_{8}$$
Diving by the inlet air mass flow rate and rearranging, we arrive at:
$$\begin{array}{r}{\big(1+\alpha\big)\big(h_{a i r,4}-h_{a i r,5}\big)+\beta\big(h_{s,4}-h_{s,5}\big)=\beta\big(h_{8}-h_{7}\big)}\end{array}$$
The enthalpies are calculated to be:
$$\begin{array}{r l}{h_{a i r,4}=991.3\:\mathrm{k J/k g},\quad}&{h_{a i r,5}=401.3\:\mathrm{k J/k g},\quad\:h_{s,4}=3880\:\mathrm{k J/k g},\\ }&{\quad h_{s,5}=2730\:\mathrm{k J/k g}}\end{array}$$
Solving the enthalpy balance equations of the combustor and HRSG yield:
$$\alpha=0.03\quad\mathsf{a n d}\quad\beta=0.2939$$

question.text:
In modern physics, the energetics of nuclei and their reactions is described in terms of masses. For example, if a nucleus (with zero velocity) is in an excited state with energy $E_{_{e x c}}$ above the ground state, its mass is $m=m_{0}+E_{e x c}/c^{2}$ ,where $m_{0}$ is its mass in the ground state at rest. The nuclear reaction $^{16}\mathrm{O}+^{54}\mathrm{F e}\rightarrow^{12}\mathrm{C}+^{58}\mathrm{N i}$ is an example of the so-called "transfer reactions",in which a part of one nucleus ("cluster") is transferred to the other (see Fig.).In our example the transferred part is a 4He-cluster (α -particle). The transfer reactions occur with maximum probability if the velocity of the projectile-like reaction product (in our case:$^{12}\mathsf{C})$ is equal both in magnitude and directionto the velocity of projectile in our case:$^{16}0\rangle$ .Thetaret Fe is initially at rest.In thereaction,Ni is excited into oneof its higher-lyig states. Find the excitation energy of that state (and express it units of MeV) if the kinetic energy of the projectile $^{16}0$ is 50 MeV. The speed of light is $c=3\cdot10^{8}\mathrm{m/s}$ .
1.$\mathsf{M}(^{16}\mathrm{O})$15.99491 a.m.u.
2.$\mathsf{M}({}^{54}\mathsf{F e})$53.93962 a.m.u.
3.$\overline{{\mathsf{M}(^{12}\mathsf{C})}}$12.00000 a.m.u.
4.$\overline{{\mathsf{M}(^{58}\mathsf{N i})}}$57.93535 a.m.u.
Table 1. The rest masses of the reactants in their ground states. $1\mathrm{a.m.u.}=1.6605\cdot10^{-27}\mathrm{k g}$

answer.text: This part can be solved by using either non-relativistic or relativistic kinematics. Non-relativistic solution First one has to find the amount of mass transferred to energy in the reaction (or the energy equivalent, so-called Q-value): ${\left[\begin{array}{l}{\Delta m={\mathrm{(t o t a l m a s s)}}_{\mathrm{a f f e r~r e a c i o n}}-{\mathrm{(t o t a l m a s s)}}_{\mathrm{b e f o r~r e a c i o n}}=}\\ {\quad=(57.93535+12.000000){\mathrm{a.m.u.}}-(53.93962+15.99491){\mathrm{a.m.u.}}=}\\ {\quad=0.00082{\mathrm{a.m.u.}}=}\\ {\quad=1.3616\cdot10^{-30}{\mathrm{k g.}}}\end{array}\right]}$ Using the Einstein formula for equivalence of mass and energy, we get: $\boxed{\begin{array}{r l r}{Q=}&{{}\left(\mathrm{t o t a l k i n e t i c~e n e r g y}\right)_{\mathrm{s f l e r~r e a c t i o n}}-\left(\mathrm{t o t a l k i n e t i c~e n e r g y}\right)_{\mathrm{b e f o r~r e a c t i o n}}=}&{\quad(20)}\\ &{=-\Delta m\cdot c^{2}=}\\ &{=-1.3616\cdot10^{-30}\cdot299792458^{2}=-1.2237\cdot10^{-13}\mathrm{J}}\end{array}}$ Taking into account that 1 MeV is equal to $1.602\cdot10^{-13}$ J, we get: $Q=-1.2237\cdot10^{-13}/1.602\cdot10^{-13}=-0.761MeV$ (21) This exercise is now solved using the laws of conservation of energy and momentum. The latter gives (we are interested only for the case when $^{12}\mathrm{C}$ and $^{16}0$ are having the same direction so we don't need to use vectors): (22) $m(^{16}\mathrm{O})v(^{16}\mathrm{O})=m(^{12}\mathrm{C})v(^{12}\mathrm{C})+m(^{58}\mathrm{Ni})v(^{58}\mathrm{Ni})$ while the conservation of energy gives: $E_{k}(^{16}\mathrm{O})+Q=E_{k}(^{12}\mathrm{C})+E_{k}(^{58}\mathrm{Ni})+E_{x}(^{58}\mathrm{Ni})$ (23) where $E_{x}({}^{58}\mathrm{N i})$ is the excitation energy of $^{58}\mathrm{N i}$ ,and Qis calculated in the first part of this task.But since $^{12}\mathsf{C}$ and $^{16}0$ have the same velocity, conservation of momentum reduced to: $\left[m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)-m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)\right]v\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)=m\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)v\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)$ Now we can easily find the kinetic energy of $^{58}\mathrm{N i}$ $E_{k}\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)=\frac{m\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)}{2}=\frac{\left[m\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)\right]^{2}}{2m\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)}=\frac{\left[\left[m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)-m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)\right]\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\right]^{2}}{2m\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)}=\frac{\left[\left[m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)-m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)\right]\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\right]^{2}}{2m\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)}=E_{k}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\frac{\left[m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)-m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)\right]^{2}}{m\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)}$ and finally the excitation energy of $^{58}\mathrm{N i}$ $$\left[\begin{array}{l}E_{x}\left(^{58}\mathrm{N i}\right)=E_{k}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)+Q-E_{k}\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)-E_{k}\left(^{58}\mathrm{N i}\right)=\\ =E_{k}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)+Q-\frac{m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)\cdot^{2}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)}{2}-E_{k}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\frac{\left[m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)-m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)\right]^{2}}{m\left(^{58}\mathrm{N i}\right)m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)}=\\ =Q+E_{k}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)-E_{k}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\cdot\frac{m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)}{m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)}-E_{k}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\frac{\left[m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)-m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)\right]^{2}}{m\left(^{58}\mathrm{N i}\right)m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)}=\\ =Q+E_{k}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\left[1-\frac{m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)}{m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)}-\frac{\left[m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)-m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)\right]^{2}}{m\left(^{58}\mathrm{N i}\right)m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)}\right]=\\ =Q+E_{k}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\frac{\left[m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)-m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)\right]\cdot\left[m\left(^{58}\mathrm{N i}\right)-m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)+m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)\right]}{m\left(^{58}\mathrm{N i}\right)m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)}\end{array}\right]$ Note that the first bracket in numerator is approximately equal to the mass of transferred particle (the 4He nucleus), while the second one is approximately equal to the mass of target nucleus $^{54}\mathsf{F e}$ .Inserting the numbers we get: $E_{x}(^{58}\mathrm{Ni})=-0.761+50\cdot\frac{(15.99491-12.)(57.93535-15.99491+12.)}{57.93535\cdot15.99491}=27.$ Relativistic solution In the relativistic version, solution is found starting from the following pair of equations (the first one is the law of conservation of energy and the second one the law of conservation of momentum): $m^{(54}\mathrm{Fe})\cdot c^{2}+\frac{m^{(16}\mathrm{O})\cdot c^{2}}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}(16\mathrm{O})/c^{2}}}=\frac{m^{(12}\mathrm{C})\cdot c^{2}}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}(12\mathrm{C})/c^{2}}}+\frac{m^{(58}\mathrm{Ni})\cdot c^{2}}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}(58\mathrm{Ni})/c^{2}}}$ $$\frac{m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\cdot v\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)/c^{2}}}=\frac{m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)\cdot v\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)/c^{2}}}+\frac{m^{*}\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)\cdot v\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)/c^{2}}}$$ All the masses in the equations are the rest masses; the $^{58}\mathrm{N i}$ is NOT in its ground-state, but in one of its excited states (having the mass denoted with $m^{*})$ .Since $^{12}\mathrm{C}\mathrm{a n d}^{16}\mathrm{O}$ have the same velocity, this set of equations reduces to: $\left[\begin{array}{c}m^{(54}\mathrm{Fe})+\frac{m^{(16}\mathrm{O})-m^{(12}\mathrm{C})}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}\left(16\mathrm{O}\right)/c^{2}}}=\frac{m^{*}\left(58\mathrm{Ni}\right)}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}\left(58\mathrm{Ni}\right)/c^{2}}}\\ \frac{\left(m^{(16}\mathrm{O}\right)-m^{(12}\mathrm{C})\right)\cdot v\left(16\mathrm{O}\right)}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}\left(16\mathrm{O}\right)/c^{2}}}=\frac{m^{*}\left(58\mathrm{Ni}\right)\cdot v\left(58\mathrm{Ni}\right)}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}\left(58\mathrm{Ni}\right)/c^{2}}}\end{array}\right]$ Dividing the second equation with the first one gives: $v\left(^{58}\mathrm{Ni}\right)=\frac{\left(m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)-m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)\right)\cdot v\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)}{\left(m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)-m\left(^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)\right)+m\left(^{54}\mathrm{Fe}\right)\sqrt{1-v^{2}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)/c^{2}}}$ (30) The velocity of projectile can be calculated from its energy: $\left\{\begin{array}{l}E_{k i n}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)=\frac{m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\cdot c^{2}}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)/c^{2}}}-m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\cdot c^{2}\\ \sqrt{1-v^{2}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)/c^{2}}=\frac{m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\cdot c^{2}}{E_{k i n}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)+m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\cdot c^{2}}\\ v^{2}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)/c^{2}=1-\left(\frac{m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\cdot c^{2}}{E_{k i n}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)+m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\cdot c^{2}}\right)^{2}\\ v\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)=\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\cdot c^{2}}{E_{k i n}\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)+m\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)\cdot c^{2}}\right)^{2}}\cdot c\end{array}\right.$ For the given numbers we get: $\left[\nu\left(^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)=\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{15.99491\cdot1.6605\cdot10^{-27}\cdot\left(2.9979\cdot10^8\right)^2}{50\cdot1.602\cdot10^{-13}+15.99491\cdot\left(2.9979\cdot10^8\right)^2}\right)^2}\cdot c=\sqrt{1-0.99666^2}\cdot c=0.08172\cdot c=2.4498\cdot10^7\mathrm{km/s}$ Now we can calculate: $v(^{58}\mathrm{Ni})=\frac{(15.99491-12.0)\cdot2.4498\cdot10^{7}\mathrm{~km/s}}{(15.99491-12.0)+53.93962\sqrt{1-0.08172^{2}}}=1.6946\cdot10^{6}\mathrm{~km/s}$ The mass of $^{58}\mathrm{{N i}}$ in its excited state is then: $\left[\begin{array}{l l}{m^{*}\left({}^{58}\mathrm{N}i\right)=\left(m\left({}^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)-m\left({}^{12}\mathrm{C}\right)\right)\frac{\sqrt{1-v^{2}\left({}^{58}\mathrm{N}i\right)/c^{2}}}{\sqrt{1-v^{2}\left({}^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)/c^{2}}}\cdot\frac{v\left({}^{16}\mathrm{O}\right)}{v\left({}^{58}\mathrm{N}i\right)}=}&{\left(34\right)}\\ {=\left(15.99491-12.0\right)\frac{\sqrt{1-\left(1.6945\cdot10^{6}/2.9979\cdot10^{8}\right)^{2}}}{\sqrt{1-0.08172^{2}}}\cdot\frac{2.4498\cdot10^{7}}{1.6945\cdot10^{6}}\mathrm{a.m.u.}}&{\left(34\right)}\\ {=57.9470\mathrm{a.m.u.}}&{\left(34\right)}\end{array}\right]$ The excitation energy of $^{58}\mathrm{N i}$ is then: $E_{x}=\left[m^{*}(^{58}\mathrm{Ni})-m(^{58}\mathrm{Ni})\right]\cdot c^{2}=(57.9470-57.93535)\cdot1.6605\cdot10^{-27}\left(2.9979\cdot10^{8}\right)^{2}=\left[2.00722\cdot10^{-12}/1.602\cdot10^{-13}\mathrm{~MeV}/\mathrm{J}\right] = 12.529\mathrm{~MeV}$ The relativistic and non-relativistic results are equal within 2 keV so both can be considered as correct -we can conclude that at the given beam energy,relativistic effects are not important.

The result should be a numerical value expressed in MeV.

reasoning_flow.step: List the rest masses (in a.m.u.) of 16O, 54Fe, 12C, and 58Ni from the problem statement.
Calculate the mass difference Δm = (total mass after reaction) - (total mass before reaction) in a.m.u., using masses from Step 1 (after reaction: 58Ni + 12C; before reaction: 54Fe + 16O).
Convert Δm from a.m.u. to kilograms using 1 a.m.u. = 1.6605·10^{-27} kg.
Compute the Q-value in joules using Q = -Δm * c^2 with c = 299792458 m/s and Δm from Step 3.
Convert the Q-value from joules to MeV using 1 MeV = 1.602·10^{-13} J.

Write the non-relativistic momentum conservation equation for the one-dimensional reaction assuming 12C has the same velocity as the incoming 16O: m(16O)v(16O)=m(12C)v(12C)+m(58Ni)v(58Ni), and reduce it using v(12C)=v(16O).
Express the kinetic energy of 58Ni non-relativistically in terms of v(58Ni) and then eliminate v(58Ni) using the relation from Step 6 to write E_k(58Ni) in terms of v(16O) and masses.
Write the non-relativistic energy conservation equation including excitation energy E_x: E_k(16O) + Q = E_k(12C) + E_k(58Ni) + E_x, and eliminate E_k(12C) using v(12C)=v(16O).
Compute the numeric factor F = [(m(16O)-m(12C))*(m(58Ni)-m(16O)+m(12C))] / [m(58Ni) m(16O)] using the masses from Step 1.
Compute E_x (non-relativistic) using E_x = Q + E_k(16O) * F with Q from Step 5, E_k(16O)=50 MeV and F from Step 9.
Write the relativistic expression for kinetic energy of 16O and derive the formula for its velocity v(16O) from E_k(16O) = m(16O) c^2 / sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2) - m(16O) c^2.
Compute v(16O) numerically using the formula from Step 11, m(16O)=15.99491 a.m.u. converted to kg, E_k(16O)=50 MeV, and c=2.9979·10^8 m/s.

Using relativistic conservation equations reduced for equal v(12C) and v(16O), derive the expression for v(58Ni) in terms of v(16O) and masses and compute v(58Ni) numerically using v(16O) from Step 12.
Compute the relativistic effective rest mass m*(58Ni) of the excited 58Ni from the momentum-energy reduced relations using v(16O), v(58Ni), and masses, then give m*(58Ni) in a.m.u.

Compute the excitation energy E_x (relativistic) as E_x = [m*(58Ni) - m(58Ni)] * 1 a.m.u. in kg * c^2 and convert the result to MeV using 1 MeV = 1.602·10^{-13} J, using m*(58Ni) from Step 14 and m(58Ni)=57.93535 a.m.u.
Compare the non-relativistic and relativistic excitation energies computed in Steps 10 and 15 and state whether they are numerically close.

question.text: A disk of radius r and mass M is placed on a fixed tube of radius R, as shown in Figure 2.The center of the disk is at a distance l from the ceiling and is attached to the ceiling through a spring of stiffness $k_{1}$ and unstretched length $l_{0}.$ At the same time, a block of mass m is hanging from the center of the disk on a spring of stiffness $k_{2}$  and unstretched length $l_{0}$ . We assume that the disk cannot slip on the tube and the lower spring remains vertical on any motion of the system. The constant of gravity is g. <image> Figure 2 Without deriving equations of motion, find sufficient and necessary conditions for the stability of the equilibrium shown in Fig. 2.

answer.text:
\begin{itemize}
  \item Active forces are potential (gravity, spring).
  \item Constraint forces do not work (no slip).\\
\(\Rightarrow\) system is conservative.\\
\(\rightarrow\) Dirichlet's theorem applies.\\
\end{itemize}
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \text { #DOF }=2 \times 3-2-2=2 \quad q_{1}=x, q_{2}=0 \\
& x_{0}=(R+r) \sin \theta \\
& y_{0}=(R+r) \cos \theta \\
& y_{m}=(R+r) \cos \theta-x \\
& V=V^{\text {disk }}+V^{b l o c k}+V^{s p r i n g 2}+V^{s p r i n g 1} \\
& V=M g y_{0}+m g y_{m}+\frac{1}{2} k_{2}\left(x-t_{0}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} k_{1}\left[\sqrt{x_{0}^{2}+\left(R+r+l-y_{0}\right)^{2}}-l_{0}\right]^{2} \\
& \frac{\partial V}{\partial x}=M g(R+r) \cos \theta+m g[(R+r) \cos \theta-x]+\frac{1}{2} k_{2}\left(x-l_{0}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} k_{1}[\underbrace{\left[(R+r)^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+[l+(R+r)(1-\cos \theta)]^{2}\right.}-l_{0}]^{2} \\
& \frac{\partial V}{\partial \theta}=-g(R+r) \sin \theta(M+m)+k_{1}\left(\sqrt{f}-l_{0}\right) \frac{f^{\prime}}{2 \sqrt{f}}=-g(R+r)(M+m) \sin \theta+\frac{k_{1} f^{\prime}}{2}\left(1-\frac{l_{0}}{\sqrt{f}}\right)
\end{aligned}
\]
where \(\quad f^{\prime}=2(R+r)\left(l^{\circ}+R+r\right) \sin \theta\)
\[
\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}=0 \quad \Rightarrow \begin{cases}x=l_{0}+\frac{m g}{k_{2}} & \text { is the equilibrium }=\text { hown in the figure } \\
\frac{\partial V}{\partial \theta}=0 & \theta=0\end{cases}
\]
For stability:
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}=k_{2} \\
& \frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial \theta \partial x}=0 \\
& \frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial \theta^{2}}=-g(R+r)(M+m) \cos \theta+\frac{k_{1} f^{\prime}}{2}\left(1-\frac{\ell}{\sqrt{f}}\right)+\frac{1}{4} k_{1} \ell_{0} \frac{f^{\prime 2}}{\sqrt{f^{3}}} \\
& f^{\prime\prime}=\left.2(R+r)(l+R+r) \cos \theta \quad f^{\prime}\right|_{\theta=0}=0 \\
& \left.f\right|_{\theta=0}=\left.\ell^{2} \quad f^{\prime}\right|_{\theta=0}=2(R+r)(l+R+r) \\
& \left.\rightarrow \quad \frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial \theta^{2}}\right|_{\theta=0}=-g(R+r)(M+m)+k_{1}(R+r)(l+R+r)\left(1-\frac{l}{l}\right) \\
& =(R+r)\left[k_{1}(l+R+r)\left(\frac{l-l_{0}}{l}\right)-g(M+m)\right]
\end{aligned}
\]
Hessian of \(V\) at equilibrium \(\left(\theta=0, x=\tau_{0}+\frac{m g}{k_{2}}\right)\) :
\[
D^{2} V=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
k_{2} & 0 \\
0 & (R+r)\left[k_{1}(l+R+r) \frac{l-l_{0}}{l}-g(M+m)\right]
\end{array}\right)
\]
\(D^{2} v\) is positive definite if and only if \(\left(k_{2}>0, R+r>0\right)\) :
\[
k_{1}(\ell+R+r) \frac{\ell-\ell_{0}}{\ell}-g(M+m)>0 \rightarrow \ell^{2}+\left[R+r-\ell_{0}-\frac{g}{k_{1}}(M+m)\right] \ell-(R+r) \ell_{0}>0
\Longrightarrow \ell>\frac{1}{2}\left\{\frac{g}{k_{1}}(M+m)-R-r+\ell_{0}+\sqrt{\left[R+r-\ell_{0}-\frac{g}{k_{1}}(M+m)\right]^{2}+4(R+r) \ell_{0}}\right\}
\]

short_answer_description: The sufficient and necessary condition for the stability of the equilibrium shown in the figure, expressed as a mathematical inequality involving the distance \ell (or l) and other system parameters (such as masses, radii, spring constants, and gravity) in LaTeX format.

reasoning_flow.step: Are all active forces (gravity and both springs) derivable from a potential?
Do the constraint forces associated with the no-slip condition do work on virtual displacements consistent with the constraints?
Given the answers to Steps 1 and 2, is the system conservative (i.e., total mechanical energy is potential + kinetic with no nonconservative work)?
Given the system is conservative, does Dirichlet's theorem (stability from positive-definite potential second variation at equilibrium) apply for assessing Lyapunov stability of the equilibrium?

Compute the number of degrees of freedom: start from 2 times 3 coordinates (disk center, disk orientation, block vertical displacement) and subtract the two holonomic constraints and two constraint relations listed in the reference; what is the DOF?

Choose generalized coordinates for the two DOF: name the coordinate for the extension of the lower spring and the coordinate for the disk rotation (or angular displacement from vertical). What are the chosen generalized coordinates?

Express the disk center coordinates (x_{0},y_{0}) in terms of R,r, and the disk angular displacement \theta, where x_{0} is horizontal offset and y_{0} is vertical position measured from the tube center line as in the reference.
Express the vertical coordinate y_{m} of the hanging block in terms of y_{0} and the lower spring extension coordinate x.

Write the total potential energy V as the sum of disk gravitational potential, block gravitational potential, lower spring energy (k_{2}), and upper spring energy (k_{1}) using the previously defined coordinates and unstretched lengths l_{0}. What is V?
Compute the partial derivative \partial V/\partial x (symbolically) from the expression of V in Step 9.

Compute the partial derivative \partial V/\partial \theta (symbolically) from the expression of V in Step 9, and express it using f:=x_{0}^{2}+[l+(R+r)-y_{0}]^{2} and f' denoting derivative of f wrt \theta.

Solve the equilibrium conditions \partial V/\partial x=0 and \partial V/\partial \theta=0 for x and \theta assuming small-angle equilibrium consistent with the figure. What are the equilibrium values x_{eq} and \theta_{eq}?

Compute the second partial derivatives \partial^{2}V/\partial x^{2}, \partial^{2}V/\partial x\partial\theta, and the general form of \partial^{2}V/\partial\theta^{2} (symbolic) from V, and then evaluate these at the equilibrium values from Step 12.

Form the Hessian matrix D^{2}V at equilibrium using the results of Step 13 and state the condition for positive-definiteness (stability) in terms of k_{2} and the expression for \partial^{2}V/\partial\theta^{2} evaluated at equilibrium.

Rearrange the inequality from Step 14 into a quadratic inequality in l and solve it to produce an explicit lower bound for l (the necessary and sufficient stability condition involving l). What is the bound for l?

question.text: <image> A coin (uniform solid circular disk) with mass M and radius b is set to roll in a circular path of radius R on a table surface $(\mathbb{R}>\mathsf{b})$ 1. The coin is given a spin angular velocity $\mathbf{\omega}_{S}$ ,and as it rolls it isfound to tilt at a small angle α with respect to vertical. Assume that the coin does not slip; constant gravity acts downward. Determine the total angular momentum vector,$\vec{L}$ , in terms of the quantities given in the diagram above, in a polar coordinate system centered on the center of the coin's trajectory. For simplicity, assume that α is very small (i.e.,only consider first order terms in α).

answer.text: The total angular momentum of the coin about its COM is the sum of the spin angular momentum and precession angular momentum vectors: $$\vec{L}=\vec{L}_{s}+\vec{L}_{\Omega}$$ The first is straightforward: $$\vec{L}_{s}= rac{1}{2}M b^{2}\omega_{s}(-\hat{r}\cos\alpha-\hat{z}\sin\alpha)$$ $$ oxed{I_{\parallel}}$$ The second is not because of the tilt of the coin, which leads to off-axis terms in the moment of inertia tensor (products of inertia). We can get an approximate handle on this by first breaking up the precession rotation vector into components parallel and perpendicular to the disk plane through the center of mass, as shown in the above diagram. Along these principal axes we compute the component angular momenta: $$L_{\parallel}=I_{\parallel}\Omega\cos\alpha= rac{1}{4}M b^{2}\Omega\cos\alpha $$ $$L_{\perp}=I_{\perp}\Omega\sin\alpha= rac{1}{2}M b^{2}\Omega\sin\alpha $$ we now have to project these axes back along the polar coordinates: $$ egin{aligned}{}&{{}\hat{\parallel}=\hat{z}\operatorname{c o s}\alpha-\hat{r}\operatorname{s i n}\alpha}\\ {}&{{}\hat{\perp}=\hat{z}\operatorname{s i n}\alpha+\hat{r}\operatorname{c o s}\alpha}\\ {}&{{}\operatorname{w h i c h~g i v e s:}}\\ {}&{{}\vec{L}_{\Omega}^{{C O M}}= rac{1}{4}M b^{2}\Omega[\hat{z}(\operatorname{c o s}^{2}\alpha+2\operatorname{s i n}^{2}\alpha)+\hat{r}\operatorname{s i n}\alpha\operatorname{c o s}\alpha]\approx rac{1}{4}M b^{2}\Omega[\hat{z}+\alpha\hat{r}]}\\ \end{aligned}$$ where the latter comes from our small angle approximation. Combining this with the spin angular momentum (and keeping the same approximation): $$ egin{array}{c}{\displaystyle\vec{L}\approx rac{1}{4}M b^{2}\omega_{s}[\hat{z}( rac{b}{R}-2\alpha)+\hat{r}( rac{b}{R}\alpha-2)]}\\ {\displaystyle oxed{\approx rac{1}{2}M b^{2}\omega_{s}[\hat{z}( rac{b}{2R}-\alpha)-\hat{r}]}}\\ {\displaystyle\approx rac{1}{2}M b^{2}\omega_{s}[ rac{b}{2R}(1- rac{3b\omega_{s}^{2}}{g})\hat{z}-\hat{r}]}\\ \end{array}$$ Note that we retain the assumption made in (c), that the radial angular momentum is primarily from the spin, and that because $\mathrm{b}<<\mathrm{R}$ . this component dominates the whole angular momentum vector, making the gyroscopic approximation a realistic one.

short_answer_description: The mathematical expression for the total angular momentum vector $\vec{L}$ in LaTeX format. The vector should be expressed in terms of the given parameters ($M, b, R, \omega_S, g$) and unit vectors (such as $\hat{r}$ and $\hat{z}$) within a polar coordinate system centered on the trajectory's center, applying the small angle approximation for $\alpha$.

reasoning_flow.step: State the moment of inertia of a uniform solid circular disk of mass M and radius b about (a) its symmetry axis (axis through center, perpendicular to disk plane) and (b) any diameter (axis in the disk plane through center).
reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: I_{sym} = \tfrac{1}{2} M b^{2},\quad I_{diameter} = \tfrac{1}{4} M b^{2}

reasoning_flow.step: Express the unit vector along the coin's symmetry axis (the disk normal) in polar coordinates (using unit vectors \hat{r} radially outward and \hat{z} upward) given that the axis is tilted by a small angle \alpha from vertical toward -\hat{r}.

Write the spin angular momentum vector of the disk about its center due to spin angular speed \omega_{s} around the disk symmetry axis, using the appropriate moment of inertia and the axis unit vector from the previous step.

For the precession (orbital) angular velocity vector of the coin about the center of the circular path, resolve this precession vector into components parallel to the disk plane's principal axis (in-plane diameter) and perpendicular to that plane (disk normal). Express these components in terms of the precession magnitude \Omega and tilt angle \alpha.

Using the principal moments from Step 1 and the precession components from Step 4, compute the magnitudes of the angular-momentum contributions due to precession along the in-plane diameter axis and along the disk normal axis.

Express the unit vectors of these principal axes (in-plane diameter axis and disk normal) in the polar basis (\hat{r},\,\hat{z}) given the tilt angle \alpha, so they can be projected back to polar coordinates.

Form the vector sum for the precession-contributed angular momentum \vec{L}_{\Omega} by combining the scalar magnitudes from Step 5 with the axis unit vectors from Step 6, then simplify the expression algebraically.

Apply the small-angle approximation (retain only first-order terms in \alpha: \sin\alpha\approx\alpha,\;\cos\alpha\approx1,\;\sin\alpha\cos\alpha\approx\alpha,\;\cos^{2}\alpha+2\sin^{2}\alpha\approx1) to simplify the expression for \vec{L}_{\Omega}.
Write the total angular momentum of the coin about its center as the sum of the spin contribution (Step 3) and the precession contribution (Step 8).
Apply small-angle approximations (\cos\alpha\approx1,\;\sin\alpha\approx\alpha) to the expression in Step 9 and collect coefficients of \hat{r} and \hat{z}.

Use the rolling-without-slipping kinematic relation between precession rate \Omega and spin rate \omega_{s} for the coin center moving on a circular path of radius R (for small tilt): express \Omega in terms of \omega_{s}, b and R.

Substitute the relation from Step 11 into the components in Step 10 and simplify, keeping only first-order terms in the small quantities \alpha and b/R (i.e., drop products of small quantities where appropriate).
Neglect second-order small products (such as (b/R)\alpha) and factor out the common prefactor to give the leading-order approximate form of the total angular momentum in the polar basis.

question.text: Consider the combined cycle power plant shown in Figure 3. Air at 300 K and 100 kPa enters the compressor whose isentropic efficiency is 80%. It is then compressed to 800 kPa, and heated to 500K. The hot stream leaving the gas turbine, which operates with an isentropic efficiency of 88%, flows through the HRSG, where it is cooled to 423 K. Superheated steam at 723 K and 8 MPa enters the steam turbine and it is expanded to 6 kPa. The mass of fuel burnt in the combustor is negligible compared to that of the air. The isentropic efficiencies of the steam turbine and pump are 90% and 70%, respectively. <image> Figure 3 - Combined cycle powerplant Determine: The work output of the gas and steam cycles.

answer.text:
For the gas cycle:
$$W_{n e t.G C}=W_{G T}-W_{c}$$
$$W_{G T}=h_{3}-h_{4}$$
where:
$$h_{3}=1636\mathrm{k J/k g}$$
$$W_{G T}=h_{3}-h_{4}=1636-1018=618\mathrm{k J/k g}$$
Similarly:
$$W_{c}=h_{2}-h_{1}$$
$$T_{2}=T_{1}\left(1+\frac{1}{\eta_{c}}\left[\left(r_{p}\right)^{\frac{k-1}{k}}-1\right]\right)=300\left(1+\frac{1}{0.8}\left[(8)^{\frac{0.39}{1.39}}-1\right]\right)=597.1\:\mathrm{K}$$
$$h_{1}=300.4\mathrm{k J/k g},h_{2}=604.3\mathrm{k J/k g}$$
$$W_{c}=h_{2}-h_{1}=604.3-300.4=303.9kJ/kg $$
Therefore:
$$W_{n e t.G C}=W_{G T}-W_{c}=618-303.9=314.1\mathrm{k J/k g}$$
For the steam cycle (note $p_{9}=6\:\mathrm{k}\mathrm{P a}\:\mathrm{a n d}\:s_{9s}=s_{8});$ 
$$h_{9s}=2019\mathrm{k J/k g}$$
$$h_{9}=h_{8}-\eta_{ST}(h_{8}-h_{9s})=3273-0.9(3273-2019)=2144.4\mathrm{kJ/kg}$$
$$W_{ST}=\alpha(h_{8}-h_{9})=0.19(3273-2144.4)=214.4k]/kg $$
$$W_{p}=\alpha(h_{7}-h_{6})=0.19(162.9-151.5)=2.166kJ/kg $$
$$W_{n e t.S C}=W_{S T}-W_{p}=214.4-2.166=212.2\mathrm{k J/k g}$$
The net work output of the combined cycle is:
$$W_{n e t}=W_{n e t,G C}+W_{n e t,S C}=526.3\mathrm{k J/k g}$$

short_answer_description: The calculated net work output specifically for the gas turbine cycle (Brayton cycle) component of the power plant. The answer should be a numerical value representing specific work, typically in units of kJ/kg.

The calculated net work output specifically for the steam turbine cycle (Rankine cycle) component of the power plant. The answer should be a numerical value representing specific work, typically in units of kJ/kg.

The total net work output for the entire combined cycle power plant, representing the sum of the gas and steam cycle net works. The answer should be a numerical value representing specific work, typically in units of kJ/kg.

State the given enthalpy h4 for the gas-turbine exit (from the problem data or reference values).
Using the enthalpies from Steps 1–2, compute the gas turbine specific work W_GT = h3 - h4.
State the compressor inlet temperature T1 (from the problem statement).
State the compressor isentropic efficiency η_c and the pressure ratio r_p (from the problem statement).

question.text:
A flux of monochromatic electrons impinges on a pair of long narrow slits, as shown in the picture. When slit 1 is open and slit 2 is closed, a detector at point P registers the rate of $n_{1}=100$ electrons/sec. When slit 2 is open and slit 1 is closed, the rate at P is $n_{2}\;=$ 25 electrons/sec. The distance between the slits is $d=$ 25 m, the distance from the slits to the screen is $\ell=$ 1 m, and the distance from the center of the screen to $P$ is $x=50~\mu\mathrm{m}$ Find the rate at P with both slits open for electrons of kinetic energy of (a)$K=1.0\:\mathrm{e V}$ 

<image>

answer.text:
This is a classic Young interference problem for electrons. The wavefunction of the electron on the right side of the slits is a superposition of two wavefunctions:

$$\Psi=\Psi_{1}+\Psi_{2}$$

where 

$$ egin{aligned}{\Psi_{1}\;}&{{}=\;C_{1}\exp rac{i}{\hbar}(p r_{1}-E t)}\ {\Psi_{2}\;}&{{}=\;C_{2}\exp rac{i}{\hbar}(p r_{2}-E t)}\end{aligned}$$

the wavefunctions $\Psi_{1}$ and $\Psi_{2}$ describe electrons origi nating in each slit. The distances $r_{1}$ and $r_{2}$ are given by geometry:

$$ egin{aligned}&r_{1}\;=\;\sqrt{\ell^{2}+(x-d/2)^{2}};\&r_{2}\;=\;\sqrt{\ell^{2}+(x+d/2)^{2}};\ \end{aligned}$$

The overall wavefunction is 

$$ egin{aligned}{\Psi\;}&{{}=\;C_{1}\operatorname{e x p} rac{i}{\hbar}(p r_{1}-E t)\left(1+ rac{C_{2}}{C_{1}}\operatorname{e x p} rac{i}{\hbar}p(r_{2}-r_{1})ight)}\ {}&{{}\approx\;\Psi_{1}\left(1+ rac{C_{2}}{C_{1}}\operatorname{e x p}[- rac{i}{\hbar}p x d/\ell]ight)}\ \end{aligned}$$

The counting rate depends on the probability to observe the electron at a given location,$i.e.$ 

$$R=|\Psi|^{2}=R_{1}\left(1+(C_{2}/C_{1})^{2}+2C_{2}/C_{1}\cos( rac{p x d}{\ell\hbar})ight)$$

where the ratio of the normalization coefficients is given by the ratio of rates of electrons going through one slit at a time:

$${ rac{R_{1}}{R_{2}}}=\left({ rac{C_{1}}{C_{2}}}ight)^{2}$$

The momentum of the electron is 

$$p=\sqrt{2K m}$$

and finally 

$$R=R_{1}\left(1+(R_{2}/R_{1})+2(R_{2}/R_{1})^{1/2}\cos\deltaight)$$

The phase shift 

$$\delta={ rac{{\sqrt{2K m}}x d}{\ell\hbar}}$$

is most convenient to compute using $\hbar c=0.2\mathrm{e V}\cdot\mu\mathrm{m}$ We get (a):

$$\delta=6.3\approx2\piightarrow R=R_{1}+R_{2}=125\:\mathrm{e l e c t r o n s/s e c}$$

short_answer_description: The calculated rate of electrons registered at the detector at point P when both slit 1 and slit 2 are open, for the specified kinetic energy. The response should be a numerical value with units of electrons/sec.

State the final numerical result for the counting rate at P with both slits open (in electrons/sec).

question.text:
We are searching for the number 7 in the following binary tree:

<image>

We use the following algorithm (which terminates with probability 1):

(a) Write down the number currently at the root node 

(b) If we wrote down 7, terminate 

 Else, pick a random edge, and swap the two numbers at the endpoints of that edge 

(d) Go back to step 1

Let $p(a)$ be the probability that we ever write down the number a after running the algorithm once. Find 

$$p(1)+p(2)+p(3)+p(5)+p(6).$$

answer.text:
First, we have $ egin{array}{r}{p(1)=p(3)=p(5)= rac{1}{2}}\end{array}$ . By symmetry, there is $\mathrm{~a~}	extstyle{ rac{1}{2}}$ chance that 1 gets to the root before 7 does. The same holds for 3 and 5.

Next, we compute $p(2)$ 1. Consider the first time either 2 or 7 is moved. There is $\mathrm{~a~} rac{1}{4}$ chance that this move brings 2 to the root, and $\mathrm{~a~}	extstyle{ rac{3}{4}}$ chance that this move brings 2 and 7 to the same level,at which point we can apply symmetry. This gives us $p(2)={	extstyle{ rac{1}{4}}}+{	extstyle{ rac{3}{4}}}\cdot{	extstyle{ rac{1}{2}}}={	extstyle{ rac{5}{8}}}$ 

Finally, we compute $p(6)$ . For this case, we can consider the first time 6 or 7 is moved. There is $\mathrm{~a~}	extstyle{ rac{1}{3}}$ chance that 6 is moved to the root, a $ rac{1}{3}$ chance that 6 is moved to the same level as $7.$ and a $ rac{1}{3}$ chance that 6 and 7 are swapped. We get 

$$p(6)={ rac{1}{3}}+{ rac{1}{3}}\cdot{ rac{1}{2}}+{ rac{1}{3}}(1-p(6)),$$

and we can solve this equation to get $	extstyle p(6)={ rac{5}{8}}$ 

In total,

$$p(1)+p(2)+p(3)+p(5)+p(6)= rac{1}{2}+ rac{5}{8}+ rac{1}{2}+ rac{1}{2}+ rac{5}{8}= oxed{ rac{11}{4}}.$$

short_answer_description: The calculated probability p(1) that the number 1 is ever written down (appears at the root node) before the algorithm terminates. The answer should be a mathematical expression or fraction in LaTeX format.

The calculated probability p(2) that the number 2 is ever written down (appears at the root node) before the algorithm terminates. The answer should be a mathematical expression or fraction in LaTeX format.

The calculated probability p(3) that the number 3 is ever written down (appears at the root node) before the algorithm terminates. The answer should be a mathematical expression or fraction in LaTeX format.

The calculated probability p(5) that the number 5 is ever written down (appears at the root node) before the algorithm terminates. The answer should be a mathematical expression or fraction in LaTeX format.

The calculated probability p(6) that the number 6 is ever written down (appears at the root node) before the algorithm terminates. The answer should be a mathematical expression or fraction in LaTeX format.
The final sum of the probabilities p(1) + p(2) + p(3) + p(5) + p(6). The answer should be a single mathematical expression or fraction in LaTeX format representing the total value.

reasoning_flow.verifiable_answer: p(a)=probability that number a is ever written down (i.e., appears at the root while running algorithm once)

question.text:
A person is in one of four rooms, and after each time step has a probability $1/(M+1)$ of moving to an adjacent room where M is the number of adjacent rooms; The probability of remaining in place is $1/(\overrightarrow{M}+1)$ 1.

<image>

Figure 4: Four connected rooms. The person has a probability $1/(M+1)$ of remaining in place and a probability of $1/(M+1)$ of moving to any one of the adjacent rooms.

 Using the relationship between equilibrium probabilities and transition probabilities (along with the fact that the equilibrium probabilities are normalized), compute the equilibrium probabilities $\it{p_{1}^{\mathrm{{e q}}},p_{2}^{\mathrm{{e q}}},p_{3}^{\mathrm{{e q}}},\mathrm{{a n d}}p_{4}^{\mathrm{{\bar{e}q}}}}$ , to be in rooms 1, 2, 3, and 4.

answer.text:
We can use the transition probabilities to determine the equilibrium probabilities $p_{j}^{\mathrm{e q}}$ by using the detailed balance equation:

$$\frac{p_{j}^{\mathrm{e q}}}{p_{i}^{\mathrm{e q}}}=\frac{\pi_{i\rightarrow j}}{\pi_{j\rightarrow i}}.$$

Choosing unique ratios for Eq.(55), we find 

$$\begin{aligned}\frac{p_{1}^{\mathrm{eq}}}{p_{3}^{\mathrm{eq}}}&=\frac{1/4}{1/2}\\&=\frac{1}{2}\quad\longrightarrow\quad p_{1}^{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{1}{2}p_{3}^{\mathrm{eq}}\\\frac{p_{2}^{\mathrm{eq}}}{p_{3}^{\mathrm{eq}}}&=\frac{1/4}{1/2}\\&=\frac{1}{2}\quad\longrightarrow\quad p_{2}^{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{1}{2}p_{3}^{\mathrm{eq}}\\\frac{p_{3}^{\mathrm{eq}}}{p_{4}^{\mathrm{eq}}}&=\frac{1/2}{1/4}\\&=2\quad\longrightarrow\quad p_{4}^{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{1}{2}p_{3}^{\mathrm{eq}}.\end{aligned}$$

With probability normalization and these results we have 

$$1=p_{1}^{\mathrm{e q}}+p_{2}^{\mathrm{e q}}+p_{3}^{\mathrm{e q}}+p_{4}^{\mathrm{e q}}=\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}+1+\frac{1}{2}\right)p_{3}^{\mathrm{e q}}=\frac{5}{2}p_{3}^{\mathrm{e q}},$$

which implies 

$$\boxed{p_{3}^{\mathrm{e q}}=\frac{2}{5}.}$$

From Eq.(56), Eq.(57), and Eq.(58) we then obtain 

$$\boxed{p_{1}^{\mathrm{e q}}=p_{2}^{\mathrm{e q}}=p_{4}^{\mathrm{e q}}=\frac{1}{5}.}$$

question.text:
Attached are 8 spectrograms of short utterances. Some are spoken by a female speaker and some by a male speaker. The sentences from which these utterances are drawn are:

A. I saw Timmy.

B. I see Timmy.

C. I saw Tommy.

D. I see Tommy.

E. I saw Tammy.

F. I see Tammy.

Some utterances may be repeated (and maybe some are not represented).

<image>

<image>

<image>

 For each spectrogram, identify which utterance was produced.

answer.text:
To distinguish between "see" and "saw", we know that /i/ is a front, high vowel,with a high F2 (2290-2790 Hz, Peterson & Barney) and a very low F1 (270-310Hz, Peterson & Barney), while /o/ is a non-low back vowel, with F2 range of 840-920 Hz (P&B), and F1 range of 570-590 Hz (P&B). If the two formants in the spectrogram are far apart, it must be "see", otherwise, it is "saw".

Similarly, to distinguish the three names:

/I/in Timmy, is a laxed front high vowel, meaning F1 (270-310, P&B) and F2(2290-2790, P&B) are far apart similar to /i/, and the duration of the vowel is short.



/o/ in Tommy, like that in "saw", has F1 near 580 Hz, and F2 ranging from 840920Hz. The duration of the vowel would be longer than that in Timmy.

/æ/ in Tammy, is a low (high F1, 660-860 Hz, B&P) front (high F2, 1720-2050Hz, B&P) vowel. It is also a tense vowel, so it would have a longer duration than that of Timmy.



Spectrogram 1: second vowel has F1 and F2 far apart => "see"third vowel has F1 and F2 close together => "Tommy"=>  I see Tommy 

Spectrogram 2: second vowel has F1 and F2 far apart => "see"third vowel has F1 and F2 close together => "Tommy"=>I see Tommy 

Spectrogram 3: second vowel has F1 and F2 close together => "saw"third vowel has F1 and F2 close together => "Tommy"=>I saw Tommy 

Spectrogram 4: second vowel has F1 and F2 far $\mathrm{a p a r t}=>\mathrm{``s e e''}$ third vowel's F1 and F2 are far apart,the duration is not short => "Tammy"

=>I see Tammy 

Spectrogram 5: second vowel has F1 and F2 close together => "saw"third vowel's F1 and F2 are far apart,the duration is $\mathrm{s h o r t}=>\mathrm{{}^{\mathrm{{}^{\mathrm{{}^{\mathrm{{}^{\mathrm{{}^{\mathrm{}{T}}}}}}}}}}}\\mathrm{T i m m y}}}$ 

=>I saw Timmy 

Spectrogram 6: second vowel has F1 and F2 far $\mathrm{a pa r t}=>\mathrm{``s e e}$ third vowel's F1 and F2 are far apart,the duration is short => "Timmy"

=>I see Timmy 

Spectrogram 7: second vowel has F1 and F2 close together => "saw"third vowel's F1 and F2 are far apart,the duration is short => "Timmy"

$\Rightarrow\boxed{\mathrm{I s a w~T i m m y}}$ 



Spectrogram 8: second vowel has F1 and F2 close together => "saw"third vowel's F1 and F2 are far apart,the duration is not short => "Tammy"=> I saw Tammy

question.text:
The Bode plot of a stable discrete-time filter is shown below.

<image>

a)What is the transfer function $G(z)$ of this filter? Explain how you estimated the filter transfer function from the given Bode plot. Sketch the filter poles and zeros on the zplane.

answer.text:
From the plot, we can see
there is a zero @ \(10^{-3}\)
There is a pile. @ \(10^{-2}\)
There is a double pole@ \(10^{-1}\)
zero:

\[
\frac{z-\alpha}{1-\alpha}=\frac{z-.999}{1-.999}=1000(z-.999)
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1-\alpha}{z-\alpha}=\frac{1-.99}{z-.99}=\frac{1}{100} \frac{1}{z-.99} \\
& \frac{1-2 r \cos \Omega+r^{2}}{z^{2}-z(2 r \cos \Omega)+r^{2}} \\
& \Omega=10^{-1}, \frac{1}{2(1-r)}=\sqrt{10}, r=0.9841 \\
& \frac{1-2 r \cos \Omega+r^{2}}{z^{2}-z(z r \cos \Omega)+r^{2}}=\frac{1}{100} \frac{1}{z^{2}-2(2 r \cos \Omega)+r^{2}}
\end{aligned}
\]

pole(s):

Gain of 10 at \(D C\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
& G(z)=1000(z-.999) \frac{1}{100}\left(\frac{1}{z-.99}\right) \frac{1}{100}\left(\frac{10}{z^{2}-z(2 r \cos \Omega)+r^{2}}\right) \\
& G(z)=\frac{z-.999}{z-.99} \frac{1}{z^{2}-z(z r \cos \Omega)+r^{2}}\\right), \Omega=10^{-1}, r=.9841
\end{aligned}
\]

short_answer_value: {0.99, roots of z^2 - z(z r cos Ω) + r^2 = 0 (complex conjugate pair)}

question.text: In this problem we examine the acoustic and perceptual consequences of speaking loudly compared with speaking in a normal voice. We focus here on just one word – the word cat –produced in a normal and a loud voice. Spectrograms of the two utterances are shown in Figures 1.la and 1.1b, and spectra sampled near the middle of each vowel are given in Figures 1.2a and 1.2b. These are DFT spectra obtained with a 25.6 ms window, with a time window that is displayed superimposed on the waveform below each spectrum. The reference for amplitude scales (in dB)for the spectra are arbitrary, except that the reference is the same for the two spectra, i.e., the spectra (and the waveforms below them) correctly represent the relative amplitudes. In making the spectrograms in Figure 1.1, however, the overall amplitudes are normalized to have the same maximum amplitude. <image> Figure 1.1 <image> Figure 1.2 Estimate the diference, in dB, between the overall sound pressure levels for the two vowels,as represented by the spectra in Figure 1.2?

answer.text:

question.text: Another problem to test your knowledge on continuity conditions. A system of two identical beams shown in the figure below is a statically determined problem. The beams are rigidly welded, so that the angle remains 90 degrees. <image> Determine (Note: Do not solve this problem using the Castigliano's theorem, which is much simpler, but has not been covered yet.) Find the relation between the tip--- load and the vertical displacement of the tip.(Hint: assume the rotations to be very small.)

answer.text:
From moment distribution of beam 1, we know 
$$M_{1}=\frac{P}{2}(L-y)\quad0<y<L $$
Governing equation 
$$-EI\frac{d^{2}w_{1}}{dy^{2}}=M_{1}=\frac{P}{2}(L-y)\quad0<y<L $$
Integrate twice 
$$w_{1}=-\frac{P}{2EI}\left(\frac{Ly^{2}}{2}-\frac{y^{3}}{6}\right)+C_{1}y+C_{2}\quad0<y<L $$
Apply boundary conditions 
$$\begin{aligned}&\left.w_{1}\right|_{y=0}=\left.w_{1}\right|_{y=L}=0\\&\Rightarrow C_{1}=\frac{PL^{2}}{6EI},C_{2}=0\\ \end{aligned}$$
$$w_{1}=-\frac{P}{2EI}\left(\frac{Ly^{2}}{2}-\frac{y^{3}}{6}\right)+\frac{PL^{2}}{6EI}y\quad0<y<L $$
At.$\\scriptstyle{\mathrm{y}}=0$ 
$$\left|\theta=\frac{PL^{2}}{6EI}\right]$$
Vertical displacement of point O 
$$u_{o}=\int_{x=L}^{o}\varepsilon d y=\int_{x=L}^{o}\frac{P}{E A}d y=\frac{P L}{E A}$$
Integrate governing equation of beam 2
$$-E I\frac{d^{2}w_{2}}{d y^{2}}=M_{2}=-P(L-x)$$
We have 
$$-EI\frac{dw_{2}}{dx}=-P\left(Lx-\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right)+C_{1}$$
$$-E I w_{2}=P\left(\frac{L x^{2}}{2}-\frac{x^{3}}{6}\right)+C_{1}x+C_{2}$$
Use angle continuity condition 
$$\begin{aligned}&-EI\frac{dw_{2}}{dx}\bigg|_{x=0}=\theta_{1}\bigg|_{x=0}=\frac{PL^{2}}{6EI}\\ &\Rightarrow C_{1}=-\frac{PL^{2}}{6}\\ \end{aligned}$$
$$\begin{aligned}&\left.w_{2}\right|_{x=0}=u_{0}=\frac{PL}{EA}\\ &\Rightarrow C_{2}=-\frac{PIL}{A}\\ \end{aligned}$$
Finally 
$$w_{2}=\frac{P}{EI}\left(\frac{Lx^{2}}{2}-\frac{x^{3}}{6}\right)+\frac{PL^{2}}{6EI}x+\frac{PL}{EA}$$
$\\mathrm{A t}\\mathrm{x}=\\mathrm{L}$ , the tip deflection is 
$$w_{p}=\frac{PL^{3}}{2EI}+\frac{PL}{EA}$$
Now, let's compare the magnitude of the two terms in $w_{p}$ , for a square cross-section 
$$\frac{w_{p}^{\prime\prime}}{w_{p}^{\prime\prime}}=\frac{\frac{PL}{EA}}{\frac{PL^{3}}{2EI}}=\frac{2I}{LA}=\frac{2\cdot\frac{h^{3}}{12}}{Lh^{2}}=\frac{1}{6}\left(\frac{h}{l}\right)^{2}$$
For $h/L=1/20,w_{p}^{I I}/w_{p}^{I}=0.25\times10^{-3}$ $w_{p}^{\mathit{\Pi}}$ , which is the deflection caused by compression,is three orders of magnitudes smaller than ${w_{p}}^{I}$ , which is the deflection caused by bending.

Apply the angular continuity condition at the joint: set the internal bending moment derivative relation for beam 2 at x=0 equal to theta1 from Step 6 and solve for C1 (use -EI dw2/dx|_{x=0}=\theta_{1}).
Apply the vertical displacement continuity at the joint: set w2(0)=u0 (with u0 from Step 7) and solve for C2.
Substitute C1 and C2 from Steps 11 and 12 into the general expression from Step 10 to obtain the particular w2(x).
Evaluate the tip deflection w_p by substituting x=L into w2(x) from Step 13.

For a square cross-section with area A=h^{2} and second moment I=h^{4}/12 (note: I for square of side h about centroidal axis is h^{4}/12 or h^{3}b/12 with b=h; use I=h^{4}/12), substitute A and I into the ratio from Step 15 and simplify to express the ratio in terms of h and L.
